column2: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 2 -- The South Korean delegation to the Red Cross talks to reunite divided families returned home from Pyongyang, North Korea, today after participating in the opening session that began there Wednesday.

. . . to New York City from abroad, leave your smoked salmons at home, but bring your potential for awe, for wonderment and for absorbing experiences you are not likely to have elsewhere. Most Americans won't speak your language, but in New York City there will be someone who does, if you can find him.
You all deserve some fun. . . . Have it. . . . The garden can do without you 'til next week.
LONDON -- The great "cod war" was on again last week.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2 -- A union drive to organize health care employes here was marked by protests this week after a union organizer was shot to death outside Metropolitan Hospital, allegedly by a private security guard.
A gypsy cab driver was shot and killed in the Morrisania section of the Bronx last night by three holdup men who fled on foot, the police reported.

ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Bill Parsons scattered seven hits and drove in two runs with a pair of hits today as the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Texas Rangers, 6-2, before the smallest crowd ever to see a major league game at Arlington Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- After months of negotiations involving the United States Steel Corporation, the State of Pennsylvania and Allegheny County, a prospective agreement on a plan to clean up air polution by the concern's huge coke plant at Clairton is in danger of coming apart.

AT a Society for Photographic Education conference some time ago, a parent addressed a question to the two panel members most involved with the psychology of photography, Ralph Hattersley and myself. He asked passionately, "What right do you have to meddle with the inner workings of our children?"

OBERSCHLEISSHEIM, West Germany, Sept. 2 -- Catching a boatload of East German cops in a photo finish, the United States eight-oared crew went second to New Zealand in a rousing race for America's only rowing medal in these Olympic Games.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 2 -- John Lowenstein hit a three-run homer and Steve Dunning hit a two-run homer, leading the Cleveland Indians to a 5-3 triumph over the Minnesota Twins today.
COLTS NECK -- Whether or not this township's name came from its resemblance -either real or fancied -- to a colt's neck, there's no doubt about the influence of horses on its life-style.
The arrest rates for drug addicts enrolled in the city's methadone treatment program have dropped by as much as 82 per cent, according to data released yesterday.
MINEOLA, L.I. -- Despite the conciliation called for under the state's five-yearold divorce law, the majority of Long Islanders now seeking divorce win their decrees without any conciliation attempt.

In her article on "Frenzy," Victoria Sullivan says she wants to see films about men getting raped by women, seeing "the look of terror in his eyes when he suddenly realizes she is bigger, stronger and far more brutal than he."

SEOUL -- The meeting was mostly "atmosphere" -- smiles, handshakes, friendly gestures by delegates of both sides. The only concrete result of the three-hour meeting in Pyongyang last Wednesday was the adoption of a five-point agenda for a second session to be held Sept. 13 in Seoul.

The swing is toward "law and order"; the issue of students' rights is running into formidable hostility. At least with regard to the schools, the mood of the public has taken a marked conservative turn this year.

There's a basic human instinct, a fundamental urge that Sigmund Freud never properly acknowledged. Joseph Hirschhorn, the uranium tycoon, has it and so does Michael Lewis, a 15-year-old schoolboy from Chappaqua, N. Y.

Cheers for Ellen Peck's thoughtful analysis of motherhood in the world of day-time television. As the mother of two most wanted and deeply loved children, I know and appreciate the joys involved, yet I resent the dishonest and foolish TV use of motherhood as a panacea for all women.
One third of the 930,000 residents of Essex County report a language other than English as their "mother tongue."
TITUSVILLE -- On Christmas night, 1776, despite fiercely adverse conditions, George Washington crossed the Delaware River from Pennsylvania, with his army of 2,400 men, his horses and his cannons.

MOSCOW, Sept. 2 -- The tempo of anti-American propaganda in the Soviet press has risen sharply in recent days from the restrained period of President Nixon's visit here, when the mining of Haiphong harbor went unmentioned for 21 days.
SOMEWHAT involved as I am with the museums of the Dukes County Historical Society on Martha's Vineyard, I have come to know of the strong attachment people have to things old, rare and beautiful.

The securities markets, as last week clearly showed, are constantly shifting, never behaving quite the same way twice. The week before last, stock prices declined, depressed largely by the prospect of higher interest rates and tighter money conditions. Last week, by contrast, interest rates kept rising but stock prices rose, too.

DETROIT -- Everything is going up: groceries, taxes, rent -- but not prices for new cars. At least not now. Last week the Price Commission denied increases to General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, the two biggest car makers, saying their profits might be too high if prices went up.
CLEVELAND -- Ohioans, like most people, have been inclined to take their banking services pretty much as they find them.

MONMOUTH JUNCTION -- For Dennis Biddle, a South Brunswick High School sophomore, it was more than "what I did on my summer vacation"; it was a practical application of some of the theories he has been taught en route to his chosen study of architecture.

On Sept. 15 a group of Baker Street Irregulars will be at Belmont Park to celebrate the twenty-first running of the "Silver Blaze." These devout followers of Sherlock Holmes meet at the races once a year to do honor to that great man.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 2 (Reuters) -- The Marxist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens today spoke of the existence of a seditious "September plan" and said any attempt at a coup would be met by a nationwide general strike and occupation of plants and buildings by workers.

" I've just read over what I've written," says the narrator-protagonist of this novel. "My name is Abel Tiffauges. I run a garage in the Place de la Porte des Ternes and I'm not crazy." I've just read the whole of the story of Abel Tiffauges. My own perceptions and pretensions have been stripped so bare by this strange, rich, terrifying book that I cannot stand with Tiffauges and proclaim my sanity.

Sam Posey, an auto race driver whose business base is in San Juan Capistrano, Cal., has returned to Connecticut, his home. Connecticut is his home two ways. His residence is in Sharon, and his home track is at Lime Rock, where he first learned about cornering and drafting.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 -- Milt Pappas of the Chicago Cubs came within one strike of the 12th perfect game in baseball history today as he hurled a no-hitter against the San Diego Padres.

SAYVILLE, L. I., Sept. 2 -- Chuck and Dennis O'Malley finished one-two in the Raven Class today, and another brother combination, Bob and Mark Powell, was first and second among the Finns as the Sayville Yacht Club's annual Labor Day weekend regatta got under way.

State Industrial Commissioner Louis L. Levine completed a series of public hearings last week on New York's proposed occupational safety and health plan and reported that he had found general approval for having the state continue its program.

MONTREAL, Sept. 2 -- In a shock to Canada's nervous system, the remarkably controlled Soviet Union national team tonight trounced the National Hockey League's finest players, 7-3, in the first meeting between the world's top professional and amateur hockey teams.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 2 (AP) -- Vinny Giles ended several years of frustration today by shooting a 72 for a 285 total and a three-shot victory in the United States amateur golf championship.
WEST NEW YORK -- A Catholic parish here is experimenting with a new form of government -- the team ministry.
MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Army Major Lones Wigger of Columbus, Ga., won the Olympic free rifle shooting gold medal today, a hair's breadth ahead of Boris Melnik of the Soviet Union.

For many Americans party politics seems pointless and closed. Still our political parties, for all their current limitations, offer citizens the best potential for redirecting American politics. The unprecedented changes that have occurred in the representative structure and procedures of the Democratic party since 1968 are clear indications that extensive party modernization is an entirely feasible goal for the nineteen-seventies.

With the world's best tennis players competing together for the first time this year, Forest Hills has taken on a linguistic flavor. The streets around the West Side Tennis Club are buzzing with dialects.
Many Labor Day weekend barbecues are featuring steaks and hamburgers this year because prices of red meat dropped just before the holiday, instead of rising in anticipation of increased demand.

Florida millionaire Glenn W. Turner has an ample assembly of critics -- including the attorneys general of most of the 50 states -- but even his detractors agree he is something of a phenomenon. "The man," said one assistant attorney general who tangled with him, "is incredible.

WASHINGTON -- President Nixon's celebrated but never really stated four-year "plan" to resolve the nation's agony in Vietnam was, in fact, a three-tiered strategy aimed at that pivotal day of reckoning, Nov. 7, 1972. As Election Day nears, only one of those tiers has actually been reached, but the President appears to have been right in calculating that this would suffice to mollify the voters.

Jean Renoir remains to this day the only notable film director with a hereditary claim to artistic eminence. His childhood features have been immortalized in four of Papa Auguste Renoir's most famous paintings.

The family's dental experience in Germany made for interesting reading, but it probably should be taken with a grain of salt. Expecting a patient to control an orthodontic appliance for a lengthy time is just too much to ask. I a!'a reminded of Bob and Ray who, on their radio program a few years hack, used to advertise a home-use, do-ityourself brain surgery kit. That never caught on either.
OAKLAND, Sept. 2 (AP) -- Bill Freehan and Mickey Stanley hit home runs in the 11th inning, giving the Detroit Tigers a 3-1 victory over the Oakland A's today.

After having herself been isolated and barred from the United Nations since its inception twenty-seven years ago, what sad, ironic commentary that the Peking Government should cast its first veto to exclude Bangladesh from entry to this world body.

After a month of plays, block parties, dance and music events, movies, children's theater and community happenings, the first International Festival, an undertaking of the Brooklyn Arts and Culture Association, will culminate tomorrow with a massive West Indian-American parade down Eastern Parkway.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Sept. 2 -- Dennis Powers, with Wild Woozle in the Etchells-22 race, and Dr. George K. Brazill Jr., with Double Dare in the Shields Class, were .winners on Long Island Sound today in the season's 31st Yacht Racing Association championship regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.
Someone should point out to Mr. Bannard and other art representatives that "The War Against The Good In Art" is the same war against good that's going on all around us.

That was a great article by Martha Lear, "Save the Spouses Rather Than the Marriage" (Aug. 13). As a sex teacher and author of books for children on sex, I am impressed that our society through its schools holds up to the kids too insistently the motto: Be Married.
The Aug. 6 article on the city's housing court plan leaves out one of the quaint examples of the Lindsay administration's incompetence.

SOME months ago there appeared a perfectly respectable "Die Zauberflote" on Eurodisc, an East German label. It proved to be a performance ably conducted by Otmar Suitner, but most compelling for the fine Pamina and Tamino of Helen Donath and Peter Schreier.

The seven major independent Eastern college football teams scrap among themselves on and off the field and meet more intersectional opponents than any seven conference teams in the nation. They know one another's strengths and weaknesses thoroughly and compete with one another in the recruiting wars.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2 -- East Germany's Roland Matthes became a double gold medalist for his second straight Olympics tonight, and American swimmers won the other finals, Melissa Belote, Cathy Carr and John Hecken getting the victories.

HACKENSACK -- Summer culture may not be a big money-earner, but two New Jersey organizations have decided that their 1972 programs were successful enough to warrant consideration of return engagements.

MONTREAL -- On a ferry boat winding its way along the rugged British Columbia coast one afternoon 10 days ago, a top adviser to the provincial government mused for a moment about the forthcoming provincial election and what might happen if David Barrett, a former social worker, happened to become Premier of British Columbia in an upset victory.

EL PASO -- La Raza Unida, a burgeoning political party of Mexican-Americans, was started in 1969 on the dusty back streets of the Southwest Texas town of Crystal City, the "spinach capital" of the world.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Ricardo Carreras, a New York bantamweight, advanced to the quarterfinals of the Olympic boxing tournament today by gaining a 3-2 split decision over Buian Ganbat of Mongolia.

The emergence of professional tennis as a glamour sport has been paralleled by the amateur game across the country. In the metropolitan area, tennis is now a year- round sport. Former summer-only courts are sprouting domelike "bubbles" for winter play and new clubs are popping up everywhere. The following is a brief rundown on some of the playing facilities, instruction, books and equipment currently available.
ARE we really supposed to believe that a large portion of the art world is attacking good art so that they can replace it with bad art? This isn't the first time this sort of whining has been heard.

PRINCETON, N. J. -- Advocates of a moratorium to stop killing whales -- which was urged by the United Nations' Conference on the Environment at Stockholm -- were disappointed by results of the recent International Whaling Commission meeting at London.
QANTARA, Israeli-Occupied Sinai, Aug. 29 -- Boats were sailing across the Suez Canal and Egyptian seamen were casting for fish from the Israeliheld eastern bank.

Linguist-educator J. L. Dillard of the University of Puerto Rico has produced a highly readable, usable and extremely timely discussion of the language system and habits of African Americans in previous and current times. Readable in that he doesn't go off on the reader about phonemes and dental fricatives and all them other things linguists be running off at the mouth about doin their professional number.

Regarding "To scoop or not to scoop" by Gini Kopecky (Aug. 20): as the owner of a 3 1/2-year-old cocker spaniel (who was easily trained to pull into the street when he had to defecate) I have no objection to scooping up his droppings if the city would enforce some of the related laws -- e.g.:

REYKJAVIK -- Robert James Fischer, the new chess champion of the world, is not going to be any less ornery than he was as Bobby Fischer, the challenger. He has done it all by himself, and from now on it is going to be a brand new chess game.
DETROIT, Sept. 2 -- The United Automobile Workers has asked the Chrysler Corporation to begin talks on how to "humanize" jobs on the assembly line.
HALF of being an artist today lies in promotional skill, yet to accept this condition is to be half an artist.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- The seizure of 70 pounds of heroin and cocaine with an estimated street value of $12.6-million and the arrests of 14 persons in Caracas, Venezuela, and Miami have broken up an international drug ring, the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs said today.

Mayor Lindsay's administration plans to name a "blue ribbon panel" to study the often criticized antipoverty program here, in part responding to complaints that the Jewish and Italian poor have been largely overlooked.

The Aug. 11 editorial "Racism in Uganda" not unexpectedly exonerates the British Government and facilely condemns Uganda for what is termed "ugly racism." The British are acting "with honor and courage" and are risking serious political, economic and social disorder for their "humanitarian" act in taking responsibility for an estimated 50,000 Asians ordered out of Uganda.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (AP) -- -- The British Trawlers Federation said that an Icelandic gunboat tried to wreck a British trawler's fishing gear today. It was the first reported move by Iceland against about 100 British, West German and Belgian trawlers defying Iceland's new 50-mile territorial-waters limit.

WEST HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 31 -- "Born, brought up in this town. Never did notice that stadium much till this summer," said the cab driver. "I stay away from all that traffic on game nights. They draw some damn fine little crowds."

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 2 (UPI) -- Tom Henderson, Tom McMillen and James Brewer led a United States surge midway through the second half that brought a 72-56 victory over Spain tonight and clinched a berth in the semi-finals of the Olympic basketball tournament.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 2 (AP) -- A dispute over how many striking Northwest Airlines pilots would be recalled immediately after their strike ends has broken up contract talks between the nation's seventh largest air carrier and its 1,600 pilots.

WASHINGTON -- Senator George McGovern delivered a speech on tax and welfare reform to a Wall Street audience last week. He wore a dark suit, a white shirt, a navy blue tie and his hair was a little shorter than usual.

President Nixon's pledge to eliminate the draft, if reelected, may go down in history -- along with his vow to and the Vietnam war -- as the twentieth century's most ingenious contribution to the art of electioneering: the "two-campaign promise." Mr. Nixon ran successfully on that platform in 1968. Now, with the target date for a draft-free army set for July 1973, he is campaigning on the same promise again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 -- With the arrival of Labor Day, summer is over for most of us and so is our fleeting encounter with physical exercise. Once home from the beach, we will have done for another year with physical effort except running for the bus.

I am distressed by the fact that U.S. Steel insists that there is no solution to the coke manufacturing problem. ["U.S. Steel Forced Into Vast Antipollution Program," Aug. 27.] The fact is that technology is commercially available and has been for the past 12 months.

An article I wrote for the Jan. 9 issue of the Book Review ("Not Science Fiction but 'If' Fiction"), demonstrating the difficulty of any satisfactory definition of the genre, drew some interesting responses. The most pleasurable was an assignment, by the Encyclopedia Americana, to define "science fiction" for the new edition.
TRENTON -- The volatile rent-leveling controversy in New Jersey began quietly enough last year in Lake-wood, where the first rent-control ordinance was adopted in the state.

WESTWOOD -- Years before Lambert Hitchcock began mass-producing his famous caned and rush-bottom chairs in Connecticut, a branch of the Bogert family was busy turning out similar designs in Bergenfield. This was in the early 1800's.

Contract talks between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers continued yesterday, with the president of the board reporting that some progress was being made in efforts to head off a teachers' strike threatened for the opening of the fall term on Sept. 11.

The terse message from the Jets' locker room after their 9-3 victory over the Atlanta Falcons in Georgia Tech's Grant Field Saturday said simply that Joe Namath had suffered a slight bruise of his right wrist in the first period.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 -- While Thomas H. Mercer explained the decision not to continue funding the fishermen's cooperative out there across the Pacific, patterns of sun and cloud flashed across the windows, products of afternoon fog scudding across Nob Hill from the Golden Gate.

T. Jordan Kunik's astonishing Op-Ed article Aug. 26 on the "depressing" Grand Central Terminal will, I hope, inspire rebuttal of the rather chilling thrust of his argument. "What spirit," asks Mr. Kunik. "Who is responsive to that spirit?"

ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 3 -- Roger McCluskey today won the California 500, a Southern California happening that was marred by freakish incidents, interrupted two hours by rain, enlivened by rhubarbs and started by the President's daughter, Mrs. Tricia Nixon Cox.

Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat-Liberal of Manhattan, announced yesterday that he had called upon the Nixon Administration to admit 5,000 expelled Asians from Uganda without subjecting them to admission quotas.
EL PASO, Sept. 3 -- A Texas revolutionary who led an uprising of Mexican-Americans six years ago said today that a fledgling brown power political movement was already showing its worth.
The Polaroid Corporation has announced that its new pocket-sized instant color camera will not be ready for national introduction by Christmas, the target previously set.
MANILA, Sept. 3 -- The United States is acting to combat the increasing activity of international heroin traffickers in the Philippines.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 2 -- Did the Dallas Cowboys let Craig Morton down, or did he let them down here last night as the Kansas City Chiefs snapped the Super Bowl champions' winning streak at 15 by winning easily, 20-10? The Chiefs had poise and power, playing before a crowd of 79,592 in the new Arrowhead Stadium two weeks before the opening of the National Football League season.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 3 -- The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra will make its first tour of the Far East in April, with performances scheduled for Japan and Korea. A highlight of the tour will be three concerts -- April 10, 11, 12 -- at the Osaka Music Festival in Japan.

The Arab villages of Berem and Ikrit are not easy to find on a modern map of Palestine and they are even harder to locate on the ground, for in common with many other old Arab settlements they have been bulldozed away by the construction of modern Israel. These two villages now epitomize a crisis of conscience among Israelis on an issue where comfortable consensus has long reigned.

Lewis Hine wrote in 1911: "I am sometimes inclined to think that we must mutilate these infants in industry before the shame of it can be driven home. The horror of placing an industrial mortgage upon the back of a perfectly good child does not seem to be obvious."

RICHMOND, Sept. 3 (AP) -- An elderly woman and a teenage girl were killed early today when a southbound Greyhound bus plunged 35 feet off a highway overpass and landed upside down near a hotel parking lot, the authorities said. The 44 other persons aboard the bus were reported injured.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 3 -- President Nixon assailed today those who, he said, espoused policies that would threaten fundamental American values -- most particularly what he called the "work ethic" -- and thereby weaken the "American character."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 4 -- United States Air Force jets wrecked one of North Vietnam's biggest air bases 10 miles north of Hanoi and shot down a Soviet-built MIG interceptor in a dogfight near the base, the Air Force announced yesterday.
Some are serious and some are frivolous but all the exhibits have the same goal -- "Making New York Understandable."
Danger signals are up this Labor Day for the pension plans in which millions of American workers pin a major part of their hope for old-age security.

HILTON HEAD, S. C., Sept. 3 -- Senator George McGovern came here tonight to assure Southern Governor that he did not take the region lightly in his campaign to oust President Nixon from the White House.

The "war room" back in Cincinnati has been disbanded. The "battle" is about to begin. How successful the planning has been will come out over the next 11 days, the duration of the 1972 International Machine Tool Show in Chicago, which opens tomorrow.

" Carmen," a perennial bread-and-butter staple of the operatic repertory, will be very much with us during the fall season. A good deal of curiosity has already been generated by the forthcoming Metropolitan production conceived by the late Goeran Gentele, while the City Opera has planned eight performances of its current mounting that was first unveiled just a year ago.

DETROIT, Sept. 3 -- The General Motors Corporation expects car and truck sales in the United States to climb to a record 13.5 million to 14 million next year, up from the 13.2 million expected for 1972, Richard C. Gerstenberg, chairman of G.M., said today.

Most businessmen and economists say that they are unconcerned about the Nixon Administration's controls on profit margins, even though the Price Commission has taken action against 42 companies for violations of such controls dozens more price-rollback orders are pending and hundreds more could be issued by the end of the year.
TORONTO, Sept. 3 -- Canada awoke from its bad dream today. But when the people saw the newspapers they realized that last night really happened.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- A coalition of women's rights organizations today urged George Meany, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. president, to use his influence to help expand and upgrade the role of women in leadership of the American labor movement.

Cesar Chavez's nationwide consumer boycott of lettuce appears to have rallied little effective support in the three months since it started, but there is evidence that it may now be gaining some momentum.

Ralph Houk, as field manager, and Lee MacPhail, as executive vice president and general manager, were rehired by the New York Yankees yesterday, ending speculation about possible changes. The speculation had pretty much died of its own weight since the Yankees got involved in the pennant race, even though no formal action was taken until, this weekend.

Not too long ago, my infant daughter discovered her hand. With great concentration she studied it, sometimes holding it so close to her nose that her eyes crossed. She also took it and aimed it in the general direction of her mouth. Often she bumped her nose, her cheek, but as the days went on, she developed confidence.

The building on East 79th Street could be any of the high rise, high-rent apartment houses between Third and Lexington Avenues except that on the sidewalk in front of No. 211 frail-looking old men and women lean against a low wall or sit in wheel chairs.

TOKYO, Sept. 3 -- Several seemingly trivial incidents in which Japanese leftists stopped the movement of American military tanks here have caused American authorities to become noticeably impatient with the continued harassment and the apparent reluctance of the Japanese Government to provide the protection that would allow American forces to move equipment unimpeded.
An off-duty patrolman suffered a fractured skull when struck with a hatchet early yesterday in a fight with two teenagers after they forced his car to stop, authorities reported.

Lucian K. Truscott 4th's comments on the West Point Honor Code (Op-Ed Aug. 19) left me with a sense of frustration and anguish. The standard has surely fallen if an attack on a code of conduct as venerable as this can go unchallenged and if remarks as irrelevant and as unsubstantial as his can serve as adequate rebuttal to countless lives of honor and integrity

A stepped - up campaign against cigarette bootleggers, who are costing New York State $50-million a year in uncollected excise taxes and additional millions in sales taxes, is planned by the State Division of Taxation.
PARIS, Sept. 3 -- The Soviet Ambassador to France has rejected charges by a top French Socialist leader of Soviet "discrimination" against Jews and "intervention" in Czechoslovakia.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 3 -- A British soldier was shot dead and another seriously injured when two army patrols mistook each other for terrorists and opened fire early today.

Board of Education negotiators sought yesterday to put together a total contract package acceptable to the United Federation of Teachers, which has threatened to strike next Monday, the opening day of the new school year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 -- China has negotiated or renewed aid and trade agreements with 24 African countries in the last two years, closely following the resumption of active diplomacy after the isolation of the Cultural Revolution in the late nineteen-sixties.

Seymour Escava, one of the owners of the Nadeen clothing store at Third Avenue and 152d Street in the Bronx, was outraged the other day to see a street peddler nonchalantly spreading out his clothing wares on the sidewalk directly in front of his store.

John Akii-Bua, the newly crowned Olympic 400 meter hurdles champion and world record-breaker, did his training in the Mountains of the Moon in Uganda running uphill wearing a vest containing 25 pounds in lead weights.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 3 -- A message received yesterday by President Hafez al-Assad of Syria from President Anwar el-Sedat of Egypt has heightened speculation in diplomatic quarters here about a mediation effort by General Assad designed to check the deterioration in Egyptian-Soviet relations.

In the early eighteen hundreds, New York's High Constable, Jacob Hays, evolved an assembly-line technique for nabbing street brawlers. As one police chronicle tells it, "He usually knocked off their hats with his staff, and while they were in the act of stooping to pick them up, he would shove them forward and throw them down, their prostrate bodies generally serving as a barrier to keep the others back. . ."

An aging red-brick building on Brooklyn's Bay Ridge waterfront is the headquarters of a relatively new Consolidated Edison generating system that is credited more than anything else this summer with keeping the city from plunging into another power blackout.

Channel 13's daily recreating of the Fischer-Spassky chess match proved so popular that the public television station is negotiating to present a weekly chess series starring Shelby Lyman, the master who has become famous as a TV performer as well as a chess player.

New York's Knickerbocker tournament concludes today, at the New York Hilton. The knockout teams finished yesterday in a round-robin final between three New York teams captained by B. Jay Becker, Peter Weichsel and Jerome Weissman.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 3 -- Bobi Herfield's King William Henry I became the ruler of the regular working hunter division at the Fairfield Bridal Path Association Horse Show today.

As regularly as the seasons change, some expert writes a lament about the scarcity of good operatic tenors. You can't very easily go wrong in that, either; such voices are always in short supply. Some baritones and basses even half-jokingly insist that the tenor throat is an unnatural phenomenon. But it is best to stay out of that debate.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 3 (Agence France-Presse) -- Two of the three American pilots who are to be released from North Vietnamese prisons have purportedly issued antiwar statements and an appeal to the American people and Congress to "take firm, positive action" to end the fighting.

A man in upstate New York, concerned about American planes bombing the dikes in North Vietnam, wrote a letter recently to President Nixon. He got an answer from the Acting Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, John Richardson Jr. As an example of contemporary official logic it deserves a wider audience.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 3 -- Dr. Nahum Goldmann, the controversial president of the World Jewish Congress, created a stir this weekend with a suggestion that Israel should raise money to pay the high levies demanded by the Soviet Government from educated Jews wishing to come to Israel.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 3 (UPI) -- Cambodia's first National Assembly election in six years opened today with teams of Government workers moving from house to house asking citizens to vote. Military planes dropped thousands of leaflets on the capital urging that citizens go to the polls.

Just when it looked as if Rod Laver was going to join Ken Rosewall as an early round upset victim in the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens, the Rocket roared back yesterday to defeat Jaime Fillol of Chile, 6-2, 4-6, 6-7, 6-1, 7-6.
MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 3 -- Mark Spitz won his sixth gold medal of the current Olympics tonight, the first athlete to achieve such success in the history of the modern Games.

The Yankees' eight-year march along the road back was slowed yesterday when they lost a 5-0 decision to the Chicago White Sox and Wilbur Wood, the left-handed plumber and lobster - pot tender from Maine.

SINGAPORE, Monday, Sept. 4 -- Lee Kuan Yew's ruling Peoples Action party held victory celebrations yesterday after its clean sweep in Saturday's general election.

BOGOTA, Colombia -- There are two kinds of governments in South America: those chosen by voters and those imposed by the military. Today, the largest countries in both camps -- Colombia and Brazil -- are also showing the most impressive economic gains.

How did people ever get into the habit of selecting that artificial calendar day called New Year's to make resolutions for improving the quality of their lives? Everyone knows that this season, the end of the vacations, the return to life's routine, brings the best mood for making resolutions.

Baltimore, Boston, New York and Detroit were locked in the American League Eastern Division race, separated by a half-game on Labor Day. No major league race involving so many teams has been so close so late in the season.

The fact that the emotion-filled debate over abortion in New York State is far from over makes particularly valuable the statistical analysis of the 1971 experience just released by the state's Department of Health. Fifteen participants in a "prisoners' march for peace" that began in Danbury, Conn., arrived here yesterday and ended an eight-day fast with juice and soup.

Stressing the need for coordinating all of New York State's post-secondary-school educational resources, the Board of Regents released a development plan yesterday that for the first time spells out the roles of private colleges and universities and trade, business and other proprietary schools.

LONDON, Sept. 7 (Reuters) -- Mr. Barber said today that he and Mr. Schmidt "were in complete agreement on the need to press on with the reform of the international monetary system." Mr. Barber spoke after a meeting with Mr. Schmidt here today.

A great deal has been made of the "orchestration" of the Republican National Convention, in contrast to the melee that was the Democratic convention. Most commentaries view negatively the Republican "orderliness," in contrast to the "excitement" generated by the Democrats' confusion.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 7 -- The Munich police, strongly defending their unsuccessful attempt to rescue nine Israeli hostages from eight Arab terrorists Tuesday night, reported today that five sharpshooters had been assigned to the task.

TRENTON, Sept. 7 -- The head of the New Jersey Highway Authority announced today that he had finally cleaned up what he described as the "horrors" in the Garden State Parkway's restaurants and service stations after a 19 month "upgrading" campaign.
The creators of the best graphics in 1971 were honored last night by the Art Directors Club at a dinner in the Plaza Hotel.

BONN, Sept. 7 -- West Germany asked today its partner countries in the European Economic Community to recall funds they had invested in the so-called international Eurodollar market. The appeal is contained in a list of anti-inflationary measures that the Bonn Government proposed to its Common Market partners in advance of next week's meeting in Rome of the community's foreign and finance ministers.

The Penn Central Transportation Company, the bankrupt railroad subsidiary of the Penn Central Company, incurred a net loss of $29,788,053 in July exceeding the $27,953,761 loss for July, 1971, according to yesterday's report of the trustees.

Bridge administrators are of two main species: the fulltime professional, rare in the United States and almost unknown elsewhere, and the spare-time amateur, on whose unselfish enthusiasm the organization of the tournament world largely depends.

ST. CROIX, V. I., Sept. 7 -The largest manhunt in the history of the Virgin Islands today combed the brush-covered hills surrounding the Fountain Valley Golf Club where gunmen shot eight persons to death yesterday on a terrace overlooking the fairways.
Six weeks after he was shot six times by a disgruntled student, Columbia College's dean of students, Henry S. Coleman, was back at his desk yesterday as classes resumed at Columbia University.

Antonio Gades is the reigning king of Spanish dance. On Wednesday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater he came with his company and demonstrated why. This was his first visit to New York since his widely acclaimed performances at the Spanish Pavilion during the 1964 World's Fair.

HOUSTON, Sept. 7 -- Senator George McGovern, campaigning for Texas's 26 electoral votes, visited the Manned Spacecraft Center here today and said that he thought "the future American space effort should focus on unmanned exploration."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 8 -- North Vietnamese troops have reportedly taken control of most of the key district town of Tienphuoc in Quangtin Province about 35 miles south of Danang.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -Congressional sources reported today that the Joint Chiefs of Staff had detected at least one of Gen. John D. Lavelle's unauthorized bombing missions against North Vietnam in 1971, well before the series of raids ended.

A governing committee of 28 men was created at the New York Stock Exchange on May 1, 1869. Its purpose was to rule on policy matters for the Big Board, and for 103 years the group and its successors have met in secrecy.
WASHINGTON -- Traveling with Homer's hero could hardly have been more perilous than following Senator McGovern's odyssey toward an economic and fiscal policy for the American people.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 7 -- Two civilians reportedly were shot dead and two others wounded as violence erupted in the Protestant Shankill Road area of Belfast for the third successive night.

HARTFORD, Sept. 7 (AP) -A Federal Court judge today refused a request by Ralph Nader to open the case against the completed merger of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- The Emergency Loan Act passed last year by Congress to rescue the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has succeeded in preventing a financial collapse of the company and enabled it to begin delivering its first Tristar jetliners, the Government said today.
Harlem Hospital physicians, nurses, orderlies, citizen-advisers walked together in an extraordinary picket line yesterday to protest what they called "appalling medical care" there.

The National Endowment for the Humanities, which last year gave a matching grant of $500,000 to the New York Public Library for its deficit-plagued research libraries, offered $750,000 yesterday for the coming year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A bill that would permit the National and American Basketball Associations to merge -- but only at the expense of giving up the reserve clause -- was passed today by a Senate subcommittee, and may be enacted into law before this session of Congress ends.
An 11-year-old girl who had been left home alone by her working parents was found dead in her apartment on Riverside Drive at 152d Street yesterday, the apparent victim of a strangler.

Fervent young Palestinians, convinced that the Arab commando movement must go completely underground, have swelled the year-old Black September organization's ranks to about 300 men, well-placed Arab informants reported in Beirut yesterday.

BABYLON, L. I., Sept. 7 (UPI) -- An angry crowd of about 250 youths surrounded and assaulted a Suffolk County patrolman as he attempted to arrest two youths on drug charges at a park here last night, the police said.

Theodore S. Weiss, chairman of the City Council's Committee on Environmental Protection, predicted yesterday that the Council would pass "the most comprehensive and advanced noise-control legislation in the country" next Tuesday.

PARIS, Sept. 7 -- William J. Porter, the chief United States representative at the Paris peace talks, warned Hanoi once more today against hoping to achieve political ends in Saigon by military means. The Communist side once again took the position that continued American bombing of North Vietnam was proof of American unwillingness to end the war.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- A few days after James Riddle Hoffa was released from a Federal penitentiary last Dec. 23, he was on the phone ordering suits and shoes with the concentration and energy that he once used in negotiating contracts.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

GENEVA, Sept. 7 -- The 25-nation disarmament conference today ended its sessions for this year with no progress to report on its search for agreements to scrap chemical weapons and to ban all testing of nuclear armaments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) -- Cardinal Cooke, the Archbishop of New York, testified today that Roman Catholic schools had never fostered racial or religious segregation and urged approval of a bill to provide tax credits for private school tuition.

A three-judge Federal Court yesterday extended central voter registration in New York State to Sept. 23 and ruled unconstitutional a provision of the State Election Law that terminated such registration earlier.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept 7 (Reuters) -- The Netherlands cut the bank rate to 3 per cent from 4 per cent, the Dutch central bank said today. The cut takes effect tomorrow.

Before the new television season gets started officially on Monday, the American Broadcasting Company on Sunday evening will be offering a glossy smattering of TV nostalgia in the form of "Zenith Presents a Salute to Television's 25th Anniversary." The 90-minute special will begin on Channel 7 at 9:30 P.M.
Mark Spitz's seven Olympic gold medals will be worth $5-million to him. Sherm Chavoor, Spitz's coach, said on the West Coast yesterday.

Two unions with more muscle than good sense are the chief obstacles to final settlement of the nine-week strike of construction workers in this city. Jack Kramer was named yesterday executive director of a new organization of tennis pros.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday the appointment of Seymour Bernstein as director of police personnel.
Steve Carlton, who has known the tension and the glory of World Series competition, has had to provide his own star status this season with the futile Philadelphia Phillies.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 31 -- Shocked and startled, Dutchmen are beginning to figure out the unhappy meaning of street fights that raged for a week recently between Dutch and Turkish workers here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The current issue of Commentary contains a debate between two leading intellectuals, Nathan Glazer and Milton Himmelfarb, on "McGovern, Nixon, and the Jews." The issue is whether and to what extent Jews should depart in November from their traditional allegiance to the Democratic party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 -- The National Transportation Safety Board is pressing other Federal agencies to identify and reduce hazards in what it calls the "explosively growing" use of recreational vehicles.
Investors seemed reluctant to make commitments yesterday because of developments in the Middle East as the stock market registered its third consecutive decline in dull trading.
