CHARLOTTE, N. C., Sept. 10 -- Archbishop Iakovos, Primate of the Greek Orthodox Church of North and South America, said today that he was "not in agreement" with a suggestion by a prominent Charlotte priest that the center of Eastern Orthodoxy be moved from Istanbul, Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Abram L. Chayes, a Harvard professor and chairman of Senator George McGovern's foreign policy advisory panel, has denied controversial views attributed to him in the Sept. 11 issue of Newsweek.

Last week's judicial decision setting aside the primary-election victory of Representative John J. Rooney over Allard K. Lowenstein pointed up the fact that the Board of Elections, which is charged with insuring the integrity of elections, is actually a creature of the politicians involved in those elections.
The Times' otherwise excellent obituary of C. Suydam Cutting (Aug. 25) opened with the statement that he was "the first white Christian to enter the forbidden city of Lhasa" (in 1935).

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 (AP) -Boris Spassky, the man who let the world chess championship slip from Soviet hands for the first time in 24 years, returned home to a loser's welcome tonight. The only concession authorities made to him was that he did not have to open his bags for customs inspection.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- President Nixon and his challenger, Senator George McGovern, are heading for a sharp ideological confrontation over economic issues, according to campaign strategists for both candidates.
PERUGIA, Italy, Sept. 10 -- This ancient hill capital of Umbria, host to a fluctuating body of more than 2,000 Arab students, has suddenly become tense with suspicions, rumors and fears.

The flip of a coin determined the winner of a soccer exhibition at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday afternoon between Barcelona of Ecuador and Nacional of Colombia, with Nacional declared the winner.
The president and vice president of a Manhattan recording company and a rock drummer were arrested yesterday and charged with having kidnapped, assaulted and sexually abused three teen-aged girls.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10 -- The Cambodian nation is in deep trouble and once again its non-Cambodian residents are living in dread lest they be blamed for everything and become targets of a new pogrom.
LANSING, Mich., Sept. 10 -- Michigan voters will decide in the November election whether to legalize abortion.

MOSCOW, Sept. 10 -- The arrival of two United States business delegations in Moscow today signaled a new round of intensive trade talks here this week, coincident with discussions between Soviet leaders and Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's national security adviser.

TUXEDO, N. Y., Sept. 10 -A tiny four-pounder proved to be the biggest dog of 2,498 at the Westchester Kennel Club's 55th fixture tonight in Sterling Forest, N. Y. For Ch. Mi-Lo's Mischief Gold Pat, a Pomeranian owned by Lady Florence Conyers of Bermuda was chosen best in show by James A. Farrell Jr., making Westchester history.

People in the credit markets can't make up their minds about how tight they think the Federal Reserve wants the money market to be. It's no wonder. Last Thursday, the Federal Re serve reported that the money supply expanded at an annual rate of almost 11 per cent during July and August while bank reserves that support non-government deposits increased at a 12.5 per cent rate.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 10 -- Henry Kissinger spent today talking to Chancellor Willy Brandt and other West German political leaders about the future of Europe and its relations with the United States.

FORT ORD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- The Army has ordered a crackdown on "Chapter 10" discharges, a process by which misfits, malcontents, goldbricks, drug addicts, those who have been AWOL and others who may merely loathe the military system can escape to civilian life without facing court-martial.
Herbert S. Denenberg, Pennsylvania's increasingly influential Insurance Commissioner, shook up the health insurance business earlier this year after he spotted an ad he didn't like.
An Associated Press dispatch from Saigon Sept. 3 included this passage:
Ilie Nastase of Rumania won the United States Open tennis championship yesterday at Forest Hills, a top prize of $25,000 and the right to be called the world's best player on grass.

Freed from the threat of a teachers' strike, the city school system will start the new academic year this morning with a sigh of relief, a record enrollment, a number of new programs and a determination to do something about an old problem -- violence, in the schools.

WILTON, Conn. -- One day recently a man and a woman sat in a parked car in nearby New Canaan and went over some contracts, planned some itineraries and did other paper work. They were waiting while their youngest child, 11-year-old Matthew, took a cello lesson.

A leaping-one-handed catch in front of the left-field fence by Cleon Jones on Luis Melendez's long drive with the bases loaded yesterday saved a 3-2 victory for the New York Mets over the St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium.

City Controller Abraham D. Beame asserted yesterday that a "dual set of records" had been kept by the former management of the Pioneer Bus Corporation, and those submitted to the city had failed to show $108,033 in revenues between April 1, 1969, and last Jan. 13.
PULVERSHEIM, France, Sept. 8 -- A group of some 30 potash miners here sounded the one discordant note in Premier Pierre Messmer's pre-electoral tour of Alsace.

DUBLIN, Sept. 8 -- Despite the fitful efforts of the Irish Government to change their colorful lifestyle and settle them down, the "traveling people" of Ireland persist in their nomadic existence and their numbers seem to be swelling rather than declining.

CAIRO, Sept. 10 -- The Egyptian Government, though angered by the Israeli air raids on Palestinian camps in Lebanon and Syria, is determined to avoid involvement in military action against Israel unless the Israelis attack Egyptian territory, political sources here said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- Representative Ogden R. Reid warned today that the situation in Northern Ireland threatened to become a "British Vietnam" and urged the United States to offer its "good offices in some area."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- A scientific panel said today that lung cancer was twice as common among those who breathed the polluted air of cities as it was among country dwellers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 11 -- The United States Embassy here has found attacks on Senator George McGovern on the South Vietnamese national television and radio so offensive that it has protested to the Saigon Government, according to an embassy spokesman.

ESPANOLA, N. M., Sept. 10 -- Senator George McGovern refused today to confirm or to deny published reports that the Democratic party had a highly placed informant at the Committee for the Re-election of the President or the Republican National Committee.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Most pension plans that collapse do so when one company is taken over by another, two Senators sponsoring corrective legislation said Sunday.
Bobby Fischer is planning to change his life-style substantially now that he is the world chess champion, Life magazine says in its issue out today.
Rabbis called on the nations of the world yesterday to develop security measures to prevent incidents like the slaying of Israeli athletes at Munich.
A Long Island youth was] wounded yesterday morning after an argument with a corn-[ panion in front of all East Sidell bar was broken .up by two men who then robbed the couple, the police reported.
FAIRFIELD, Calif., Sept. 10 -- The trial of Juan Corona, a farm labor contractor accused of killing 25 men, is scheduled to begin here tomorrow after being delayed for more than 10 months.
About three-fourths of a first group of drug addicts to whom the city sent letters asking about their treatment programs failed to respond, and the city is moving to take them from the welfare rolls.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 -- Mel Stottlemyre's three-hit shutout and Horace Clarke's wide-ranging offense brought the New York Yankees a 5-0 victory over the Detroit Tigers today, and solidified their position in the American League's Eastern Division pennant race.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 10 -- Six Argentine lawyers have] charged here that naval guards[ opened fire "suddenly and[ P' -'gg 'l rillas' who had been paraded/ at 3:30 A.M. on Aug. 22 at a Patagonian naval base. When the prisoners attempted
When Frank Shorter dropped out of medical school in 1970, he explained that he just wanted to "go to work" and see how good a runner he could really be.

The Soviet Government's attempt to capitalize on Jewish emigrants is a dehumanizing and unconscionable act. Moral-humanitarian consideration aside, it is essential to examine objectively the Soviet claim that persons emigrating from the U.S.S.R. should repay the state for the costs of their education.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 -- President Suleiman Franjieh of Lebanon has begun a diplomatic effort to get major powers that are interested in the Middle East to tackle the Palestinian refugee problem, which underlies much of the violence in this region.

Stop the season, I want to get out! Well no, not really, but the little show "Crazy Now" that somewhat apologetically opened at the Eden Theater last night hardly got the 1972-73 New York theater off to a running start.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) -- President Nixon today designated parts of northwest Wisconsin a national disaster area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Legislation about to emerge from the House Agriculture Committee could result in a costly Federal penalty for cities and states that try to enact meat packaging and labeling rules stronger than those of the Federal Government.

The State Correction Commissioner, Russell G. Oswald, reported yesterday that changes in the state prison system in the year since the Attica rebellion "constitute a creditable record of accelerated penal reform."
GUATEMALA CITY, Sept. 10 -- The fraying Central American Common Market is in serious danger of collapse. The free trade group, which originally was composed of five members, now has only three.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board has decided that 33 groups named on the Attorney General's list of subversive organizations no longer exist.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, the state campaign manager for the Democratic Presidential nominee, George McGovern, yesterday conceded that dissension in the McGovern camp "sets us back."

A stepped-up program in bilingual education heads the list of new offerings and improved services that the New York City public school system plans to offer the 1,161,500 pupils who begin classes today.

When the word got out in early July that the Buckingham Corporation was toying with the idea of moving its Cutty Sark Scotch out of Clyne Maxon, Inc., after 11 years, some people didn't take it seriously.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 10 (Agence France-Presse) -- A combination of high - spirited athletes and jumpy guards led to a false report of shots fired in the Olympic Village tonight. The police, with the results of last week's guerrilla raid fresh in their minds, reported that an unidentified man had fired five shots but that there were no victims.

ATTICA, N. Y., Sept. 10 -- "I don't want to be a puppet just to prevent a riot," said Edwin Temple, one of 28 prisoners elected by fellow inmates to speak for them to administrators of the state prison here.
The "bilingualism" discussion in your letters columns Sept. 2 offers a much needed service for your reading public.

CALIFON, N. J. -- The liberation of the young from the "oppression" of their elders makes no sense. A question can initially be raised whether it is compatible with the nature of man and his development. Human creatures have a long childhood and adolescence when the young need their elders to survive and to acquire the knowledge needed to maintain the continuity of life.
WASHINGTON -- A cartoon cocktail party for campaign contributions? Well, there's more than one way to raise money, so why not sell original art from the New Yorker or Playboy?

A strike authorized by 558 Catholic lay teachers against 12 Roman Catholic high schools in Brooklyn and Queens was averted last night when the teachers voted to accept a contract containing no salary increases and virtually no new benefits.

MONZA, Italy, Sept. 10 (UPI) -- Emerson Fittipaldi coasted his gold and black Lotus to victory in the Italian Grand Prix today and became the first Brazilian to win the world drivers' championship as well when Jackie Ickx of Belgium dropped out in the 46th lap.

A standing-room crowd of 44,571 in Houston's Astrodome got its chance to cheer when Ward Walsh scored with 52 seconds left to give the Oilers the tie. Walsh, a running back, went round left end from 10 yards out for the score.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 9 -A tall, skinny woman eating a German sausage on a stick stood eying a big iron washpot that was giving off rich smells of cooking beef.

The series of articles by your staff writers Linda Charleton and Iver Peterson did a public service by spotlighting one of the more fraudulent areas of malpractice in the mental health field, the granting of diploma-mill degrees which are used by unscrupulous individuals who set themselves up as self-styled mental health practitioners.

BASEL, Sept. 10 -- Governors of leading Western central banks meeting here today to discuss basic reform of the International Monetary System and further development of economic and monetary union within the European Economic Community, appeared to give some support to a review of the community's narrower-band currency system.

It is so unusual to see The Times write anything at all about Westchester that I do not want to discourage you with unkind words about the "Westchester's Test" editorial [Aug. 31] which blessed the state's Urban Development Corporation and attacked its critics.
PARIS, Sept. 11 -- After a long spell of two-sided summitry, the Western diplomatic calendar is crowded again with conferences. But the emphasis has changed.
The city's Department of Health is changing its tuberculosis screening procedures, substituting the skin test for the routine use of the chest X-ray.

Amid a chorus of "no comment'' for the record, senior partners and other spokesmen for major law firms here have privately expressed surprise and resentment over the decision of the Price Commission last week to impose a ceiling on the fee increases of big law firms.

Mrs. Alfred A. Knopf wanted to invite 80 people to a birthday dinner for her husband tonight -- one for each of his years. But the Cosmopolitan Club cannot handle quite that many, so he will be victim of a slightly short count.

The entry representing Sigmund Sommer co-operated perfectly in the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday. Night Staker, with Eddie Belmonte riding, won the seven-furlong sprint, after Aqua Belle, with Bobby Woodhouse up, carried out the pace-setting assignment in the early stages.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, Lionel Hampton and George Romney will be among a group of 50 Presidential "surrogates" who will spend Saturday as volunteer canvassers, pushing doorbells in major cities to mark the start of the Republican canvassing effort.
The Sarah Lawrence Chorus stopped off at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night on the way home from its seventh European tour and gave a concert that at its frequent best did the collegians honor.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Noel H. Klores, New York City's chief Washington lobbyist for the last two and a half years, is resigning to enter private law practice here.

If history is any guide, the recent bombings of North Vietnamese dikes must be considered as harbingers of large-scale dike destruction in the future. Previous escalations of the war, during both the Johnson and Nixon Administrations, were signaled by small-scale attacks of the kind being planned.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 11 -- Vice President Agnew transformed a "nonpolitical" appearance before blue-collar workers today into an enthusiastically partisan speech that may have set the tone for his national campaign this year.
Five independently made feature films will have their premieres during the Whitney Museum's third annual New American Filmmakers Series, which starts on Sept. 21.
The City Opera's "Rigoletto" returned to the State Theater Sunday night, the leading singers in fine voice, the production just a bit rusty after its summer layover.
Prices of American Stock Exchange shares slumped yesterday, pushing the index down 0.14 to 26.32. The drop continued a decline that began last week.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The General Motors Corporation announced today that it was recalling 37,000 Cadillacs produced at the end of the 1972 model year to find 5,000 defective left rear axle shafts.

MUNICH, West Germany -- The notion of an exhibition devoted exclusively to Bavarian art might seem somewhat specialized, perhaps provincial and even dull. This is by no means the case of the "Bavarian Art and Culture" exhibition that the Munich State Museum mounted as a special treat for visitors to the Olympic Games as well as for the forthcoming October festival.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday described as "utter nonsense" the charge that provisional appointments to city jobs were political payoffs, saying that provisionals "are essential in order to run the city better."

Some would not only walk a mile to see Carmen de Lavallade dance but also regularly endure the hurly burly at the New York Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater to enjoy her artistry. The programs presented each year under the wing of the New York Shakespeare Festival happily find a place for her in her ever rarer New York appearances.

ROME, Sept. 11 -- Finance ministers of the European Common Market nations took a modest, although important, step today toward establishing a Federal Reserve System for Europe. They agreed to all but minute details of a European Monetary Fund that would help members of the European Economic Community out of temporary financial difficulties.

Secretary of the Treasury George Shultz has attacked Senator McGovern's proposal for phasing out the depletion allowance and other favorable tax treatments which permit businesses and individuals in the oil industry substantially to reduce their Federal income tax bill.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The United States and Japan held the first of a two-day policy level meeting today aimed at clarifying the Treasury's plans in enforcing the American antidumping law.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 11 -- The New York Mets salvaged something from a sinking season tonight when they defeated Steve Carlton, the 23-game winner of the Philadelphia Phillies, 4-2.
Metallic lathers and building contractors in the city reached agreement yesterday on a two-year contract, leaving three other unions still on strike against the construction industry here.
Three thousand gallons of flammable No. 2 diesel oil spilled into Eastchester Creek at the foot of Canal Street in Mt. Vernon early yesterday, the Coast Guard reported.
Repaving of more than a mile of Jamaica Avenue between Woodhaven and Lefferts Boulevards in Richmond Hill, Queens, began yesterday.

A rigid sense of personal pride was the force that carried Gale Sayers out of professional football. The Chicago Bears' running back, who announced his retirement Sunday, gave up $75,000 in salary for this season when he packed in after a dismal effort during a preseason game against St. Louis on Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz challenged George McGovern today to produce a "shred of evidence" that any grain dealers had got inside information enabling them to profit at the expense of United States consumers and farmers in a massive grain sale to Russia.

A musicians' strike that would have darkened New York's legitimate theaters was temporarily averted yesterday when union and management agreed to extend for a week the three-year contract that expired at midnight Sunday and to continue negotiations for a new pact.
MOSCOW, Sept. 11 -- Henry Kissinger began three days of wide-ranging talks with the Soviet leadership today without making any contact here with the North Vietnamese negotiator, Le Duc Tho.
The yield on high-grade electric utility bonds -- the most widely used measure of the corporate bond market -- rose yesterday to 7.58 per cent, its highest level since late June.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 11 -- The Board of Foreign Trade has directed Taiwan importers to turn to American or European sources rather than Japanese for orders of machinery or industrial materials exceeding $20,000.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 11 -- South Vietnam's Communists today issued what they called an "important statement" of their terms for a peace settlement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Democratic party today accused Maurice H. Stans, finance chairman of the Nixon campaign, and three other campaign aides of conspiring "to commit political espionage" against Democratic officials and candidates.
A Bronx man allegedly shot and killed his estranged wife yesterday morning and fled with the couple's five-year-old son.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Government officials were scratching their heads today over the exploits of William L. Taub, the mysterious "New York lawyer" who represented James R. Hoffa in his abortive effort last week to go to Hanoi to negotiate for the release of American prisoners.
One person was killed and three were injured early yesterday morning in shootings at taverns in the Bronx and Manhattan.

A specially built $3-million trestle, opened yesterday for detoured traffic while a decayed section of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway is being rebuilt, is up for sale if the buyer will wait a year or two for delivery.

In the tortured days before the final bloodshed at the State Correctional Facility at Attica a year ago, the rebel inmates made many demands for changes in the conditions of their confinement. It is a measure of the fever for reform in the state prison system that all but four of those demands have been at least partially met in the ensuing 12 months.

The New York Shakespeare Festival's production of "Much Ado About Nothing," one of its three presentations this summer at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, will open at the Winter Garden Nov. 11 for a run of 10 weeks.

ST. CROIX, V. I., Sept. 11 (UPI -- One of the seven suspects charged with murdering eight persons last week at a plush Rockefeller-owned golf course on the island of St. Croix was arraigned today on burglary charges.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- A confidential, internal report by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare says that school districts across the country have been using inaccurate figures and unreliable estimates in accounting for billions of dollars in compensatory education funds.

Arnold Scaasi, the last of the big-time couturiers in New York, isn't terribly worried about his clients dashing off to buy all their clothes from plain pipe racks. They like the special attention, the chance to choose their fabrics, the advice from the designer on what neckline is right for them, what outfit to wear for what occasion.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 11 -- An Israeli diplomat was lured to a cafe here last night and critically wounded by gunfire as he waited for information he had been promised on plans for a terrorist attack on his embassy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The accused leader of the Watergate raid admits his role in the break-in but says he would endure a long prison term rather than implicate others or disclose the reasons behind the affair.

Emerson Fittipaldi, the 25-year-old Brazilian, who became the world drivers' champion on Sunday by winning the Italian Grand Prix at Monza, Italy, disclosed yesterday that he almost failed to make it to the starting line.
In a far-reaching spread of affluence on Manhattan's middle East Side, family income levels rose by $12,000 to $18,000 between 1960 and 1970 in numerous areas.
TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- Municipal corruption in the handling of planning and zoning decisions will be the subject of public hearings conducted by the State Commission of Investigation starting Sept. 19.

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (Agence France-Presse) -- Hundreds of Muscovites and Soviet and foreign tourists today filed past the tomb of the former Premier, Nikita S. Khrushchev, on the first anniversary of his death.

PARIS, Sept. 11 -- Le Duc Tho, chief adviser to Hanoi's delegation at the Paris peace talks, returned to Paris today, creating speculation that he might meet again with Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security.

In the fast-paced women's fashion field, two leading retailers that have made no change in their presidencies for many years announced yesterday new appointees to that post. The companies are the Petrie Stores Corporation, New York, a 240-store concern, and Martin's, Brooklyn, a family-owned chain of quality fashion stores.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Treasury had no comment today on the court decision in San Francisco involving the Bank Secrecy Act because the text of the decision has not yet been received here.
Weeb Ewbank, the coach of the New York Jets, spent several hours yesterday viewing films of his team's 20-20 tie with the Chargers at San Diego on Saturday night and most of what he saw pleased him.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- After months in which it was Senator George McGovern who kept using tax and other economic statistics that no one else could add up the way he did, it is now President Nixon and his staff who are having trouble with their arithmetic.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 11 -- Representative Ogden R. Reid and his opponent, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari, today filed formal charges of unfair campaign practices against one another.

Lewis W. Gillenson has been elected president of the Thomas Y. Crowell Publishing Company, succeeding Robert L. Crowell, who was appointed chairman. Mr. Gillenson was named last November as president of Funk Wagnalls Publishing Company, also a subsidiary of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and will now serve as chief executive officer of both companies.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 11 -- Israel's highest court ruled today that Meyer Lansky, the American underworld figure, was not entitled to Israeli citizenship even though he is a Jew.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11 -- Long after the memories of who won and lost have been absorbed, analyzed and forgotten, the Games of the XX Olympiad will be remembered for their chaos, confusion and tragedy.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11 (AP) -- The International Olympic Committee today banned 11 Pakistani field hockey players from Olympic competition for life, charging they were disrespectful at the final awards ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The children are going back to school again. Time for the old false sentimentality. Time for the tired pieties about education. Roll them out. Send the newspaper feature writers over to P.S. 17 for one more rewrite of every editor's favorite back-to-school story: Little 6-year-old Adolf Hitler, leaving home for the first day of school, weeps for mother; finds compassion among schoolmates.

Lulu, the gorilla who has been in a state of euphoria since giving birth nine days ago -- to the first gorilla born in this area -- swung into an outside cage at the Central Park Zoo yesterday and showed her baby off to the public.

Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday dismissed as "obscene, intolerable and unacceptable" charges by construction-industry spokesmen that if they "blew the whistle on shakedown-minded inspectors," there would be reprisals from colleagues of the inspectors.

According to the Republican National Committee (RNC) and the Committee to Re-Elect the President (CREEP), their files do not support the widespread belief that candidate Nixon in 1968 claimed a "secret plan" to end the Vietnam war. Inasmuch as they are better known for rummaging around in other people's files than producing facts from their own, I gladly offer the following to save the locks on my doors.

The former Lynda Bird Johnson said that her 2-year-old daughter, Catherine Robb, almost drowned on Labor Day in the swimming pool at the LBJ ranch in Texas when the child apparently crawled under a safety rope around the pool.

TRENTON, Sept. 11 -- New Jersey's American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations is preparing to endorse Senator Clifford P. Case, a liberal Republican, for re-election to a fourth term. The endorsement would be the first ever accorded in New Jersey to a statewide Republican candidate by the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

CAIRO, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- A will, in which the Palestinian terrorists who attacked the Israeli Olympic team at Munich last Tuesday apologized to the athletes of the world for interrupting their games, was reported by Palestinian sources here to have been made public by the Black September organization, to which the terrorists belonged.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11 -- The International Olympic Committee ruled today that Russia should have the basketball gold medal but left open the possibility of revoking it if a United States protest is upheld.

The Marriott Corporation, a food-service concern and hotel operator, had a 29 per cent rise in net income for the fiscal year ended July 28, the company reported yesterday. Net climbed to $17,734,000, or 62 cents a share, from $13,777,000, or 51 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.
The United States applied formally to Britain yesterday to extradite a Taiwanese convicted here of plotting to murder the son of Chiang Kai-shek.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday that its office products division has introduced five new models of "input word processing equipment," better known in the past as dictation equipment.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 11 -- Princeton University, by reducing its expenses and increasing its income, has balanced its budget after two years of deficits that ran as high as $1.5-million.
DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- Aided by a timely rainstorm, the New York Yankees completed a three-game sweep of the Detroit Tigers tonight with a 4-2 victory ended alter 5 1/2 innings by a steady downpour.
Cesar Chavez' call for a nationwide lettuce boycott is being met by legislation prohibiting use of this tactic, the only effective strategy for the migrant farm worker.

The $750,000 grant to the New York Public Library by the National Endowment for the Humanities underscores both the library's precarious finances and the growing realization that a national rather than a local resource is at stake.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- By its veto in the Security Council yesterday, the United States signaled a fundamental change in strategy with regard to the Middle East.

The Republican leaders of the Assembly began an eight-city election campaign trip here yesterday asserting that the Republican-controlled Legislature had "met the needs of the city and its administration."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Retail sales rose strongly again in August to a record $38-billion, the Commerce Department reported on a preliminary basis today.

PANAMA, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Panama's newly elected Assembly of Community Representatives today charged that the Panama Canal Zone was being "occupied arbitrarily" and voted to reject the $1.93-million the United States pays annually to use it.

The race for the American League's Eastern Division continued on its merry-go-round last night. But one contending team, the Boston Red Sox, was undone by a sacrifice fly in Cleveland's Municipal Stadium and lost to the Indians, 6-5.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle, in what some Senators considered a change of testimony, told the Senate Armed Services Committee today that he had "committed no wrong" in connection with the unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam for which he was dismissed from the Air Force.

The New York Giants cut their roster to 40 players yesterday, as required by National Football League rules, when they asked waivers on Ralph Heck, a linebacker with 10 years of professional experience; Ed Baker, a quarterback, who has spent two years on the Giants' taxi squad; Dick Kotite, a tight end, and Bart Buetow, an offensive lineman.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 -- A three-judge Federal Court ruled today that provisions of the Bank Secrecy Act permitting the Government to examine individual bank accounts were an unconstitutional invasion of privacy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission asked Congress today to enact swiftly legislation that would give the commission clear-cut authority to regulate pyramid sales ventures similar to Glenn W. Turner's Dare to Be Great.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Senator George McGovern opened his national media campaign tonight with a television commercial that has served his cause ever since the New Hampshire primary.

Construction was ordered halted last night on two new terminals in the $400-million redevelopment project at Newark Airport after negotiators failed to resolve a dispute over the hiring of six black men as iron-worker trainees.
Carrie Jones figured that Warren MacArthur would be "a difficult case" the minute he walked in the door for his first day in the first grade at Public School 155 yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 12 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today a new guarantee program for automobile repairs. It called the plan "the most extensive improvement program in automotive history."

Six works, commissioned by the Koussevitzky Music Foundation, will be performed by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center this season and next. One of them, Barbara Kolb's " -- soever" for winds and strings, will be given its premiere in the society's opening concerts on Oct. 27 and 29 in Tully Hall.

ATHENS, Sept. 11 -- The International Commission of Jurists has accused Greece of violating legal practices "accepted among civilized nations" by holding a woman political prisoner incommunicado for four weeks without charge or trial.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- The Pontiac Motor Division said today that it had redesigned 1973 model car engines to provide better performance and economy while still meeting the stricter Federal antipollution rules.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- One or more gunmen broke into the home of the police chief of Bermuda, George Duckett, Saturday night, shot him to death and wounded his 17-year-old daughter, the police reported yesterday.

Rapid transit is a popular form of chess among more advanced players. One way of playing it is to limit the game to five minutes, which requires fast thinking and immediate decisions, and which can be extremely strenuous when the competition is strong.
Nine more food establishments, including five restaurants and two bakeries, were cited yesterday by the Health Services Administration for violating the city's Health Code.

In a chase scene like the one that highlighted the movie "The French Connection," two policemen -- commandeering trucks and cars in the street below -- pursued an elevated train in the Bronx for five stops yesterday before heading it off and seizing two armed-robbery suspects who had boarded it.

DETROIT, Sept. 11 -- A game that may decide the American League pennant race remains unscheduled by Joe Cronin, the league president, for no discernible reason except that it may not have to be played.

The President's National Commission on Productivity is sponsoring a comparative study of work attitudes and job satisfaction, it was disclosed yesterday at a productivity conference conducted by the American Management Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Terence Jackson, assistant to the executive director of the commission, said that it was involved in a joint project with Japan, West Germany and other industrial nations to study attitudes on work under conditions of automation.
The new school year got off to a generally smooth start yesterday for most of the city's 1.1 million pupils and their 60,000 teachers.

Granite Management Services, Inc., a diversified real estate and computer-leasing concern based in Garden City, L. I., announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Inter-Island Mortgage Corporation, a mortgage-banking company also based on Long Island, for an undisclosed amount of cash and notes.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 11 The San Francisco Opera began celebrating "Opera Week" today, with Joan Sutherland singing before a noon crowd in Union Square.
TUNIS, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- The bodies of five Arab guerrillas killed in Munich, West Germany, last week arrived tonight in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, the Libyan radio reported.

Two committees supporting inmates at the State Correctional Facility at Attica, N. Y., announced yesterday that a "dignified, peaceful" memorial service would be held outside the prison walls tomorrow.

WASHINGTON -- "The Old Guard dies, but never surrenders." Those ringing words were supposed to have been said by Gen. Pierre Etienne de Cambronne, commanding Napoleon's Imperial Guard at Waterloo, when called upon to surrender.

Despite some technical problems, the first Earth Resources Technology Satellite is transmitting a steady stream of panoramic portraits of the earth, including the first published picture of the New York metropolitan area taken from space.

MUNICH,. West Germany, Sept. 11 (AP) -- American riders lost the last gold medal of the Olympics Games tonight to the host West Germans by the narrowest possible margin -- a quarter of a point -- but they were happy to get so close.
Uncertainty over the future of platinum futures sent prices down sharply again yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

A funny thing happened to the port last month. For the first time in several years, according to traffic data furnished by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, there was an increase in both ship arrivals and ship departures over the previous year.
A Louis Harris poll of voters made public yesterday showed that 55 per cent supported continued heavy bombing of North Vietnam, while 32 per cent opposed it.

BONN, Sept. 11 -- The West German Government announced today that it was granting about $1-million to relatives of the 11 Israelis killed here in the commando raid last week. An official statement said that the money would be delivered by the West German Red Cross to the Magen David Adom, the Israeli equivalent of the Red Cross.

ATHENS, Sept. 11 -- The Greek Government unveiled today a summary of a 15-year master plan for economic and social development that promised to "achieve material prosperity without sacrificing the nation's spiritual values."

The Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 600,000 common shares. Net proceeds will be used to repay outstanding domestic short-term indebtedness with the balance to be added to working capital.
Schools remained closed in a number of suburban areas yesterday as striking teachers continued to press their demands.

WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Sept. 11 -- A healthy Willis Reed, the ingredient the Knicks must have to challenge for the championship in a stronger National Basketball Association, signed a multiple-season contract today.
The stock market posted its fifth consecutive loss yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by more than 2 to 1 in continued light trading.
Within five short blocks of my apartment on East 52d Street, there are about ten squirrels, a bevy of moles and a large assortment of sparrows, starlings, swallows, and wrens.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 11 -- The social Olympics that got under way in connection with the 1972 Olympic Games resumed in this sprawling city after only a one-day pause last Tuesday following the Arab terrorist attack in which 17 persons died. By the weekend, the partying was in full swing again.

Consolidated Edison's peak demand for electricity in the coming winter will exceed output from its "efficient plants" by 2 million kilowatts, foreing the utility to use costlier and obsolete units, the city administration said yesterday.

" My name is Mrs. Friedman and I'm your teacher. And I'm new here, like you are," said the slim, smiling 2-year-old -- wearing bell-bottoms, a knit pull-over and thong sandals -- to each new arrival yesterday for her kindergarten class at Public School 14 in Corona Heights, Queens.
ATTICA, N, Y., Sept. 11 (AP) -- An Attica prison inmate from Buffalo died today in his cell, an apparent suicide by hanging, according to Superintendent Ernest L. Montayne.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 11 -- One leg of the Bay Area Rapid Transit district's new system opened to paying passengers today in a nearly flawless display of what electrified rails can provide in what may be their last stand against the automobile.

CHICAGO, Sept. 11 (UPI) -- The American Medical Association has proposed legislation that would establish an emergency medical services administration as a branch of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- President Nixon's main campaign treasury took in and spent nearly $5-million during the last three weeks of August, campaign finance disclosures showed today.
BERNE, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Switzerland has dropped plans to buy either American or French fighter-bombers to modernize her air force, Defense Minister Rudolf Gnaegi said today.

FRYEBURG, Me. -- Shortly after dawn, acres of white water lilies on Pleasant Pond opened to the light and warmth of the sun, and as white as the blossoms of the lilies was a herring gull that had made this remote inland lake its summer home.
Most investors are about as familiar with the put-and-call market as they are with the mating habits of the porcupine.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 11 (AP) -- Any new law to increase speed and efficiency of securities handlers should retain a "climate of cooperative regulation,'' a New York Stock Exchange official told Congress today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 11 -- Sargent Shriver promised the machinists' convention here today that if George McGovern becomes President he will appoint a union man to head the Department of Labor.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 11 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy joined Senator George McGovern's traveling campaign party here tonight and helped the Democratic Presidential candidate evoke one of his best welcomes yet from a largely youthful crowd of more than 9,000 at the Minneapolis Auditorium.
Previously confidential documents have been obtained that reveal the story of a small agency's unsuccessful seven-year effort to get on the roster of one of the country's top advertisers.

Most movies with all-white casts have nothing to do with the issue of race, but the same does not seem true for current movies and plays in which black actors predominate. Of the "black movies" now on view -- "Shaft," "Shaft's Big Score," "Super Fly," "Come Back Charleston Blue" and others -- all seem to be commenting in one way or another on what it means to be black in America.

CAIRO, Sept. 11 -- Egypt today dismissed as "unacceptable and illegitimate" a West German Government statement criticizing Arab nations for failing to condemn publicly the Palestinian guerrilla attack on Israeli athletes in Munich.
MUNICH, West Germany, Sept, 11 -- With a moment of silent prayer as a somber reminder, the XX Olympic Games ended tonight after two weeks of tumult and tragedy.
Muhammad Ali and Floyd Patterson continued yesterday to approach their 12-round heavyweight bout at Madison Square Garden Sept. 20 with congeniality, not controversy.
The Theodore Hamm Company, a subsidiary of Heublein, Inc., and one of the 10 largest brewers in the country, will stop using the J. Walter Thompson Company as its advertising agency Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- Paul A. Volcker told Congress today that intervention by the Federal Reserve and Treasury in foreign-exchange markets would not be used "to artificially prop up the dollar counter to any basic balance-of-payments trends."

MOSCOW, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- Ninety-four Jews have protested to the Moscow City Council over restrictions on access to the city's main synagogue during Rosh ha-Shanah, the Jewish new year, usually reliable sources said today.
BELFAST, Sept. 11 -- Workers walked out of two Belfast power stations today in a protest against the British Paratroop Regiment's killing of two Protestants in riots here last week.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 11 (Reuters) -- The West German Bundesbank announced today modifications to the June ruling subjecting the sale of mark fixed-interest securities to non-residents to specific Bundesbank permission.

China's purchase of 10 Boeing jets and her conditional order in July for three supersonic Concordes herald the entry of the last of the world's major powers into the big leagues of commercial aviation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 (AP) -- Efforts to adopt two tax-reform amendments to help pay for the $34.8-billion revenue-sharing bill failed in the Senate today.

Bridge authorities are sometimes asked two apparently unrelated questions: Should husbands teach their wives to play? And can the unorthodox bids and plays of an inexperienced player so confuse an expert that he will go astray? The answer to both questions is "very rarely," but the diagramed deal happens to illustrate exceptions in both areas.

Although fall is just around the corner, boys' wear retailers are beginning to plan their purchases for the spring, 1973, season. Talks with a group of them yesterday indicated that they were looking for a big one.

PUYALLUP, Wash., Sept. 11 -- Administrative Judge Ernest Nash of the Federal Communications Commission recessed today the hearing on Radio KAYE's application for the continuation of a broadcast license, and announced that he would enter an order to end the hearing.

Governors Cahill and Rockefeller will have a rare chance to strike a blow for environmental integrity when the Delaware River Basin Commission meets tomorrow in Philadelphia. The New Jersey and New York executives will in effect decide whether or not to block the potentially devastating Tocks Island Dam project, which has been studied, restudied and studied again for seventeen years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 11 -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today a $4.3-billion cut in the defense budget. Despite the reduction, the $74.6-billion measure represents the largest defense appropriations bill to be recommended by the committee since World War II.

MOSCOW -- In the quiet process of borrowing fashions from the bourgeois West, Soviet men feel they are falling behind their women. The women are getting an increasing, though still modest, flow of chignons, patterned panty hose and pants suits. But men complain they can't find a decent wide tie.
AUBURN, N. Y., Sept. 11 -- William H. McKeon, former state Democratic party chairman, has a chance at winning $109,234 in the bonus drawing of the state lottery.

The United States broke off discussions with France yesterday for a new bilateral treaty on reciprocal air service because of what State Department officials called Paris's "unbending resistance" to a proposed new international treaty against hijacking.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Mrs. John N. Mitchell has identified the man who allegedly tore the telephone from the wall during her conversation with a reporter last June as the new head of security for the Committee for the Re-election of the President.

Miss Elizabeth Fontaine Martin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fontaine Martin of Darien, Conn., and Landgrove, Vt., was married in London last Friday to Erno Ferencz Belan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Erno Belan of London, formerly of Budapest.

TORONTO, Sept. 12 (AP) -The American challenger, Dynamite, again exhibited superior boat speed in light air today, beating Mirage on the Lake Ontario course and taking a 2-0 lead in the Canada Cup sailing series.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 12 -The Democratic boss in Danbury has problems. He is trying to run a campaign to get Democrats elected in an industrial, conservative Democratic town where the people do not particularly like the man at the top of the ticket.

Robert D. Wood, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System television network, yesterday branded as "completely cockeyed" proposals that the networks be prevented from presenting reruns during more than 25 per cent of the evening prime viewing time in any given year.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 12 -- A miscalculation in Yale's budget estimates has resulted in a 1971-72 deficit that is less than one-fifth of the $5.7-million originally predicted.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 12 -- A prominent American physician said today on the return from his second trip to China in two years that he expected herbal remedies would follow acupuncture as the next medicinal import from China.
CHICAGO, Sept. 12 (AP) -Federal prosecutors say that former Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois took a $45,000 bribe from a race track operator just before his election in 1960.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday he would announce "soon" his decision on a proposed mall on Madison Avenue between 42d and 57th Streets.
YONKERS, Sept. 12 -- It long has been acknowledged that the most hazardous gamble at a harness track is a wager on the outcome of a race involving 2-year-old trotting fillies.

The American Basketball Association suffered a damaging blow yesterday, when Ernest Tidwell, a Superior Court judge in Atlanta, ruled that Julius Erving could play for the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association.

Kuhns, president of General Public Utilities Corporation, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of two of its subsidiaries, Jersey Central Power Light Company and New Jersey Power Light Company. Dr. Shepard Bartnoff, who had been director of environmental affairs at the G.P.U. Service Corporation -- another company in the G.P.U. system -- was named president and chief operating officer of the two New Jersey organizations.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The nation's two smaller automobile manufacturers said today they would raise the prices on their 1973 models if possible even if the prices on other new cars remained frozen.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 12 -Chile's socialist revolution in slow motion, approaching its second anniversary, has come up against the little man, the home or store owner, organized and fighting to survive in an increasingly state - controlled economy.
MOSCOW, Sept. 12 -- Cold war competitiveness may be mellowing in other fields, but it still runs strong in sports.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 12 -- Secretary General Waldheim declared today that the United Nations could not remain "a mute spectator" to the acts of terrorism that were plaguing the world.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -With eight weeks to go until Election Day, state and national Republican officials gathered today to duscuss how the campaign has been going and also to look ahead. They met with almost everyone concerned, from President Nixon to political technicians.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- After a three-year battle to placate opposing lobbies and pressure groups, the Food and Drug Administration today finally -- maybe -- settled the question of the definition of the word macaroni.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -Lieut. Gen. John D. Lavelle has told the Senate Armed Services Committee that he received permission from Gen. Creighton W. Abrams and Adm. Thomas H. Moorer before ordering a series of attacks on North Vietnamese airfields in November, 1971, well-placed sources said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 13 -- South Vietnamese marines fought their way into the walled Citadel in Quangtri city Monday night, a South Vietnamese military spokesman said. The marines reportedly took up where paratroopers left off July 28, after the first attempt to recapture the town from the North Vietnamese.

A 9-year-old girl whose mother allegedly drowned her in a kitchen sink to save the child from hunger will have a "decent" burial today because neighbors in the East Harlem slum where she lived raised $410 in a door-to-door collection.

LONDON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -A Taiwanese architect convicted of conspiring to assassinate Gen. Chiang Kai-Shek's son at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan was ordered held in custody in London for another week today.

Rod Stewart and Faces have been bouncing around the States this summer buoyed by their reputation -- at home -- as one of the best rock bands in all of England. WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -The United States Court of Appeals was asked today to reject the delegate-apportionment formula for the 1976 Republican National Convention on the same ground on which a lower court had found the 1972 formula unconstitutional.

Textile sales this year are expected to exceed the 1971 level by 7 per cent, H. W. Close, president of the American Textile Manufacturers Institute, said yesterday. He estimated domestic mill volume at $24.5-billion, up from $22.9-billion last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -Senator George McGovern, the Democratic nominee for President, has spent the last few weeks clarifying his views on a range of domestic matters. But in one area he has not yet enunciated a comprehensive doctrine, and it is the area in which President Nixon feels himself on safest and strongest ground -- foreign policy.
(AP) -- The Oldsmobile Division of General Motors unveiled today the industry's only brand new model offering of the 1973 run -- a compact called the Omega.

GOSHEN, N. Y. -- A light bulb hanging from the ceiling illuminates the kitchen in the gray predawn light as Lupe Ortiz starts her day, cooking breakfast for her husband and their nine children. One of about 2,000 migrant workers in Orange County, she is the hardest working member of a hard-working family. Her sturdy figure bends over the stove while Victor, her husband, and their children, sleep.

The United States Court of Appeals here granted a stay yesterday of a week-old injunction against political activities by the National Committee for Impeachment, which seeks to impeach President Nixon for his conduct of the war in Vietnam.

DETROIT, Sept. 12 -- John Hiller, Woodie Fryman and Ed Brinkman blended their varied talents and backgrounds tonight to bring the Detroit Tigers a 3-2 victory overthe Baltimore Orioles and a further tightening of the American League's Eastern Division pennant race.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -The Pay Board today ordered Washington's two daily newspapers, The Post and The Evening Star-Daily News, to reduce wages and salaries they pay to their mechanical employes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -- The scope of yesterday's Federal Court decision in California relating to the Bank Secrecy Act of 1970 was far narrower than most reports of the decision implied, Treasury and banking industry spokesmen said here today after examining the decision.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 -William L. Taub, the mysterious figure who acted as "legal counsel" for James F. Hoffa, was able to arrange and attend the showing of a film on China at the White House last February, even though the Secret Service had a thick dossier on him.

LOGAN, W. Va., Sept. 12 (UPI) -- A special grand jury will not begin its investigation of the Buffalo Creek Valley flood, which killed at least 118 persons on Feb. 26, until after the Nov. 7 general elections, a judge ruled yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 12 (AP) -Britain issued a stiff protest to Iceland today over an incident between three British trawlers and an Icelandic gunboat.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A specially designed low-cost automobile pro duced by the General Motors Corporation and called the Bedford Tiger was unveiled today for demonstration purposes.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 12 (AP) -- Oilmen offered more than $586-million for 74 tracts of sea bottom off Louisiana's oil-rich shore today, including one bid of $77.3-million for a prime 5,000-acre area.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would suspend trading in 13 preferred issues of 10 companies, including the General Tire Rubber Company and W. T. Grant Company, effective Sept. 25.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Leaders of both parties moved month-long Senate debate over the new United States-Soviet nuclear arms control agreement.

Marc Chagall has agreed to create a 70-foot-long outdoor mosaic structure in Chicago's Loop, a few blocks from Picasso's Colossus. The work is expected to take form next year on an open landscaped terrace at the First National Plaza.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Sept. 12 (UPI) -- A Mount Vernon toiletries manufacturer was fined $70,000 yesterday in Suffolk County District Court after being convicted in a charity swindle.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 12 (UPI) -- Mark Spitz said today he had been flooded with contract offers, requests for personal appearances and fan mail since winning seven Olympic gold medals in swimming.

FRASCATI, Italy, Sept. 12 -- The foreign and finance ministers of the Common Market's six present and four prospective member nations removed today the final doubts over the holding of the proposed European summit conference to chart the course of the enlarged market.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- The nation's corn crop, a key to consumer meat supplies next winter, will be 5,124,425,000 bushels, down 8 per cent from the record harvest in 1971 but 4 per cent more than forecast in August, the Agriculture Department estimated today.

President Nixon is leading Senator George McGovern in New York State, 50 per cent to 30 per cent, according to a WCBS-TV news poll released last night.

Now the Soviet Union has announced a similar but even more impressive feat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 12 (AP) -- A coalition of Indians has sued the Federal Government for $15-billion in damages, saying that tribes were deceived in settlement of their claim to two-thirds of California.

BERLIN, Sept. 12 -- The outlook for European monetary union is still clouded by a lack of harmony between the French and the West Germans. The West Germans cling tightly to their American relationship. The French, under President Pompidou, continue their basic Gaullist line of seeking political and economic independence of the Americans.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- Ancient Line turned on the heat in the stretch today to cap a hard-driving advance from fifth place with a victory by a nose in the $7,500 feature for fillies and mares on the turf at the Atlantic City Racecourse.

The people who make classical recordings are pinching themselves, cautiously but happily, as they look forward to the 1972-73 season. Since their darkest days, some three or four seasons ago, they have been slowly but steadily returning to life.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -The Air Force is dropping simulated North Vietnamese currency printed on propaganda leaflets over North Vietnam to drive home to the population woes caused by "inflation," State Department officials said today.

ATLANTA, Sept. 18 (AP) -Kathy Whitworth and Jane Blalock have passed the $50,000 mark in earnings this year, the first players in the history of the Ladies Professional Golf Association to reach that figure.

The General Signal Corporation announced yesterday an agreement in principle to acquire the Mixing Equipment Company, Inc., for 480,000 shares of General Signal com mon stock, which would have a current market value of $24.66-million.

Floyd Patterson rested yesterday and hoped that Muhammad Ali would be made a strong favorite for their fight tomorrow night. Meanwhile, Ali continued to train and said he "expected the fight to go all the way."
MANILA, Sept. 18 -- Two explosions rocked the new city hall in Quezon city today, injuring 25 people and destroying several rooms and part of the auditorium in the community just east of Manila.

Sparky Lyle saved the game in another relief pitching appearance, but he could do nothing about thieves who made off with $27,000, from the Stadium Club at Yankee Stadium some time after Sunday's New York Yankee victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Sept. 18 (UPI) -- United States and Laotian spokesmen today reported an upsurge in fighting around the Plaine des Jarres in northern Laos and near the town of Khong Sedone in the southern part of the country.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 18 -- The potential of offshore floating nuclear power "islands" moved a step nearer reality today at a point just under three miles off the Jersey coast.

LOGAN, W. Va., Sept 18 -Senator George McGovern came to West Virginia's coal country today to assert that the Government should "put an end to the strip mining that is destroying much of this beautiful state."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -Industrial production resumed its brisk rise in August following two months of sluggishness, partly caused by the effects of tropical storm Agnes, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy has told his policemen that those who make bribery arrests will be considered for higher paying jobs and more desirable assignments.

A dispirited stock market, locked in a slump since Labor Day, drifted downward yesterday in one of the slowest trading sessions of 1972. The Dow-Jones industrials, firming near the close, ended 1.96 lower at 945.36.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Sept. 18 -- Fifty years after winning her first tournament, New Jersey's most durable golfer can still belt a tee shot 215 yards. That's about 35 yards shorter than Maureen Orcutt used to hit, but she's managed to compensate for loss of distance by improving other areas of her game.

Sudden and unforeseen bonanzas are eagerly awaited in Wall Street. They usually seem to involve technology companies with new products, mining companies with big ore strikes or other equally exciting vehicles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Soviet-American maritime negotiations, the first step toward a planned comprehensive trade pact between the two countries, opened here today with the United States facing complex domestic and international issues.

While building bridges to the Russians and Chinese, Mr. Nixon has been burning bridges to America's allies in West Europe and Japan. The Democratic platform opened this issue and it has been carried further by the head of the McGovern foreign policy task forces, Prof. Abram Chayes of Harvard, in visiting Europe to combat fears about Mr. McGovern's alleged "isolationism." Mr. Chayes argued that President Nixon has "already isolated" the United States.

But America's European allies fear a McGovern administration even more than they dislike the Nixon one. The Democratic candidate has said that he is a "convinced internationalist." Withdrawal from Vietnam and his "Come Home America" call, Mr. McGovern has said, are intended not as moves toward disengagement everywhere but as steps that would enable the United States to concentrate on really vital interests abroad, Western Europe and the Mediterranean first of all.

Floyd Patterson rested yesterday and hoped that Muhammad Ali would be made a strong favorite for their fight tomorrow night. Meanwhile, Ali continued to train and said he "expected the fight to go all the way."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz qualified today the pledges recently made by two other Administration officials that President Nixon would not propose any tax increases throughout a second term in office.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 18 -- Secretary of State Edmund G. Brown Jr. filed a suit in the Sacramento County Superior Court last week asking that controversial farm labor initiative be removed from the Nov. 7 California election ballot.
Henry W. Loomis, deputy director of the United States Information Agency, was appointed yesterday to head the federally chartered Corporation for Public Broadcasting.

SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 18 -- A field of 61 countries, a record, is entered in the Chess Olympics, which started today at 4 P.M. (11 A.M. New York time.) The competition is for the team championship of the world, held generally every two years.
Former Gov. Richard J. Hughes said yesterday that he was too busy to take a leading role in Senator George McGovern's campaign in New Jersey.

That The Times should find the current wave of "black movies" a subject worthy of an editorial [Sept. 12] is interesting enough, but more interesting is your assertion that ". . . movies with all-white casts have nothing to do with the issue of race. . . ." Indeed, such movies more often than not have everything to do with race.

LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 18 -- The brother of John F. Kerry, an antiwar candidate for the Democratic nomination to the House in the Fifth Massachusetts District, was arrested with another Kerry campaign worker early today and charged with breaking into the building housing the headquarters of a Kerry opponent.

ATLANTA, Sept. 18 (AP) -Kathy Whitworth and Jane Blalock have passed the $50,000 mark in earnings this year, the first players in the history of the Ladies Professional Golf Association to reach that figure.

About 4,500 teachers in Washington vowed to go on strike this morning for higher pay and in protest against increases in the size of their classes. Government officials sought a temporary restraining order to block the threatened walkout.

For the last six months Christopher Darway has been working on a system to link pieces of jewelry, taking a basic unit or modular element and adapting it to rings, bracelets and necklaces. What he has done is on exhibition and sale through Sept. 29 at Amulets and Talismans, 740 Madison Avenue.

" If it wasn't for Congresswoman Shirley Chisholm's support of Assemblyman Vander Beatty, there would be no contest," said State Senator Waldaba Stewart, who faces Mr. Beatty today in a court-ordered re-run of the primary vote for the State Senate and district leader seat of Bedford-Stuyvesant's 18th Senatorial District.

Commercial interests, including exporters, bought wheat futures heavily yesterday, pushing prices up the 10-cents-abushel daily limit in the case of some deliveries, with resulting new life-of-contract highs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- Representatives of three farm organizations and several Democratic members of a House Agriculture subcommittee sharply criticized the Department of Agriculture today for the way it had handled the United States-Soviet grain deal.

ALBANY, Sept. 18 -- A sharp reduction in fresh fruits and vegetables reaching market in New York State was reported here today by state and Federal agriculture officials, indicating that prices for consumers would be soaring in the near future.
NEWARK, Sept. 18 (AP) -A sun roof providing cover for 6,000 fans will be installed at the proposed New Jersey home of the football Giants.

The problems of the world come to roost at the doorstep of the United Nations in an exceptionally urgent sense today as the representatives of 132 nations gather under extraordinary security precautions for the 27th session of the General Assembly at Turtle Bay.

A French horn player in Stuyvesant Town whose practice sessions allegedly drove at least one neighbor up the wall was ordered by a judge yesterday to confine her playing to specified hours or face eviction.

KANA, Lebanon, Sept. 18--Highly placed Lebanese sources said today that the Lebanese Army was setting up new roadblocks and otherwise building up its presence in southern Lebanon to restrict the activities of Arab commandos along the Israeli front.
The Port of New York appears to be more than holding its own in the constant and often fierce competition with other Atlantic ports that serve as terminals for containerships.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -The Securities and Exchange Commission is seeking ways in which individual investors of relatively modest means can get somewhat personalized investment advice at reasonable cost, William J. Casey, chairman, said today.
TRENTON, Sept. 18 -- A $54-million Medicaid program for Newark, announced here today, places the Federal Government in the role of guaranteeing the delivery as well as the payment of medical care.
CHICAGO, Sept. 18 -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon began her first and longest political swing on her own for the 1972 Presidential campaign today by declaring: "I'm taking the White House to the people."
GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 18 -- Tenure hearings for a University of Florida wildlife ecology instructor, Dr. George W. Cornwell, resumed today after a three-week recess.

LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The first Indians and Pakistanis to be airlifted out of Uganda arrived here this morning and were met by a chilly rain, hot tea, an official welcome, and a reminder that to many Britons they were not so welcome.
BONN, Sept. 18--Chancellor Willy Brandt said today that, to open the way to federal elections on Nov. 19, he would ask parliament for a vote of confidence Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18-The Administration has suddenly become alarmed at the implications of an amendment in the big defense-appropriations bill that may threaten the agreement with European and Japanese steel producers to limit their steel exports to the United States.

HARTFORD, Sept. 19 -- The General Assembly met in special session today, summoned by Gov. Thomas J. Meskill to stave off a bus crisis and possibly to formulate a comprehensive, long-range approach to Connecticut's worsening public-transportation problems.

The stock market opened yesterday with a mild show of strength, but it gave ground later in another spiritless session to finish with a loss. The Dow-Jones industrials, dipping 2.18 points, ended at 943.18.

In an effort to save some private, expensive parkland scheduled for development in Tudor City, the City Planning Commission announced yesterday that it had gone to the unusual length of preparing a list of alternative plans -- including a 46-story apartment tower spanning East 42d Street -- that would be put to a public hearing Oct. 4.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Sept. 19 -- Etsusaburo Shiina, the special envoy sent by Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan, ended a three-day visit here today, apparently without having softened the Taipei Government's strong opposition to Tokyo's plans for "normalization" of relations with the Chinese Communist Government.

The three one-act plays that opened Monday as the first installment in a two-part Imamu Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones) festival at the Afri-American Studio are angry indictments written from a highly moral position.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -The seven men charged on eight counts each in the Watergate bugging conspiracy case all pleaded not guilty today and were released an bonds ranging from $10,000 to $50,000.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Sept. 19 -- Delegates to the United Steelworkers of America convention voted decisively today to support the decision of the union president, I. W. Abel, and other steelworker leaders to refrain from endorsing either Presidential candidate.

TRENTON, Sept. 19 -- New Jersey will offer bettors a daily 50-cent lottery beginning Nov. 29, to meet increased competition to the weekly lottery from surrounding states and to cut into receipts of the illegal numbers racket.

NEW CITY, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- A 2 per cent Rockland County sales tax, designed to reduce the tax burden on real property owners, was proposed tonight to the County Legislature.
Health authorities issued warnings yesterday against eating clams or mussels harvested in Maine, New Hampshire or Massachusetts waters since early this month.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Sept. 19 -- Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling, promising the 180,000 residents of the Bahamas their freedom from Britain next summer, apparently led his Progressive Labor party to victory at the polls today.

There is a special curiosity due to a Jewish dramatic company originating today in Eastern Europe, where Jews do not seem particularly welcome. Senator George McGovern says that if he is elected he will hold Presidential news conferences twice a month, open Cabinet meetings to the press "except in rare cases where the national security poses a secrecy requirement" and end background briefings in which information is supplied on the condition that the source is not disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A Federal judge issued today a temporary restraining order that will probably delay two major new regulations of the Federal Reserve Board that were scheduled to take effect on Thursday.

The Knicks, looking to the future when they will have to rebuild their talented, but aging front line, obtained the negotiation rights yesterday to John Gianelli from the Houston Rockets. The 22-year-old Gianelli was the nation's second leading college rebounder last season at the University of Pacific and was named to several all-America teams.
CHICAGO, Sept. 19 -- Senator George McGovern endorsed today a tax-credit system of providing Federal aid to parochial and other nonpublic schools.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Nixon is now fighting on about four fronts at the same time, so it is scarcely surprising that what he says and does on one front sometimes gets in the way of what he is trying to do on the others.
ALBANY, N. Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- New York State has been studying for the last six months the possibility of starting a daily state lottery, State Tax Commissioner Norman F. Gallman said today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 20 -- Heavy fighting was reported yesterday in the central coastal province of Quangngai, with four of its 10 district capitals under continuing attack.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Two Hempstead boys were in custody today at the Children's Shelter here in connection with the fatal wounding of a man and the shooting of his wife during a robbery at their home last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Overseas Private Investment Corporation, the government agency that insures American private investment abroad, announced today that it had denied insurance claims from the Anaconda Company of $154-million connected with Anaconda's nationalized copper investments in Chile.

Mayer Lindsay toured the garment area, unveiled a sign temporarily renaming part of Seventh Avenue, "Fashion Avenue," and had lunch with leaders of the garment industry at The Daily News yesterday as the city began its first annual Fall Fashion Festival.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Clarence D. Palmby, a former Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, denied "categorically" today that he had had any part in negotiations between the Continental Grain Company and the Soviet Union after he had left the Government to join the company as vice president.
One of the largest land development companies in the country acknowledged yesterday that many Federal charges against the industry of widespread unscrupulous practices have been justified.

S. J. Perelman, the man without a country home, has returned to his native New York City.

TOKYO, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The policy board of the Bank of Japan announced today the abolition of two measures designed to promote exports with preferential treatment. They are the system of making loans on the security of export trade bills and the system of discounting export advances denominated in yen.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The United States protested to Syria nine days ago the arrest of Major Barrett, but he remains detained without known charges, the State Department said today.
The dissolution of one of the oldest partnerships in the mutual fund industry was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A Government study suggests far-reaching changes in the habits of Americans, particularly in transportation, that might moderate the soaring demand for fuels and electric power.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 -- The grim succession of terrorist acts against Israeli targets in recent months has set Israelis, and Arabs of various political stripes, to addressing themselves to two questions: Why should Arab militants have recourse now, more than 20 years after the birth of Is rael, to such spectacular terrorist gestures?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Justice Department and Governor Rockefeller yesterday urged a Senate subcommittee to approve a compact between New York and New Jersey extending the jurisdiction of the Waterfront Commission to airports.

LONDON, Sept. 19 -- An Israeli diplomat was killed and another injured today when an envelope sent through the mail exploded in the embassy.

Governor Rockefeller's response to the Knapp Commission's call for a special prosecutor to root out official corruption holds promise of effective reform. WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -Dr. George Gallup, the dean of American political pollsters, said today that Senator George McGovern had as good a chance of closing the gap with President Nixon as he did in winning the key primaries.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- David L. Kinley, executive assistant to L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that the former chief of the Los Angeles office of the bureau had been suspended for a second time and demoted to the Minneapolis office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- A toxic chemical used in plastics and paints has been found in unexpectedly large amounts in 17 of 39 states sampled, according to Government scientists. The chemical appeared especially prevalent in newly developed real estate lakes.

The Metropolitan Opera opened its season last night with what Lowell Wadmond, in a pre-curtain speech, called "Goeran Gentele's new 'Carmen'." Mr. Wadmond, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera, was of course referring to the late general manager and his projected debut.
A French specialist in cave research, after remaining isolated underground for 205 days in Texas, has found that, for reasons unknown, his body rhythm sometimes doubled its rate.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (AP) --Steve Dunning's pitching in the first game and Graig Nettles's hitting in the second powered the Cleveland Indians to a 3-2, 6-4 double-header sweep over Detroit tonight that knocked the Tigers out of first place in the American League East.
New York University plans to lay off or retire 217 faculty members and impose a strict "pay-your-own-way or perish" rule for its member schools and colleges under a plan to stave off bankruptcy.

Federal District Court Judge John F. Dooling Jr. yesterday dismissed a contempt charge against Nassau County Medical Center brought by a 20-year-old woman who had been refused an abortion.

Representative John J. Rooney jumped to an early lead last night in the first returns from the court-ordered special primary election in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.
Representative John J. Rooney defeated Allard K. Lowenstein early today in the court-ordered special Democratic primary in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District.

CEDAR GROVE, N. J., Sept. 19 -- While the bulk of the track and field world takes a post-Olympic training reprieve, Marty Liquori has started double workouts aimed at resuming his competitive career.
More than 150 pilots and other airline employes demonstrated quietly near the United Nations Building yesterday to campaign for tougher international treatment of hijackers.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Government conceded today that despite the advantage it has claimed for Communism in protecting the environment, heavy industrial pollution was still causing serious damage to the nation's economy.
