WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The House challenged President Nixon to a new veto today by approving an appropriations bill for the Department of Labor and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare that provides $836-million more than requested by the Administration.

A pop music contest for young New York musicians, with two prizes of four-week engagements at two well-known local restaurants, was announced at a news conference yesterday at the Riverboat restaurant, Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, by Phyllis Robinson, Deputy Commissioner of Cultural Affairs.

A former director of Monticello Raceway was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday. Jerome Ehrlich, 41 years old, of South Fallsburg, N.Y., was charged with devising a fraudulent tax scheme in connection with raceway winnings.
Record net income and sales for the quarter and the year ended July 31 were reported yesterday by the Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., Montreal.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Following is a summary of issues that are expected to figure prominently in the 27th annual General Assembly session, which opened today. Some of the issues are formally inscribed on the agenda; others are expected to be raised in the general debate or at committee meetings during the course of the 13-week session.

Another customer, in Chevy Chase, Md., is collecting Adolfos with a passion. She has ordered 55 from his fall collection. The least expensive is a short knitted dress at $260.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Cornell University may construct a multimillion-dollar complex for biological studies at its campus here, university officials disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- It is ironic but unsurprising that policemen's organizations have endorsed President Nixon for re-election. Ten persons were arrested yesterday at the Meyer Levin Junior High in Brooklyn as Brownsville parents continued to demand the admission of their children to the East Flatbush school.

A non-registered secondary offering of 64,700 shares of Carolina Freight Carriers common stock at 13 1/4 was offered yesterday by Bache Co. The company's stock closed at that price, up 1/8, on the New York Stock Exchange.

NEWARK, Sept. 19 -- Despite lower enrollments and mounting costs the Catholic schools of New Jersey are facing a new year with optimism.

Robert Marcel Casadesus was generally considered a musician in the best French tradition -- a tradition known for clarity of expression, a sense of proportion and elegance of phrasing. In reviewing one of his earlier recitals here in 1937, Noel Straus wrote in The New York Times that of the "many striking merits" of his playing, "sanity and continence were pre-eminent" and "few pianists possessing Mr. Casadesus's strength refuse as consistently to indulge in overstatement."

With an anticipated sellout throng of 19,000 expected to produce more sympathy for his 37-year-old opponent than idolatry for him, Muhammad All will oppose Floyd Patterson tonight at Madison Square Garden in a 12-round bout.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -President Nixon will fly to New York next Tuesday to kick off the second tour of his re-election campaign.
LONDON, Sept. 19 -- An Israeli diplomat was killed and another injured today when an envelope sent through the mail exploded in the embassy.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Patrolman Wallace E. Cowper, 31 years old, was arrested today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a police precinct roll-call room and charged with participating in the $316,500 larceny of a suburban Mentor bank.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The State Department said today that the American Embassy in Kampala had been in touch with President Idi Amin and other top officials to secure the release of six Americans detained by Uganda.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Senate voted today to allow the states to use part of their Federal highway money to build mass transportation systems in urban areas.

TRENTON, Sept. 19 -- A rakish bow-backed Windsor, a Jenny Lind callabash bottle and a porcelain coffeepot boasting a dog-shaped spout are all part of the mixed and surprisingly rich legacy that two centuries of this state's craftsmen have left for today's antiques enthusiasts to mull over or merely enjoy.

JERUSALEM -- With the passing of Egypt's President Nasser, Premier Kosygin's hasty visit to Cairo, which outlasted the normal requirements of protocol, indicated Russian apprehension as to relations with Egypt.
A group of private investors announced plans yesterday to build a 3,200-seat theater in Westchester County near the intersection of the State Thruway and the Cross Westchester Expressway.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A Mexican teen-ager, Paul Ramirez, eliminated the United States pro champion, Bob Lutz, from the $60,000 Pacific southwest open tennis tournament in straight sets today.
Governor Rockefeller named a special state prosecutor yesterday to take over from New York City's five District Attorneys all cases of corruption including policemen, prosecutors and judges.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved a revised $1.5-billion military authorization bill today to replace the one that the Senate killed in July.

Not very often does a team lose its No. 1 ranking after a 49-0 victory. Nonetheless, that was Oklahoma's fate yesterday as the United Press International board of coaches selected Southern California as the No. 1 major college football team in the nation.

As the national park system goes into the second century of its existence, the crucial question is whether its priceless properties will remain the natural havens they were intended to be or deteriorate into man-made playgrounds against striking scenic backdrops. A government-sponsored panel, organized by the Conservation Foundation, has turned in a report that courageously opts for nature -- and specifies ways to preserve it.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19 -Vice President Agnew's formal campaign began here today with a suggestion from him that the men indicted for the break-in at the Democratic headquarters in Washington last June were "set up" by someone attempting to embarrass the Republican party.

Acting with unusual speed to avoid the risk of heavy losses, the underwriting group that won $50-million of Baltimore Gas Electric Company bonds on Monday decided yesterday to give up trying to sell them at the price originally decided upon and released the slow-selling issue into the free market, where the yield rose substantially.
New York University plans to lay off or retire 217 faculty members and impose a strict "pay-your-own-way or perish" rule for its member schools and colleges under a plan to stave off bankruptcy.

ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (AP) -Representative Shirley Chisholm, who unsuccessfully sought the Democratic Presidential nomination, says she will not actively support Senator George McGovern's campaign for the White House.

Directors of four publicly held subsidiaries of Wilson Co., Inc., approved yesterday in principal a proposal to consolidate into one new company. The proposal will be submitted to shareholders of the four concerns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Daniel Ellsberg, Anthony J. Russo Jr. and 17 of their attorneys and consultants in the Pentagon papers case sued 10 top Federal officials for damages today, accusing the Government of illegal wiretapping.

Jerome H. Holland, former United States Ambassador to Sweden and president of the Hampton Institute, was elected a director of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and its parent company, the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. Dr. Holland was recently named a public director of the New York Stock Exchange.

MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- The Soviet hockey coach, whose team scored an upset over the Canadian professionals earlier this month, said today that the upcoming four games in Moscow would be tougher for the Russians despite the advantage of playing on home ice.

Not very often does a team lose its No. 1 ranking after a 49-0 victory. Nonetheless, that was Oklahoma's fate yesterday as the United Press International board of coaches selected Southern California as the No. 1 major college football team in the nation.

" Coronation Street," the longest-running and most popular television serial in Britain, will begin a 26-week run here Nov. 13 on WNET-Channel 13. as it is in Britain, the serial will be presented here in twiceweekly episodes, on Mondays and Thursdays at 10 P.M.///

By 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon the dank subterranean hall that is McGirr's Billiard Academy was filling with men who broke into groups and talked excitedly about the imminent head-to-head_ three-cushion billiard confrontation between Jimmy (the Cat) Cattrano and Larry (Boston Shorty) Johnson.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -The chairmen of the Republican and Democratic national committees solemnly promised today to conduct a clean and fair political campaign. Minutes after they signed the pledge, they traded accusations of personal abuse and espionage.
Jack Cassidy, Rosemary Harris and Joel Grey will head the list of Phoenix Theater "alumni" taking part in "Phoenix Rising," a musical and drama salute to the Phoenix as it enters its 20th season.
The Cincinnati Reds broke a 4-4 tie and spoiled Juan Marichal's relief pitching to beat the San Francisco Giants, 5-4, last night in Riverfront Stadium.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Senate voted today to allow the states to use part of their Federal highway money to build mass transportation systems in urban areas.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 19 -- Vice President Agnew said today that the F.B.I. had been ordered to investigate the $750-million sale of American wheat to the Soviet Union.
Manhattan Supreme Court Justice Saul S. Streit announced yesterday that he was retired after more than 36 years on the bench.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 19 -- Spurning opportunity so thoroughly as to be absolutely rude, the New York Yankees were never in the game tonight as they lost to the Milwaukeel Brewers, 7-2.

The Metropolitan Opera opened its 88th season last night and turned what was to have been the joyful debut of Goeran Gentele, its first new general manager in 22 years, into an emotional requiem for his death in an automobile accident on the island of Sardinia in July.

TRENTON, Sept. 19 -- The State Commission of Investigation, opening public hearings here today on alleged municipal corruption in New Jersey suburbs, received testimony of local officials' shakedowns and demands for bribes and kickbacks in return for zoning and planning changes in Hillsborough, a sprawling Somerset County community.

The United States Supreme Court did not want to discuss the disclosure that for the first time in its 182-year history the Court has appointed a girl page -- 14-year-old Deborah Gelin of Rockville, Md. Miss Gelin, a high-school sophomore, was not permitted by her mother to discuss her new job on the telephone.

HASBEYA, Lebanon, Sept. 19 -- The 18-member Arab League moved today to forestall open conflict between the Arab commandos and the Lebanese Government while commandos and Lebanese troops maintained a wary coexistence here near the Israeli border.

More than 3,500 Washington, D.C. teachers ignored a court order and walked off their jobs yesterday in protest against job cuts and a stalled pay rise. Their action forced the closing of 54 of the 184 public schools in the nation's capital.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Housing starts rose strongly in August after an irregular downward drift in previous months, the Commerce Department reported today.

Just about every style a fashionable women would want to wear this winter is in the Donald Brooks fur collection for Bonwit Teller, which was shown yesterday. There are smocks, battle jackets, blazers, pants suits, caftans, fireside skirts, trench coats, cardigans, you-name-it.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 19 -- Of the players on the Washington Redskins 40-man roster, Ted Vactor and Bill Malinchak rank about No. 29 and No. 36. Yet these two little-known members helped tip last night's game to Washington over Minnesota, 24-21, as George Allen's special teams on kicking plays clearly outperformed those of Bud Grant, the Viking coach.

Patterson Cup last season for the first time in 15 years, made it two straight today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association intersectional matches at Rockville Links. The Garden State team scored 44 1/2 points, to 25 1/2 for Long Island and 20 for Westchester.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Senate approved today a major environmental bill designed to meet a developing "land crisis" by authorizing the Federal Government for the first time to help states develop long-range plans for use of land. The vote was 60 to 18.
For years the New York Stock Exchange has been accused of acting as a "private club" strictly for the benefit of its members.

ALBANY, Sept. 14 (AP) -- New York State has been studying for the last six months the possibility of starting a daily state lottery, state Tax Commissioner Norman F. Gallman said today.

A group of 50 tenant shareholders of the Co-Op City housing development in the Bronx charged a state agency and two corporations with fraud yesterday in the sale of apartments in the cooperative which opened three years ago.

Jim Jamieson, the Western open champion, and Tom Weiskopf were named yesterday as the team that will represent the United States in the World Cup golf matches in Melbourne, Australia, Nov. 8 through 12.

A neighborhood association obtained a court order yesterday halting demolition of two turn - of- the - century town-houses opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art, after failing to persuade a Community Board committee, at a stormy session Monday night, to rescind approval of a 24-story apartment building planned for the site.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Clarence D. Palmby, a former Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, denied "categorically" today that he had had any part in negotiations between the Continental Grain Company and the Soviet Union after he had left the Government to join the in negotiations between the Continental Grain Company and the Soviet Union after he had left the Government to join the company as vice president.

Wesleyan got a two-week jump on Amherst and Williams, its Little Three colleagues, when it opened its season last Saturday and lost to Southern Connecticut, 31-21. This proved to Bill Macdermott, the Wesleyan coach, that "our defense, which we thought was our strong point, has work to do."

The Barnard College alumnae association honored Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger yesterday for "excellence and service, intelligence and old-fashioned hard work" in helping her Alma Mater.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Senate passed by 78 to 0 today an omnibus bill to extend several important health programs scheduled to expire next June 30.

Speculators were buyers and commercial concerns were sellers in a relatively quiet grain futures market yesterday. Prices dropped on the Chicago Board of Trade by several cents a bushel in the case of December and later deliveries and more than 6 cents a bushel in the case of the September contract that expired yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A Federal Judge ruled today that Maurice H. Stans, President Nixon's chief campaign fund-raiser, who is also a former Secretary of Commerce, could be named by attorneys for Lawrence F. O'Brien as a defendant in a revised, $3.2-million suit arising from the break-in last June 17 at the Watergate office building.

BOSTON, Sept. 20 -- The results of yesterday's state and Congressional primary elections, coming less than two months before national elections in November, indicated a surprisingly conservative mood in Massachusetts.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A misstatement by Vice President Agnew apparently led President Nixon today to order an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the sale of 400 million bushels of wheat to the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A privately sponsored study concluded today that last year's devaluation of the dollar would not solve the nation's balance-of-payments problem. Julius Erving, who played for the Virginia Squires last season and signed to play for the Atlanta Hawks this season, was awarded to the Milwaukee Bucks yesterday.
