A record-breaking triumph, to the accompaniment of "Ole, Canonero," was registered by the King Ranch's Canonero II in the $28,050 Stymie Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- George Meany decreed strong reprisals today against the Colorado Labor Council for its endorsement of George McGovern.

Controversy continues to smoulder over the refusal of Justice William Rehnquist to disqualify himself in three sensitive cases decided last term. Legislation on the general question of judicial disqualification is sure to be introduced in the next Congress, yet there seems to be a curious pattern to Justice Rehnquist's behavior that has received no attention.

Mao Tse-tung and Chou Enlai, the Chinese Communist leaders, offered to come to Washington in the last months of World War II to talk personally with President Franklin D. Roosevelt but their message was never relayed directly to him, according to Barbara W. Tuchman, the Pulitzer Prize winning historian.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- Secretary General Waldheim today proclaimed 1974 as World Population Year and announced plans for a major conference then on demographic problems.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, Sept. 20 -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon continued her most extensive campaign swing of 1972 today after an outdoor performance that was pelted by rain, sleet, snow and hail.

Having been down so long, fashion is pursuing the road back. Not only has it banned the loony look, but it's linking its respectable clothes with respectable causes. Alexander's opened its fall fashion collection yesterday with a benefit for the American Cancer Society and a "Salute to Women of Achievement."
Four restaurants, a supermarket and a butcher shop were cited by the Health Department yesterday for serious violations of the city's Health Code.

The South Street Seaport Museum and the projected American Museum of the Metropolitan Museum of Art were indorsed yesterday as the first official projects to be sponsored by the newly formed New York City Bicentennial Corporation.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 20 -- British troops reportedly arrested a senior officer of the militant Provisional wing of the outlawed Irish Republican Army here today.
DORADO, Puerto Rico, Sept. 20 -- Armando Miro who left Cuba in 1960, is an artist. The medium he uses is acrylic and more than 1,000 works have been created in his Miami studio.

Scores of paintings and sculptures, many priced at more than $20,000, were put up for sale last night at two Manhattan galleries in an effort to enlarge the financial coffers of Senator George McGovern's Presidential campaign.

HARTFORD, Sept. 20 -- For the second time this year, a Federal district court declared Connecticut's abortion statutes unconstitutional, saying they abridged the rights of a woman "to privacy and personal choice in matters of sex and family life."
Stocks continued their post-Labor Day decline yesterday, drifting lower in slow trading. "The market is dead," said one broker, who added, "That's figuratively speaking, of course."

State Controller Arthur Levitt and City Controller Abraham D. Beame accused the Nixon Administration yesterday of "seriously considering" a national sales tax and said it would be "terribly regressive."
Contrary to the impression created by some environmentalists, an aluminum beer can tossed into the woods by a careless hiker will break down and return to nature -- eventually.

Dr. Wolfgang G. Friedmann, professor of international law and director of international legal research at Columbia University, was robbed and stabbed to death yesterday afternoon three blocks from the campus.
SOUTH NYACK, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- A rare grand piano was moved by helicopter to a sixth-floor apartment here this morning in what an observer was quick to dub "the rarest of piano movements."

Meade H. Esposito, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, charged yesterday that former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein had "stooped to irresponsible charges and manufactured truths" during his unsuccessful campaign for the Democratic nomination for the House in Brooklyn's 14th District.

James Plosia, the Republican Mayor of East Rutherford, N. J., named in a local extortion and shakedown scheme, charged that his implication at a public hearing of the State Commission of Investigation had been engineered by Governor Cahill in retaliation for the Mayor's opposition to the new meadowlands sports complex. A spokesman for the Governor called the Mayor's charges "baseless and ridiculous."

The three-member family of a 76-year-old partly blind retired mill worker in Little Falls, N. Y., was the apparent winner yesterday of the $1-million-plus prize in the New York State lottery drawing, billed as "the richest lottery ever played in America."

NEWARK, Sept. 20 -- A member of the interim board operating Radio Station WNJR under a Federal Communications Commission directive to provide service to the city's black community today broke with the two remaining board members over changes in public-service programing.

The Board of Education has asked Luis Fuentes, the controversial superintendent of Community School District 1, to return $15,527.41 that was paid to him after his services as a principal were terminated last October by his former employer, District 23.

Ken Buchanan of Scotland was awarded a sixth-round knockout over Carlos Ortiz last night at Madison Square Garden in a duel of former world lightweight champions when the 37-year-old New Yorker surrendered on the stool in his corner, and later announced his retirement.
MOSCOW, Sept. 20 -- The Soviet Union launched today an unmanned spacecraft, Cosmos 520, into a high eccentric orbit, believed to be that of a military communications satellite.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- An effort to place the question of reunification of Korea on the agenda of the General Assembly, which could have embarrassed the United States, was beaten back this evening by a narrow margin.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Woody Fryman hurled a six-hitter tonight and drove in two runs with a ninth-inning single as the Detroit Tigers beat Cleveland, 4-1.

An emotional, raucous hearing marked by charges of racism was held at City Hall yesterday on the Forest Hills public-housing project as hundreds of Queens residents turned out to denounce the compromise proposal endorsed by Mayor Lindsay.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The House swept aside objections of the Nixon Administration today to pass a bill to create an independent Federal commission with broad authority to set mandatory safety standards for consumer products.
Profit increases for the eight months ended Aug. 31 were announced yesterday by two airlines -- Trans World and American.

An emotional, raucous hearing marked by charges of racism was held at City Hall yesterday on the Forest Hills public-housing project as hundreds of Queens residents turned out to denounce the compromise proposal endorsed by Mayor Lindsay.

STATELINE, Nev., Sept. 20 (UPI) -- A gunman took $183,000 from Harrah's Tahoe Casino late yesterday, fled through the crowded gambling area to a spot near Lake Tahoe and escaped on a motorcycle tended by a waiting accomplice.
GREENFIELD, Mass., Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Two years ago, vandals destroyed a 99-year-old covered wooden bridge spanning the Green River. It will be replaced this weekend.

A five-year study of the psychological and social factors influencing the sexual responsiveness of women challenges many popular myths and professional theories and raises new thoughts on the treatment of women who fail to reach orgasm.

LONDON, Sept. 20 -- British officials said today that they feared that unless the departure rate of Uganda's Asians was sharply increased, thousands would be left in Uganda after the deadline for their expulsion, Nov. 7. About 50,000 are being forced to leave.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Connecticut fish dealers complained today that government bans on the sale of certain soft-shell clams or "steamers" had hurt sales of hard-shell clams and other shellfish.

Clifford Buck, president of the United States Olympic Committee, charged yesterday that the Munich Organizing Committee failed to enforce the tight security measures it had planned for the Olympic Games.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 20 -- Uganda armed forces loyal to President Idi Amin appeared today to have decisively defeated an invading force of exiles trying to overthrow him.

Sir Rudolf Bing, for 22 of his 70 years the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, has just begun a new career as distinguished visiting professor of music at Brooklyn College. Twice a week he teaches two classes, Humanities 801 (seminar in the performing arts) and Opera 20.3.

The International Business Machines Chess Congress in Amsterdam attracted more than 300 participants, who were divided into groups. The grandmaster tournament -- the main event -- drew 16 players and was won by Lev Polugajevsky of the Soviet Union, who finished with 12 points of a possible 15.

HARTFORD, Sept. 20 -- For the second time this year, a Federal district court declared Connecticut's abortion statutes unconstitutional, saying they abridged the rights of a woman "to privacy and personal choice in matters of sex and family life."
BONN, Sept. 20 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt asked for a parliamentary vote of confidence today and made it plain that he intended to lose as a means of attaining a new Federal election.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 20 -- State, interstate and Federal officials laying the cornerstone of the $80-million PATH Journal Square Transportation Center here hailed the center today as practical evidence of their commitment to mass transportation.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 20 -- Two furious rainstorms, 20 minutes apart, saved the New York Yankees tonight from a defeat that would have all but snuffed out their flickering pennant hopes. They ended play with the Milwaukee Brewers leading, 2-0, and still at bat in the last half of the fourth inning.

TRENTON, Sept. 20 -- A study commission on fluoridation heard opponents this morning challenge the impartiality of the commission and ask its members to fight mandatory fluoride treatment of the state's potable water supply.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Federal Reserve Board, acting under a court restraining order, postponed today putting into effect two major new regulations affecting same-day payment of checks and calling for a large net reduction in bank reserve requirements.

In an atmosphere more conducive to pathos than a prizefight, Muhammad Ali was awarded a seventh-round knockout over Floyd Patterson at Madison Square Garden last night when the 37-year-old former two-time champion was adjudged unable to continue because of a severe cut over his left eye.

The New York-New Jersey Regional Championships, heirs to a tournament tradition stretching to the nineteen-thirties when the country's top stars sought national titles ensconced in comfortable rocking chairs at Asbury Park, have a new home this year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase Social Security taxes by about $6-billion to finance a vast array of new benefits for the nation's elderly and disabled.
The death knell sounded yesterday for Rafkind Co., a small brokerage house that voluntarily gave up the ghost because of what it called a decline in its business and a lack of profits.
About 200 faculty members at colleges and universities throughout the state hold bogus degrees from unaccredited institutions, the State Department of Education said yesterday.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Sept. 20 -- Bahamians celebrated with street dancing and singing today after giving Prime Minister Lynden O. Pindling a mandate to proceed with steps to make the Bahamas an independent nation.

Explosive devices concealed in envelopes and mailed from Amsterdam to Israeli officials were discovered yesterday in at least six cities abroad, and it was disclosed that they had also been found here.

The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the parent company of the nation's third-largest bank, has quietly asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to exempt its new investment management subsidiary from S.E.C. regulation.
Explosive devices concealed in envelopes have been mailed from Amsterdam to Israeli officials here and in at least six cities abroad.
Truly excellent plans for creating working waterfowl decoys are available from the Sneak Box Studios, 44 Main Street, P.O. Box 55, Concord, Mass. 01742.
A little more than four years ago Candace Jordan saw a newsreel and it changed her life. What's more, through her, it has changed a good many other lives, mostly children's.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 (AP) -- President Nixon signed into law today a $4.8-billion antipoverty bill that continues the controversial Legal Services for the poor program without the shift of control fought for in Congress.
The FMC Corporation announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Raygo, Inc., for 3 bout $20-million in FMC stock.

MAYWOOD, Sept. 20 -- This prospering, small (1.2 square miles) borough is a fairly typical Bergen County community. Neither its geology nor its history is extraordinary. Apparently Maywood has long been simply a nice place where nice people live.
NORTH BERGEN, N. J. Sept. 20 -- Senator George McGovern proposed today a $6.1-billion Federal program to aid the elderly.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 20 -- American planes have been mining the coastal rivers and canals of northern Quangtri Province, just below the demilitarized zone, to prevent the North Vietnamese from moving supplies across the border by boat, a senior United States Air Force officer has disclosed.

" Stepin Fetchit was a point of pride to the Negro people," said Lincoln Theodore Perry, who became Hollywood's first black star by playing the role of the shuffling Stepin Fetchit in movies of the 1920's and 1930's.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Romalie Hanover and Songcan scored impressive victories today in the third day of Grand Circuit harness racing, which produced six world records at the Delaware County Fairgrounds.
SANTA ROSA, Calif., Sept. 20 (AP) -- Richard Oakes, a leader in an Indian occupation of Alcatraz Island in San Francisco Bay, was shot to death today, the District Attorney reported.

The Chrysler Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had reached an agreement with the Universal Oil Products Company under which Universal will provide a manufacturing facility to make some catalytic converter equipment for 1975 model Chrysler cars.

YONKERS, Sept. 20 -- Howard Parker has been driving standardbreds since 1933, but it was not until tonight at Yonkers Raceway, where he drove Lou's Hope to a 3 1/2-length victory over Boddy Kaola in 2:05 3/5, that the 68-year-old horseman achieved his richest triumph.

The municipal hospital system's proposed capital budget of $81.8-million for the fiscal year 1973-74 came under public scrutiny yesterday. This was the first of half a dozen steps the budget must undergo before it emerges in final form, which will represent a substantially whittled-down version.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 20 (UPI) -- Dr. James C. Fletcher said yesterday he might resign as director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration after the final Apollo mission, scheduled for December.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he regarded his decision to supersede New York City's District Attorneys on the handling of corruption among the police, prosecutors and judges as the single most important act of his 14 years as Governor.
Texas Instruments, Inc., made its debut yesterday in the electronic calculator market with three products made entirely of American made components.
The bond market continued to back and fill yesterday with little evidence of any basic trend in interest rates.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 20 -- A United Nations panel, after examining hundreds of letters, has reportedly concluded that a "consistent pattern" of gross violations of human rights appears to exist in Greece.

TOKYO, Sept. 20 -- Premier Kim II Sung of North Korea was quoted here today as urging Japan to establish diplomatic relations with his Government on the same basis as those Tokyo maintains with South Korea.

The Metropolitan Museum's new exhibition, "Synagogues from Damascus to Newport," which opened yesterday and which consists of eight large models of historic synagogues accompanied by related Judaica from New York collections, will have strong emotional associations for the Jewish portion of its audience at this time of year.

A $628.5-million city school construction program for 1973-74, which would substantially eliminate all space shortages and end short-time schooling in three years, was proposed yesterday by the Board of Education's division of school planning and research.

The Mets, already eliminated from the pennant race, managed to delay for at least one more day the title-clinching by the Pittsburgh Pirates as Tom Seaver stopped them on five hits last night in a 4-1 victory at Shea Stadium.

" When I was 12 I used to have a recurrent nightmare," Garrick Ohlsson was saying. "I dreamed I was on the stage at Carnegie Hall in white tie and tails, before a packed house. I open the program and find to my horror that I'm supposed to play the Chopin Impromptu in G-flat major, and I don't know it at all."

Angry murmuring was heard yesterday morning in the Terrace Room of the Plaza, where the Magazine Publishers Association was beginning a three-day stay. It seems that two agency men on a panel discussing "Creativity -- the Critical Variable" chose to illustrate their remarks with television commercials.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- A misstatement by Vice President Agnew apparently led President Nixon today to order an investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the sale of 400 million bushels of wheat to the Soviet Union.

The proposal to put up a sports center in lower Manhattan's SoHo district, like the London plan to put a convention center in the Covent Garden district, has engendered unusually vehement opposition. In each case, an area of small-scale structures of healthy mixed uses, in which historic buildings have become a center of light industry and the arts, is threatened by incompatible commercial construction.
Truly excellent plans for creating working waterfowl decoys are available from the Sneak Box Studios, 44 Main Street, P.O. Box 55, Concord, Mass. 01742.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The New Republic has published what Ralph Nader calls a "rejection" of any inference that his position on no-fault automobile insurance was influenced by a $10,000 auto safety grant by the American Trial Lawyers Association.

BONN, Sept. 20 -- An official West German report, issued today on the killing of 11 members of the Israeli Olympic team in Munich on Sept. 5, absolved the police and political authorities of any blame in the tragedy.

The transportation problems of the cities and suburbs where most people live and work are frustrating as a traffic jam and inescapable as smog. Much as Americans love their private automobiles, and assiduous as highway engineers have been in building wider and better roads, it is now apparent that automobiles alone cannot solve those transportation problems. Subways, commuter railroads, express buses and new experimental forms of rapid transit are all necessary.

Democratic Assemblyman Vander L. Beatty's victory over the incumbent State Senator, Waldaba Stewart, in Bedford-Stuyvesant's 18th Senatorial District in Brooklyn, was also viewed as a victory for Representative Shirley Chisholm, who yesterday called the result a warning from voters to other black officials to recognize her leadership.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- An Interior Department official told Congress today that even with "reasonably severe" weather this winter, the nation would have "a tight but workable supply" of home-heating fuel oil.
Despite a late recovery, prices again finished lower in dull trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market.

Four surgical operations were canceled and all but emergency and obstetrics admissions were refused yesterday at the Staten Island Hospital after 130 employes were arrested while protesting delays in contract negotiations.

LONDON, Sept, 20 -- A private study urged Britain today to enact tougher laws against pornography. The study touched off a heated controversy involving lawyers, civil liberties groups, Members of Parliament and broadcasters.

LUXEMBOURG, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The European Common Market Commission intends in the next few weeks to take new antitrust action against the European packaging activities of the Continental Can Company, a commission lawyer disclosed in court here today.

Representative Les Aspin attempts to make election year capital out of developmental and financial problems of the Lockheed C-5 logistics transport. [Op-Ed Aug. 29.] He even asserts that two other contractors experiencing difficulties on two unrelated programs were somehow "encouraged" by Lockheed's having received a U.S. guarantee of up to $250 million in bank loans about a year ago.

TRENTON, Sept. 20 -- Mayor James Plosia of East Rutherford, named today at a hearing into alleged suburban corruption charged a few moments later that his implication had been engineered by Governor Cahill in retaliation for the Mayor's opposition to the new Meadowlands sports complex.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 20 -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase Social Security taxes by about $6-billion to finance a vast array of new benefits for the nation's elderly and disabled.

Two key intradivisional contests, the Jets at Baltimore and the Vikings at Detroit, will be seen here on television Sunday. The New York team, displaying Joe Namath in Baltimore for the first time, is favored by 2 points (Channel 4, 2 P.M.), while the Vikings are the choice over the Lions (Channel 2, 4 P.M.).
Foreign Minister Abba Eban said on arrival in New York last night that terrorism was a "new obstacle to peace" in the Middle East.

During her acting career, the successes scored by Audrey Meadows included a stint as the wife of Jackie Gleason in "The Honeymooners" television program and the co-star of Phil Silvers in the Broadway hit, "Top Banana.

The projects selected for joint American-Soviet scientific study in the United States encompass a broad spectrum of environmental problems that have plagued the North American Continent for many years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 21 -- The Arab bloc, with the support of a group of African nations, tonight mounted an effort to defer any discussion of the terrorism issue for this session of the General Assembly.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 21 (Agence FrancePresse) -- The bar of one of Hanoi's main hotels was the setting today for an unusual sight here: An American pilot casually drinking a beer.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21--Sargent Shriver, the Democratic nominee for Vice President, disclosed today that his net worth was $100,000, most of it in bank accounts and life insurance.

When they clinched the Eastern championship of the National League for the third straight year last night, the Pittsburgh Pirates took a giant stride toward something that nobody else in the league had achieved for half a century -- win two world titles in a row.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- For the outside world as well as Soviet citizens themselves, Lake Baikal near the Siberian city of Irkutsk has become synonymous with pollution problems and the fight to save the environment in this vast nation.

BOSTON, Sept. 21 -- The latest battle for first place in the American League's East opened here tonight with the Detroit Tigers mauling the Boston Red Sex, 10-3, and muscling their way into a virtual tie for the top.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -Spokesmen for the World Bank and International Monetary Fund said today that Rumania had applied for membership in the two institutions.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and over-the-counter market continued to drift lower yesterday in slow trading.

The Coastal States Gas Producing Company, which recently acquired about 47 per cent of the Colorado Interstate Corporation's common stock, announced plans yesterday to acquire the remainder. The original acquisition, achieved by a tender offer for $40 a share, totaled almost $83-million.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21 -- UFO, a sure-footed 8-year-old chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Fred Bauer of Weston, Conn., won his second straight amateurowner jumper class at the Eastern States horse show today.
TOMS RIVER, Sept. 21 -- A 20-year-old Toms River man testified today that a state trooper had burned three triangular brands on his buttocks with a hot wire during an interrogation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of new rules aimed at making clearer just what proposals dissenting stockholders may bring before annual stockholders' meetings.

Floyd Patterson, his left eye wrapped in gauze, returned to Madison Square Garden yesterday to pick up a $125,000 check for fighting Muhammad Ali Wednesday night and then headed-for his New Paltz, N. Y., home to resume training.
TRENTON, Friday, Sept. 22 -- Seven prisoners sawed through window bars and escaped from the Vroom Building for incorrigibles of Trenton State Prison last night.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -- Those of us who were brought up between the two World Wars were taught to be isolationists. In our grade-school history classes tremendous significance was given to the Monroe Doctrine. As sixth-graders we learned that Europeans were forever squabbling among themselves and their wars did not concern Americans.

Joe Trozzo, burly ItalianAmerican, is more or less the eyes of that small section of Amsterdam Avenue between 122d and 123d Streets where a Columbia University professor was stabbed to death in a robbery about 4 P.M. Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -The House passed and sent to the Senate today a foreign aid appropriations bill that would provide $4.2-billion in economic and military assistance during the fiscal year that began July 1. The total is nearly $1-billion less than the Administration had requested.
A 46-year-old Long Island man was killed and three others were injured when they were struck down last night by a car pulling out of a midtown Manhattan parking garage, the police reported.

Sitson Ma, a Chinese violinist and composer who has been living in this country for five years, appeared at Tully Hall Wednesday night. The program evenly balanced East and West by juxtaposing sonatas of Bach and Grieg with a collection of Mr. Ma's compositions.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 21 -- Vice President Agnew today labeled as "inaccurate" a report that the White House, in an attempt to avoid embarrassing him, ordered a fourth official investigation of American wheat sales to the Soviet Union.
A 16-year-old youth has been arrested and charged in the fatal stabbing of a Columbia University law professor, and the police issued a 13-state alarm yesterday for two brothers as accomplices.

A member of a State Select Committee on Child Abuse, investigating staff shortages in the city's Family Courts, said yesterday that the City Budget Director, David A. Grossman, would be subpoenaed to testify at a hearing next week regarding charges that the city is withholding $250,000 necessary for successful operation of the courts.

Alleged harassment by companies hired by landlords to relocate tenants was criticized in a hearing at City Hall yesterday by city, state and Federal elected officials, who declared that they intended to seek legislation to curb the companies.
SKOPLJE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 21 -- The United States and Romania tied 2-2 in their thirdround match in the chess olympics here yesterday.

While to many of you yesterday was merely Thursday of the third week of September, to the gang in the Terrace Room of the Plaza it was Circulation Day of Magazine Week in New York. A week, incidentally, of only three days.

Nan Nystrom, her blond hair flying, led the parade of mannequins down the long green runway set up in the street in front of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company branch bank in Madison Square Garden.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told a City Council committee yesterday that the Police Department was near the "bottom line" in precinct strength and would not be able to absorb the scheduled cutback of 1,200 more men in the next year without impairment of its functions.

PARIS, Sept. 21--The 160th formal session of the Vietnam peace conference was held here today, with no visible sign that intensive American diplomatic activity last week had changed the position of any delegation.

The nation's second-largest insurer, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, disclosed here yesterday that it would soon be selling insurance on homes and cars, thus making it the third leading life insurer to move into the business in two years.

Governor Rockefeller met with District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for two and a half hours yesterday in an effort to persuade the Manhattan prosecutor not to go to court to challenge the Governor's appointment of a special superseding prosecutor for cases of corruption among officials in the city.

On only its second night of the new season, Wednesday, the Metropolitan Opera had a problem of sorts. The work was Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," which was to have been conducted by Alain Lombard for the first time with the company.
Scheduled for unveiling on Oct. 24, a 43-foot sculpture called "Group of Four Trees" by the French artist, Jean Dubuffet, is being erected at Chase Manhattan Plaza.
LONDON, Sept. 21 -- Uganda soldiers pinned a man on the ground while a woman beat him with a rawhide whip -- 10, 20, 50 times until he screamed and writhed and the whip drew blood.

It could have been a case of "they laughed when I sat down to play the piano" -because there was no piano. Garrick Ohlsson, who gave a recital in Tully Hall last night, had picked out a Steinway a few days ago, and it was duly delivered.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange, a widely watched technical ingredient in the stock-market outlook, fell 15,012 shares in the month ended Sept. 15, the Big Board reported yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 21--In what was said to be an unparalleled act of Japanese corporate generosity, the Mitsubishi group of industries of Japan donated $1-million today to Harvard University to establish a chair in Japanese legal studies.

Hundreds of day-care workers, many of them women who sat down with children in the middle of the street, tied up midtown traffic on Madison Avenue for several hours yesterday as they took over President Nixon's campaign office near 52d Street to protest impending cutbacks in Federal funding.
Monetary expansion accelerated in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday, while the dollar showed signs of renewed strength in the international money markets.

The ICB Corporation, $162-million parent company of the International City Bank Trust Company in New Orleans, is actively negotiating to acquire a fire and casualty insurance company, Eads Poitevent, chairman of the company, said yesterday in an interview.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 21 -- Because of the way the other three contending teams are playing, the Yankees' ultimate exclusion from the pennant race is taking place in stages.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -The Nixon Administration ruled today that employes of all local governments, no matter how small, will be subject to the Pay Board's restrictions on wage and salary increases.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 21 -- Amihai Paglin, a key strategist of the Jewish underground in the closing years of British rule in Palestine, has been arrested here in connection with an attempt to form an anti-Arab terrorist campaign in Europe and America.

PATCHOGUE, L. I., Sept. 21--The State Commissioner of Human Rights announced today that a survey of more than 100,000 state employes had shown that workers over the age of 65 performed their jobs "about equal to and sometimes noticeably better than younger workers."

The police had to rescue several Philadelphia Councilmen yesterday after they were confronted in their chambers by 700 angry parents and students demanding an end to a three-week teachers' strike that has closed the city's 200 public schools.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 21 --Rutgers has scheduled Tampa, Tulane and Air Force as football opponents during the next four seasons. Scarlet recruiters have convinced some outstanding basketball players in recent secondary school competition to attend Rutgers. A $5-million bond issue was approved by Jersey voters last year for construction of a new Rutgers field house.

Former Representative Allard K. Lowenstein, twice defeated by Representative John J. Rooney for the Democratic nomination in Brooklyn's 14th Congressional District, said yesterday he would not ask the courts for another rerun.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -Representative Ken Hechler said today that Congressional staff workers and the coal industry were working secretly to "bury" any effective strip-mining control bill during this session of Congress.
DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- Senator George McGovern said tonight that he planned to drop off the campaign trail next week to prepare a series of "fireside chats" for national television.

William P. Howlett has been named chairman and chief executive officer of Ward Foods, Inc., a diversified food company with sales of $500million. He succeeds Charles W. Call Jr., who with five other directors resigned last week in what the company called "a policy difference between two factions."

All my friends at the beach this summer were, to a woman, reading women novelists, mostly Doris Lessing, Sylvia Plath, Joan Didion and Alix Shulman. One friend, a poet, complains of the book she is reading, "Well, this one lacks style. But then, perhaps we women have to think about getting ourselves, our struggles down on paper first, before we can attend to our art."

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Friday, Sept. 22 -- A tank trailer carrying liquid propane gas exploded in a fiery collision with a Greyhound bus and another truck on the New Jersey Turnpike near Interchange 8 last night.

YONKERS, Sept. 21--Diann Collins, a soundly beaten fifth in her most recent appearance, when traffic problems wrecked whatever chances she had in a stakes test at Syracuse, found smooth going in tonight's $43,018 New York Sires Stakes one-mile race for 3-year-old pacing fillies.

KINSLEY, Kan., Sept. 21 -There is a saying out here in the wheat country that growing grain is riskier than gambling in Las Vegas. Somebody once figured out that no fewer than 67 key factors ranging from weather to bug spray must mesh to produce a bountful harvest.
MOSCOW, Sept. 21 -- The United States and the Soviet Union agreed today to undertake 30 joint environmental projects to benefit and protect the cities, farms, rivers, lakes and air of both countries.

CLINTON, Sept. 21 -- Antiques dealers from Maine to Delaware crammed their station wagons this week with cigar store Indians and Art Deco clocks, weathervanes and whirligigs, Louis XVI consoles and Queen Anne tables and set out for the two shows that have, for years, proved to be the harbingers of the fall antiques season around here.

Mary Susino was in Peter Sergi's corner candy store at Court Street and tree-lined Loretto Place, Brooklyn, yesterday with her two little boys, Joseph and Santo -- "Sandy, except in school; we Americanized it."
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -Attacks on Federal food additive protection laws and policies were stepped up today at Senate hearings with a charge that a commonly used meat preservative and coloring agent has been linked to blood disease in humans and cancer in animals.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 21 -- Highly placed pro-commando sources said today that the recent shipment of Soviet weapons to the Arab guerrilla organization Al Fatah consisted only of conventional small arms and did not include terrorist devices or other advanced equipment.

The presidents of five leading Massachusetts institutions of higher learning have sent a letter to the Soviet Academy of Sciences to protest the imposition of exit fees on scholars who wish to emigrate.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Bethpage State Park's Black course, one of five in the golfing complex here, was opened to the public in 1936. But on this gray drizzly day, Mal Galletta Jr., the 31-yearold Glen Cove professional, tallied a 65, the lowest competitive round ever scored over the course.
Two Brooklyn youths were arrested yesterday and charged with having robbed and murdered a 27-year-old Brooklyn maintenance worker three days before his wedding last June.

Enrique Paguaga, who once met Dr. Wolfgang G. Friedmann at a debate on the Dominican revolution, stopped as he walked on Amsterdam Avenue at 123d Street yesterday to stare at the bloodstains on the pavement, left from the day before, when Dr. Friedmann was stabbed to death.

CAIRO, Sept. 21 -- The growing estrangement between the Sudan and her two Arab neighbors, Egypt and Libya, was carried a step further last night when the Sudanese President, Maj. Gen. Gaafar alNimeiry, prevented five Libyan Air Force planes from flying Libyan troops and arms to Uganda.
NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 21 (UPI) -- A tug and a 235foot barge, abandoned in heavy seas and gale-force winds, slammed into the Chesapeake Bay Bridge early today, forcing its closing for up to a month.

TRENTON -- What do you do with young dancers? Or rather, what do you do if you are running a ballet company and need to give them experience of dancing leading roles? American Ballet Theater has come up with a bright, new answer, and I saw the results of it earlier this week at the War Memorial Auditorium here.
Investors in mutual funds, who had been buying more and cashing in less, reversed themselves last month, the industry's trade organization reported yesterday.

In a new move to break the alleged corruption surrounding local zoning and land-use laws in New Jersey, Governor Cahill disclosed yesterday that he was seriously considering legislation that would require everyone doing business with a community to make a full public financial report.

The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, filed suits yesterday against four Manhattan travel agencies that he asserted had cheated hundreds of travelers who had paid for bargain-rate charter flights to and from Europe.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that an elctronic bugging device found last week on the office telephone of a Democratic party official had been put there after the June 17 break-in at the party's headquarters.
DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Strike Out erased the track record of his illustrious sire, Bret Hanover, and sped to impressive straight heat triumphs today in the $104,916 Little Brown Jug.

A 73-year-old man, taken to a hospital last night after five cars of an eight-car IRT subway train had passed over him, stepped down from a stretcher, brushed himself off, said he was unhurt and went home.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today it would issue a complaint charging Korvettes department stores and its NAC credit subsidiary with sending out unsolicited credit cards.

Aglimmer made things look easy at Belmont Park yesterday. The 3-year-old filly owned by John A. Bell took the lead at the start of the 1 1-16-mile turf event that served as the feature on the card, and held it all the way, to win by five lengths.
The chief corporate officers of three midtown movie houses were arrested yesterday on obscenity charges after warrants were issued by two Criminal Court judges who viewed films shown at the theaters.

VALLEY STREAM, L. I., Sept. 21 -- Private carters guarded by more than 100 Nassau County policemen started today to pick up about 400 tons of garbage and refuse from in front of homes here while striking municipal sanitationmen jeered.

When the New York City Opera's determinedly earthy and impious production of "Don Giovanni" opened last week in its Italian version, a bracing mixture of jeers and cheers greeted it. There had been, one understands, no dress rehearsal because of time pressures of the sort that seem to beset opera more than any other art form.

The greatest artists are the most exacting and certainly Balasaraswati, one of India's very greatest dancers, demanded no less of herself than she did of her audience and her musicians in her ex traordinary concert Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

HARTFORD, Sept. 21 -- Connecticut filed notice of appeal today directly to the United States Supreme Court against a Federal court ruling here yesterday that the state's new abortion law was unconstitutional.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 21 -Truckloads of heavily armed Uganda troops reportedly raced about the capital city of Kampala today, apparently alarmed by the belief that some new treachery was being hatched against President Idi Amin.
Officials of General Foods Corporation and People United to Save Humanity reached an agreement yesterday to improve the economic condition of blacks and other minority groups.

A gang of seven persons linked to at least 20 midtown Manhattan robberies this summer was seized yesterday when one of the alleged gang members was picked up a a hospital after he accidentally shot himself in the hand during a holdup, the police said.

With the very first piece of the first concert of the subscription season of the New York Philharmonic, last night in Philharmonic Hall, Pierre Boulez demonstrated how to make a 30-minute symphony last 20 minutes.
LONDON, Sept. 21--Britain tonight ordered the end of the controversial policy of interning suspected terrorists in Northern Ireland without trial.

AREA A -- Strong northeastern winds producing high seas effectively stopped fishing in this area for the last three days, but fishermen are taking heart at weather bureau predictions that the winds will blow out sometime tonight.

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 21 -- UFO, a sure-footed 8-year-old chestnut gelding owned and ridden by Fred Bauer of Weston, Conn., won his second straight amateurowner jumper class at the Eastern States horse show today.

New York and Bronx Democratic county committee members from the 20th Congressional District will meet Oct. 1 at the Commodore Hotel to name a candidate to replace Representative William F. Ryan, who died Sunday night.
Faced with the beauty of seeming numerical precision, it is once again the season to spread the reminder that political polls are not elections.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 21 -- An agreement signed this week provides for extensive Soviet involvement in the economy of India.

A look at the motion-picture scene for the fall and winter seasons suggests the shape if not the symmetry of an encyclopedia running from Aabenraa (a town in Denmark) to Zygohyllaceae (a family of herbs).

To the Editor: Dr. Seymour C. Post (letter Sept. 11) labors to revive those tired bickerings of yesteryear when each specialist found it profitable to disparage competing approaches to mental illness. Psychiatrists, with more conviction than proof, insisted that a degree in medicine was essential to the rendering of any form of therapy.
CHICAGO, Sept. 21 -- The motor launch cruised down the placid Monongahela River the other night, as the neon lights on the surrounding hills reflected in the dark water.
The Environmental Planning Lobby, a coalition of more than 50 organizations in the state, issued yesterday the first comprehensive environmental voting rating for state legislators.
In the menu below, the dish marked with an asterisk is followed by a recipe.

ZURICH, Sept. 21 -- Last Monday the gold market went out of control. The price of gold plummeted 8 per cent from $66 to $61.25 an ounce, a considerable drop for any commodity, let alone a metal that still represents some of the wealth of nations.

The Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday inaugurated its third series devoted to the work of new American filmmakers with the New York premiere of "Rough Magic," a first feature by Timothy Knox, a New Englander in his early 30's who now teaches English at the Dalton School here.
Three Queens men were arrested yesterday after undercover policemen allegedly purchased a total of 24 ounces of "high-quality" cocaine from them in recent weeks.

Stuart Sobel, the personnel executive in the city's Housing and Development Administration who reviewed applicants for the controversial emergencyemployment program, has resigned following questioning by the city's Commissioner of Investigation, Robert K. Ruskin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -The Senate passed a tough antihijacking bill today that provides for a new airport security police force, screening of all airline passengers and the option of imposing the death penalty for skyjackers.

Ryder Truck Rental, a subsidiary of the Ryder System, Inc., announced yesterday that it had purchased about $35million worth of trucks. It said 5,500 vehicles had been purchased from the International Harvester Company, General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -The Justice Department told Congress today that subpoenaing of newsmen by the Government was sharply reduced in the last two years, and that the Nixon Administration would therefore oppose as unnecessary proposed laws that would shield journalists from subpoenas.
Howard J. Samuels paraded a new "horse" out of his computer barn yesterday, a late starter being touted as the possible big winner of the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation's electronic sweepstakes.

The late Edith Gregor Halpert, besides being one of the most successful dealers of her generation in promoting the work of living American artists, was also one of the first to take a serious interest in American folk art. Beginning in the 1920's, when the productions of such artists were generally regarded as esthetically insignificant curiosities, Mrs. Halpert was assiduous in searching out and acquiring important works in native folk art.

Hitachi Metals, Ltd., Japan's leading specialty steels producer, announced yesterday that it was "negotiating with potential United States partners" for a joint manufacturing venture to produce metals products in this country.

State Controller Arthur Levitt invoked his rarely used subpoena powers yesterday and ordered Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, to bring to his office next week the records he said the Transit Authority had withheld from state auditors.
An agreement to sell the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel at 106 Central Park South between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue has been reached. The purchase price has not been disclosed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- When Richard Nixon ran for the Presidency four years ago, he benefited from the political equivalent of the statute of limitations.

CHATTANOOGA, Sept. 21 (AP) -- Vice President Agnew accused Senator George McGovern tonight of "parroting the propaganda of the North Vietnamese" and in helping to destroy "the morale of thousands of Americans who are not in possession of the facts" about Communist brutality in Indochina.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (AP) -- The more money a married couple makes and the more education they have, the greater the chances of the marriage surviving, the Census Bureau reported today.

Wrecking crews returned to Fifth Avenue yesterday to the job of tearing down two turn-of-the-century townhouses opposite the Metropolitan Museum of Art after Justice Wilfred A. Waltemade of the State Supreme Court angrily dismissed a court restraining order.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The United States is going to carry the fight against terrorism and anarchy in world communications to the United Nations in the next couple of weeks and try to make this a major test, not only of the world organization but of the "basic principles" signed by President Nixon and Chairman Brezhnev of the Soviet Union four months ago.

A group of parents blocked the way of two regularly licensed teachers who had been assigned to replace two substitute teachers at a West Side school yesterday as a new dispute over teacher assignments erupted in Manhattan's Community School District 3.
An agreement to sell the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel at 106 Central Park South between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue has been reached, the purchase price has not been disclosed.
Most duplicate enthusiasts agree that a long team match is the best test of skill. This accounts in part for the steadily increasing popularity of competitions organized in this form.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Sept. 21 -- The chief of the Special Branch of the Amsterdam police said today that he was "not optimistic" on the immediate chances of tracing the terrorists who mailed at least 35 letter-bombs from here to Israeli diplomats and other officials in several countries.
The stock market took another dip yesterday as Wall Street added a new worry to its long list of old worries.

Paula Fox's previous novel, "Desperate Characters," was a faultlessly crafted work and one that opened a new angle of vision on a familiar and much exploited scene. It extended the definition of urban poverty in a way that belied the statistics of increasing affluence among the middle class and investigated areas of urban blight to which sociologists would never give a second glance.

The Jewish State Theater of Bucharest is a firmly established, honored company that performs plays by, among others, Gorky, Moliere, Schiller, Gogol and Ibsen. For its current American tour, it has chosen to present S. Ansky's somber "The Dybbuk," and, in direct contrast, a musical revue called "The Pearl Necklace," which opened yesterday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -Less than seven weeks before the election, the Republicans have moved to counter the expanding television campaign of Senator George McGovern.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -The National Geodetic Survey has compiled a map showing the trends of vertical movement of the earth's crust throughout the 48 contiguous states.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 21 -The special agent in charge of the Los Angeles office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who has been under fire since May, has been allowed to retire effective next week, it was announced today.

David R. Clare has been elected chairman of the Johnson Johnson Domestic Operating Company, Johnson Johnson, Ltd., of Great Britain and the newly-formed Johnson Johnson Baby Products Company, all units of Johnson and Johnson. In addition, the Johnson Johnson Dental Products Company also reports to Mr. Clare.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Robert Carmichael of Australia upset Arthur Ashe of Miami, 6-3, 4-6, 6-2, today in third-round play of the $60,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament. Ashe was seeded second.

MOSCOW, Sept. 21 (AP) -Vic Hadfield, star left wing for the New York Rangers, and two other players withdrew from Team Canada today on the eve of its resumption of the eightgame hockey series with the Soviet national team.

To the Editor: A responsible debate on Senator McGovern's proposal to cut defense spending by $10 billion in each of three years should revolve around the issue of whether the United States could indeed keep modernizing its weaponry and adequately defend the United States for $50 billion, instead of $80billion now being spent.
More letters rigged with explosive devices and addressed to Israeli diplomats were found in several cities around the world yesterday.
August operations brought United Air Lines, a subsidiary of UAL, Inc., into the black by $9,617,000 for the first eight months, the parent company announced yesterday.
To the Editor: Mayor Lindsay's "crackdown" on pornography (and your Sept. 5 editorial support of the crackdown) are totally ill-conceived, for at least four reasons:
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 22 -- For the first time since March, 1965, a week has passed without American combat deaths in Indochina, the United States command reported yesterday.
A few months ago, the American Crafts Council Gallery held the first of its regional shows -- the work of Southwestern craftsmen. Now it is the turn of the Northeast. And there are differences.

Miss Helen Schumer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Schumer of Forest Hills, Queens, was married here yesterday afternoon to Ronald Michael Weiss, son of Morton N. Weiss of East Hills, L. I., and the late Mrs. Bette Eckman. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony in Temple Israel.

The 130 employes at Staten Island Hospital who had been arrested Wednesday returned to their jobs yesterday morning, although the month-old negotiations for the nonprofit community institution's first union contract remained at a standstill.

SWEDESBORO, Sept. 21 -"It looks dilapidated on the outside," Joseph Dibella said apologetically as he looked at the cinder-block shed that houses migrant workers on his farm on Davidson Road here. "But it's all right inside."

UNION CITY, Sept. 21 -- A member of the Board of Education here charged today that high school seniors and juniors and their teachers were forced to attend a rally held yesterday in Schuetzen Park at which George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nominee, appeared.
FORT ORD, Calif., Sept. 21 -- The court-martial of Pvt. Billy Dean Smith, the young black draftee accused of killing two white Army officers in Vietnam, went into an unexpected recess here today.

To the Editor: Although I have spent many summers, including this one, in Aroostook County, Me., I fail to recognize the heart-rending problem of "child labor" in the potato fields [Cassandra Stockburger's Op-Ed article, Sept. 4] based on the facts as I know them. The cartoon with the article, straight out of Dickens, left me very dry-eyed indeed.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -The House Public Works Committee voted today to continue to prohibit the use of Federal highway money to build mass transit systems.

A registered secondary offering of 600,000 common shares of Smith Kline French Laboratories at $58.50 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Smith Barney Co. The selling shareholder is the estate of Francis Boyer, former chairman of the board of S.K.F.
PARIS, Sept. 21--President Pompidou used his semiannual press conference today to make a dramatic defense of the criticisms that have been piling up against his Government.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -A House subcommittee reported today that "foot-dragging by the Federal bureaucracy" had impeded the effective operation of the Freedom of Information Act.

Pro basketball's owners "can't live with many of these new amendments" to a merger bill in the Senate, claimed Walter Kennedy in Houston yesterday. Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, is especially unhappy about gate-receipt sharing with visiting teams, which the N.B.A. has never had.
In the eternal quest for turnaround situations, much of Wall Street occasionally will focus on a single stock or a single industry all at once.

A registered secondary offering of 600,000 common shares of Smith Kline French Laboratories at $58.50 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group headed by Smith Barney Co. The selling shareholder is the estate of Francis Boyer former chairman of the board of S.K.F. The company's stock closed at 58 1/2, down 7/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Platinum and palladium futures yesterday rose sharply, the latter by the daily limit.

TOKYO, Sept. 21 -- Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan is scheduled to fly to Peking on Monday to extend diplomatic recognition to Communist China in Japan's most farreaching international initiative since the end of World War II.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -President Nixon asked Congress today to add 16 areas, comprising 3.5 million acres, to the nation's wilderness system.

Early reports out of Baltimore say that Norm Bulaich is slightly injured again, but Paul Crane, the New York Jets' linebacker, is one of those hoping the Colts' running back is fit for Sunday's game in Memorial Stadium.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 21 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu has rejected the latest Communist proposal for a three-part coalition Govern ment in South Vietnam, saying: "Any political settlement in South Vietnam should be determined by the South Vietnamese people themselves without foreign interference."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- A panel of advisers to Senator George McGovern called today for a new "philosophical framework" for national security policy and accused President Nixon of overextending Ameriica abroad and shortchanging its citizens at home.

ROBINSON, Ill., Sept. 21 (AP) -- Grier Jones birdied five holes in a row en route to a 66 and the lead today in the rain-soaked first-round of the $100,000 Robinson Fall Golf Classic. Jones posted his fiveunder-par score on the 6,556yard Crawford Country Club course.
Still displaying a lack of any overarching trend, the various segments of the bond market pursued their own courses again yesterday. On balance, interest rates tended to rise.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -An Israeli source reported today that Israel was advising friendly governments that she would refuse to participate in further diplomatic negotiations for a Middle East peace settlement until all Arab terrorism was eradicated.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today it would issue a complaint charging Korvettes department stores and its NAC credit subsidiary with sending out unsolicited credit cards.
The Pittsburgh Pirates won their third straight National League Eastern Division championship at Shea Stadium last night when Steve Blass pitched a seven-hitter to defeat the Mets, 6-2.
New York's 19th municipal hospital, the new Gouverneur, was formally opened yesterday in a joyful polyglot dedication ceremony reflecting the institution's constituency.

DETROIT, Sept. 21 -- The Ford Motor Company today recalled 900,000 of its 1972 cars and trucks and said that it would inspect 190,000 of the new 1973 models, seeking a defect that could cause steering to fail.
BOSTON, Sept. 21 (UPI) -Massachusetts relaxed its ban on shellfish today allowing consumers to buy available seafood from merchants.
Postal inspectors imposed rigid surveillance yesterday over mail addressed to Israeli diplomats here, looking for explosive devices similar to three tiny bombs discovered Tuesday night.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -Common Cause said today that it would seek to learn the position of every Senate and House candidate on Congressionalreform issues.

The first annual Reinhold Neibuhr award was presented to the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh at the Union Theological Seminary here. Father Hesburgh, president of the University of Notre Dame and chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, said at the award ceremony: "America is the greatest melting pot in the world but there is one area where this melting pot has simply failed to function -and that is the area of color."

Senator George McGovern told the leaders of 25 major national Jewish organizations yesterday that he would vote in favor of a plan to withhold "most favored nation" trading status from the Soviet Union until it abolished its "slave tax" on Soviet Jewish emigrants and ceased its "arming of Arab terrorists."
NEWARK, Sept. 22 -- The National Urban League announced here today the start of a program to recruit and aid black and Spanish-speaking people to join law enforcement agencies.

RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., Sept. 22--President Nixon, touring south Texas before large and friendly crowds, attacked today what he called "permissive" judges whose leniency left a "weak link" in the country's efforts to rid the streets of pushers of hard drugs.

The Columbia Broadcasting System, stanchly retaining faith in situation comedy, has inserted three new half-hours into its schedule for Sunday evening. There's "Anna and the King" at 7:30, "M A S H" at 8 and "The Sandy Duncan Show" at 8:30. And they lead into "The New Dick Van Dyke Show," which wasn't particularly new even when it began last season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -United States and Israeli officials agreed today that priority should be given to combating international terrorism although "options must be kept open" for peace negotiations in the Middle East.

" Now this is what I call workmanship. There is nothing on earth more exquisite than a bonny book, with well-placed columns of rich black writing in beautiful borders, and illuminated pictures cunningly inset. But nowadays, instead of looking at books, people read them. A book might as well be one of those orders for bacon and bran that you are scribbling." -- The Earl of Warwick in George Bernard Shaw's "St. Joan."

OMAHA, Neb., Sept. 22 -- An inflated rubber donkey fell over with a loud thud just as Senator George McGovern's wife, Eleanor, began quoting her husband's "Come home, America" speech in the party room of a bowling alley here the other night.

OSLO, Norway, Sept. 22 -- On the eve of the referendum that will decide whether Norway joins the European Economic Community, the voters are bitterly divided and a mood of tense uncertainty has settled over this far north country of fjords and forests.

In the aftermath of the meeting Thursday between Governor Rockefeller and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan, city officials waited yesterday to see how, if at all, the Governor's special superseding prosecutor to fight corruption would be affected by their talk.

Chris Farasopoulos is glad to be the National Football League's leading punt return specialist, but he realizes it could be a short-lived honor after the New York Jets take on the Colts tomorrow at Baltimore's Memorial Stadium (WNBC-TV Channel 4, 2:05 P.M.)

TRENTON, Sept. 22 -- Two of seven inmates who escaped last night from a maximum security unit for incorrigible prison inmates at the Trenton State Psychiatric Hospital were recaptured this afternoon in a tenement here.

BOSTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- United States District Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. said yesterday that newspaper publication of the criminal records of some of 89 persons indicted last week on gambling charges was "a course of conduct which no honorable citizen could doubt was prejudicial."

A Warsaw dentist, interned in the World War II concentration camp at Maidanek, Poland, from January, 1943, to April, 1944, said at a Federal hearing yesterday that she saw Hermine Braunsteiner, a former prison guard, help select Jewish women to be sent to gas chambers in August, 1943.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon stood on the windswept aerospace base in Northern California, encircled by reporters and obviously eager to get back to the mother ship. Yards away loomed the awesome Presidential jet -- a Boeing 707, silver and pale blue, with "United States of America" leaping out in black capital letters the length of its fuselage.
Randy Johnson will be the quarterback for the New York Giants tomorrow against the Dallas Cowboys at Yankee Stadium, Coach Alex Webster finally declared yesterday.

NORWALK, Conn., Sept. 22--Russell L. Hoyt's 43-foot sloop, Destination, and J. M. Gore Friedrichs's 30-foot sloop, Skipjack, were the International Offshore Rule Division winners on Long Island Sound last night on the first leg of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual cruise.

FLORENCE, Italy -- Tourists, visitors or observers of Czechoslovakia all agree in one respect: of all Eastern European countries, the deepest depression, frustration and feeling of hopelessness prevails in Czechoslovakia.

CORONADO, Calif., Sept. 22 -- "I've never seen people sock it away like this," said John J. Goodwin, executive vice president of the Gibraltar Savings and Loan Association. "There's no sign yet of any fall off in savings flow."

The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday that it had signed a letter of intent under which Pasco, Inc., would acquire its former Sinclair Oil Corporation gasoline marketing properties in 14 Rocky Mountain and midcontinent states for about $160-million, plus payment for working capital.

The plays performed by Belgium's Theater Laboratoire Vicinal have no message, characters or plot. It is a theater of action. The basic content is actors and props. The work is not propelled by logic but by inspiration.

Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens has asked the Board of Higher Education to investigate a silent memorial held for the Arab terrorists killed in Munich. The memorial took place Sept. 8 during an orientation meeting of about 1,000 incoming Manhattan Community College freshmen.

Twelve years ago, a distinguished New York judge who once served as an assistant district attorney under Thomas E. Dewey and Frank S. Hogan gave a speech in Chicago about controlling the abuses found in criminal law enforcement.

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 22 (AP) -- The Delaware Hudson Railroad Company is asking municipal governments and school districts throughout the state to allow the railroad to delay $1.7-million in 1973 tax payments that are due before December.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -The Food and Drug Administration put under strict control today the germ killer hexachlorophene. The germicide, which is commonly used in the home, has been linked to the deaths of 39 French babies this year.

Despite a three-run homer by Bill Sudakis in his first start as catcher for New York and one-hit relief pitching for almost five innings by Tug McGraw last night, the Mets lost in 11 innings to the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-4, at Shea Stadium.
Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, announced yesterday a new concentrated attempt to collect old newspapers separately so they can be recycled.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -The United States, 15 months after its original deadline, finally notified the World Bank today that it would make its agreed-upon contribution of $320-million a year for three years to the International Development Association, the bank's "easy loan" subsidiary.
MANILA, Saturday, Sept, 23 -- Martial law was imposed throughout the Philippines at 2 A.M. today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -The Food and Drug Administration put under strict control today the germ killer hexachlorophene. The germicide, which is commonly used in the home, has been linked to the deaths of 39 French babies this year.

With the holding of a special primary election ruled out by the restrictive provisions of state law, Democratic committee members from Manhattan and the Bronx will convene Oct. 1 to select a replacement for the late Representative William F. Ryan. The high standard Mr. Ryan set in his twelve years in Congress puts an especially heavy responsibility on those who must now act for his constituency in making that choice.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market were mixed yesterday in continued dull trading.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- A House subcommittee concluded hearings today on a bill that would make legal an El Paso Natural Gas Company acquisition whose divestiture the Supreme Court has ordered.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 22 (AP)--Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts discussed the Presidential campaign with Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama tonight and said afterward that Mr. Wallace's support "would be meaningful to any candidate."

A dispute over the number of deck officers to be assigned to each of eight new high-speed containerships halted nationwide operations of Sea-Land Service, Inc., yesterday. Masters of SeaLand vessels in United States ports, acting on instructions of their union, the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, stopped work yesterday morning on 12 ships in seven ports.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The Agriculture Department announced today after the close of the commodity markets that it was eliminating the export subsidy on wheat.

Army opened its 1957 football season by trouncing Nebraska, 42-0. That was standard operating procedure for the cadets, who won 16 opening games in the 18 years Earl Blaik was coach (1941-1958): Blaik's biggest problem for an opener in those days was to get his cadets concerned about it.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., operator of 67 department stores throughout the country, reported yesterday fourthquarter earnings of $6,640,000 or 61 cents a share. A year earlier, the company earned $3,667,000, or 33 cents a share.

TOMS RIVER, Sept. 22 -- The principal witness against two state troopers accused of beating and branding him during an interrogation today had his bared buttocks examined by the trial jury in the courtroom here.

TROMSO, Norway, Sept. 22 -- The mud - stained infantry, the ships and the planes were redeploying today after the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's exercise Strong Express, the biggest military extravaganza this bleak region has ever seen.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., Sept 22 -- Jimmy Wright, who led from start to finish, won the Marlboro New York State Professional Golfers' Association championship today by the record margin of 11 strokes.
NEWARK, Sept. 22 -- Passengers hurried off the commuter trains onto platforms at Penn Station here today and walked through what Governor Cahill described as "a hall of horrors."

If Buddy Noro had a problem in the decorating of his Greenwich Village home, it was not where to start, but when to stop.

Hexachlorophene, first patented in 1941 and commonly used in hospital nurseries to prevent skin infections, has been an ingredient in about $250-million worth of cosmetics in recent years. Among the products in which it is used are hygienic sprays, aerosol deodorants, toothpastes and soaps.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -United States and Israeli officials agreed today that priority should be given to combating international terrorism although "options must be kept open" for peace negotiations in the Middle East.

The Police Department's traffic division unit in Queens, created for the 1939 World's Fair, is closing Monday and its 125 men will be transferred to patrol work. It is the last of the department's traffic units outside of Manhattan.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 22 -- As in the tune, "September Song," the days are dwindling down for the Yankees in the pennant race they once were in. Another day dwindled away tonight as Cleveland won, 4-1, behind the plucky pitching of Gaylord Perry.
The pennant race is over in the National League's Western Division.

LONDON -- Shortly before 4:30 A.M. on Aug. 9, 1971, hundreds of British soldiers swarmed into Roman Catholic districts of Northern Ireland and began seizing and interning suspected terrorists of the outlawed Irish Republican Army. Finance ministers and central bank governors of 123 nations, in Washington for the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund, now face their most serious challenge and opportunity in a quarter century.

SKI, Norway, Sept. 24 -- Bent Vale threw open the doors of the grammar school gymnasium promptly at 4 P.M. today and led inside more than 50 citizens of this semirural town 20 miles southeast of Oslo who were waiting, solemn-faced and silent, in the pale autumn sunshine.
