The Yankees could be eliminated from the Eastern Division title race as early as Thursday night. Then again, if they win all seven of their remaining games, they would fail to win the title only if Boston won at least six of its nine games, Detroit six of eight or Baltimore all seven of its games.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- Governor Cahill ordered stepped-up security precautions today at the Vroom Building of the Trenton State Prison as officials pressed a nationwide manhunt for four of seven convicts who escaped last week.

Operations of the Beatrice Foods Company in the three and six months ended Aug. 31 resulted in record sales and earnings, for the 82nd consecutive quarter, the diversified food and non-food producer reported yesterday from its Chicago headquarters.

Governor Rockefeller and Edward J. Logue, president of the State Urban Development Corporation, have apparently decided to defer the U.D.C.'s building plans in Westchester County for four months to give the nine towns involved a chance to come up with multi-family housing plans of their own.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today the request of the PBW Stock Exchange for a full evidentiary hearing on the commission's proposal banning "institutional membership" on stock exchanges.
DAYTON, Ohio, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. George McGovern honored a picket line at a television station today, canceling an appearance for a 90-minute talk show.
OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Sept. 26 -- Norwegians voted decisively in two-day referendum to reject membership in the European Economic Community.

Patricia Tregellas, an accordionist who has been in the pit orchestras of such hit musicals as "Fiddler on the Roof" and "Cabaret", is also a firm believer in the concert potential of her instrument. Unfortunately, she did not make a good case for it at her Carnegie Recital Hall program late Sunday afternoon.

JACKSON, Wyo., Sept. 24 -- Public use of national parks in the United States and around the world is going to have to be rigorously "rationed'' in the years ahead, parks officials believe, if the parks themselves are not to be destroyed.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Jan Stenerud kicked a 22-yard field goal with less than two minutes to play to lift the two-touchdown favorite, Kansas City, to a 20-17 victory over the New Orleans Saints tonight in a nationally televised National Football League game.
LONDON, Sept. 25, (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Heath warned executives of the world's airlines today they must bring down fares or lose their customers to the cheap-flight charter companies.

Sudden as was the Senate Finance Committee's decision to muscle in on private pension reform, it is no surprise at all to find it playing a similarly destructive role in seeking to torpedo Congressional action on welfare reform.

A strike that would have darkened New York's theatrical district was averted yesterday morning when union musicians reached agreement with the League of New York Theaters on a new three-year contract.

MANILA, Sept. 25 -- The Government said today that 49 Filipinos -- among them six members of Congress, two provincial governors and several newsmen -- were being detained under the state of martial law imposed over the weekend.

In an internal dispute that threatens the structure of the pro basketball draft and the four-year college rule, the Atlanta Hawks and Julius Erving filed a $2-million antitrust suit yesterday against the National Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Pierre-Paul Schweitzer, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, received an ovation today when he rose to address the joint annual meeting of the fund and the World Bank.

A badly cut and bruised 10-foot-long pygmy sperm whale and her newborn calf, found washed ashore yesterday morning at a beach in Far Rockaway, Queens, were swaddled in wet blankets and rushed to the New York Aquarium at Coney Island.

LYNDHURST, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Two of New Jersey's state agencies today approved the Cahill administration's still-controversial plans to construct a vast sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands, provided the ecological integrity of the site is safeguarded.
The stock market yesterday resumed its recent downward pattern following Friday's mediocre advance. Prices closed sharply lower in slow trading.
Art and politics -- traditionally the oil and water on the intellectual seascape -- are being drawn this year into a real mix by the emotional realities of the Presidential campaign.

PEKING, Sept. 25 -- Premier Kakuei Tanaka expressed Japan's regret and repentance today for past aggression against China and joined Premier Chou En-lai in predicting complete agreement in their talks here to normalize long-strained relations.

The legal battle between William F. Buckley Jr. and Gore Vidal, arising out of their public exchange of affronts, apparently came to an end yesterday with an announcement by Mr. Buckley of two acts: the dropping of his suit against Mr. Vidal and an out-of-court settlement of $115,000 with Esquire magazine.

LYNDHURST, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Two of New Jersey's state agencies today approved the Cahill administration's still-controversial plans to construct a vast sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands, provided the ecological integrity of the site is safeguarded.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 25 -- Mrs. Andrew Sage of Piping Rock, rallying with a oneunder-par 36 after a four-over 41, posted a winning 77 in the qualifying round of the Women's Long Island match-play golf championship today at Fresh Meadow Country Club.

After an absence of little more than four months, the Knicks will be back in Madison Square Garden tonight. Coach Red Holzman's club, which lost in the National Basketball Association championship round last season to the Los Angeles Lakers, will oppose the Buffalo Braves in the second game of a preseason double-header.

A Brooklyn junior high school that has been involved in a bitter zoning controversy was ordered closed yesterday morning, about an hour before classes were to start, to avert a confrontation between parents from the East Flatbush and Brownsville sections.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP) -- A bystander's home movies may help reveal why a rebuilt jet fighter plane faltered on take-off yesterday and plunged into a crowded ice cream parlor here, Federal investigators said today. The death toll was 22.

Representative Ryan's untimely death on Sept. 17 deprives the Democratic left of one of its most capable and articulate spokesmen. For twelve years in the House of Representatives he embodied the best in American politics. Courageous and dedicated, he never compromised his principles, even when faced by illness and death.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to give President Nixon unlimited authority to cut whatever Government programs he chooses between now and next June 30 to keep total Government spending for the fiscal year at no more than $250-billion.

Howard Samuels, president of New York's Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yesterday that the National Football League, in its alleged ban of OTB advertising during New York Giant and Jet football games, was "hypocritical, if not downright silly."

PEKING, Sept. 25 -- Premier Kakuei Tanaka expressed Japan's regret and repentance today for past aggression against China and joined Premier Chou En-lai in predicting complete agreement in their talks here to normalize long-strained relations.
A bus driver, a carpenter, a house painter, a real-estate salesman and a male nurse were enjoying reunions with their families yesterday after three months in a Texas jail.

Sedco, Inc., yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed public offering of 500,000 shares of common stock. The shares, to be offered through an underwriting group headed by Goldman Sachs, are being sold to assist in the financing of four semi-submersible drilling units.

TOKYO, Sept. 25 -- The Speaker of the Philippine House of Representatives, Cornelio T. Villereal, asserted here today that President Ferdinand E. Marcos had decided to declare martial law long before it was announced as having gone into effect.

The recent hijacking by Croatian terrorists must be viewed against the background of Belgrade's decision last December to eliminate the Croatian Communist party and government leaders. That purge gave a new impetus to the previously sidelined Croatian political extremists.

Le Pavillon, at its peak the finest French restaurant in the United States has closed its doors. "Truly, the era of the grand luxe restaurant in New York is over," Stuart Levin, the manager and one of the owners, said yesterday.
Dead and dying herring gulls near the town of Manchester on Massachusetts' north shore earlier this month provided the first warning to state officials that a so-called "red tide" invasion had begun.

Highlighted by a rematch of last year's National Collegiate Eastern regional finalists -- Florida State and North Carolina -- the 1972-73 Madison Square Garden intercollegiate basketball program will offer 48 colleges in two triple-headers, 15 regular season double-headers, and an expanded Eastern College Athletic Conference Holiday Festival.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Nixon pledged to the world's finance ministers today that the United States would be "in the forefront" of efforts to achieve a "thoroughgoing reform of the international monetary system" and said Secretary of the TreasuryGeorge P. Shultz would make detailed proposals later this week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Nixon today nominated Kevin Thomas Duffy, regional administrator of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and Robert J. Ward, a New York lawyer, to be Federal district judges for the Southern District of New York.

A former assistant vice president and branch manager of the First National City Bank was indicted yesterday on charges of embezzling more than $1-million and falsifying bank records to conceal the scheme.

BOSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -With the red tide no longer in evidence off the Massachusetts coast, the Department of Public Health today opened specific sections of southeastern Massachusetts to the harvesting of hard-shell clams.
Sentencing in the city's courts has fallen into confusion, with judges by their own account regularly handing out sentences they consider either too lenient or too harsh.
The City Center Joffrey Ballet will present Jerome Robbins's "Interplay" in addition to three announced new productions during its season at the City Center from Oct. 4 through Nov. 12.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The House approved and sent to the White House today an interim United States - Soviet agreement to freeze a major part of their offensive nuclear arsenals for five years.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of New York City sharply criticized yesterday a suggestion of Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy that the department consider recruiting by neighborhood and assigning policemen by race.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A bill that would create the Gateway National Urban Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor cleared the House Rules Committee today and was sent to the House floor for a fight over whether housing should be constructed on part of what is now Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.
EAST CHICAGO, Ind., Sept. 25 (AP) -- East Chicago policemen said today that "all the evidence" points to suicide in the shooting death of City Controller George Lamb at his home.

Anthony L. DiLorenzo, the 44-year-old reputed Mafia leader who disappeared on July 26 while on an unescorted furlough from Federal prison to his dentist on Long Island, was indicted yesterday on charges of escape from Federal custody.

New York's fall season, which in recent years has been accused of having all the glamour of a soggy potato chip, apparently is going to be livelier this year. Socially, at least, the recession may be over.
In the dim light, Joe Namath swirled the ice in his glass. He was drinking vodka on the rocks with a splash of kahlua, a Black Russian, and he was grinning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- South Africa's Finance Minister disclosed today that his country had been selling about two-thirds of its newly mined gold on the free market since last spring, putting the rest into its monetary reserves.

The Vietnam war, which was supposed to be Senator George McGovern's strong suit politically, is actually working to the advantage of President Nixon in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where much of the antiwar movement has been centered, according to a voter survey released yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- Success in human organ transplantation has reached a plateau from which it can be expected to advance only with considerable effort, a major figure in that field told an international congress here today.
Steel production for the week ended Sept. 23 edged ahead by 1.6 per cent to 2,536,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

A leading French scientist yesterday reported evidence that nature spontaneously ignited a nuclear chain reaction in an African uranium mine millions of years ago. The reaction, he said, apparently ran for a prolonged period.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- Carmakers reported 150,910 retail automobile deliveries from Sept. 11 to 20, down from 194,366 sales of United States cars a year ago. There were nine selling days in mid-September this year, compared with eight days a year ago, meaning that the average of 16,768 deliveries a day was down 31 per cent from a 24,296-a-day selling rate last year.
OSLO, Norway, Tuesday, Sept. 26 -- Norwegians voted decisively a two-day referendum to reject membership in the European Economic Community.

MANILA, Sept. 25 -- The Government said today that 49 Filipinos -- among them six members of Congress, two provincial governors and several newsmen -- were being detained under the state of martial law imposed over the weekend.

Stanley M. Barkin's letter (Sept. 19) regarding the Geneva Accords and Vietnam repeats an error which needs correction, particularly since it has been uncritically accepted and published in many articles and works dealing with the origin of American involvement in Vietnam.

The number of United States companies with a stake in the Philippines, now being governed under a proclamation of martial law, has been estimated at 800 by the Philippine Securities and Exchange Commission.

WHITING, Vt. -- Ken Mayberger and his wife, Sal, could sell everything they weave and sculpt to New York's smartest shops, but they don't. They say they would rather keep their income low enough to escape Federal taxation.
In a game important because, according to Ed Giacomin, "it's a Boston team against a Ranger team," the Bruins last night captured a wide-open exhibition contest, 4-2.

Bob Devaney, Nebraska's football coach, yesterday de. nounced the Big Eight Conference rule that limits traveling squads to 50 players. Nebraska, a Big Eight team, took that many players to West Point last Saturday and trounced Army, 77-7.
BILLINGS, Mont., Sept. 25 -- Senator George McGovern charged here today that the Nixon Administration was dominated by special interests in environmental and regulatory agencies.
Two quarterbacks who didn't start Sunday afternoon probably earned the right to start against each other next Monday night when the New York Giants visit the Philadelphia Eagles.
A 38-year-old gypsy cab driver was shot and killed last night in northern Harlem when he apparently resisted three passengers who were trying to rob him, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, said today that Congress had vindicated Senator George McGovern, whose proposal to slash $4-billion from the military budget was defeated by the Senate last month.
The New York Board of Trade has named 12 companies and organizations to receive its Business Speaks Award for outstanding contributions to the social and economic well-being of the city.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board acted yesterday to lift the moratorium on conversions of savings and loan associations from mutual ownership to stock ownership at the discretion of the individual institutions.

When the statisticians had finished searching the record books they found that Joe Namath and Johnny Unitas set five club records during the Jets' 44-34 victory over the Colts in Baltimore on Sunday. Frankly, though, Namath couldn't have cared less about the records.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 (AP) -- American troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 400, to 36,100 last week, the United States command announced today.

Newspaper clippings about Julius Erving wallpaper the trophy case in the local high school in the village of Roosevelt, a predominantly black middle-class town on Long Island. His photograph is prominently displayed at the Theodore Roosevelt elementary school were he was the guest speaker at last June's graduation exercises.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 25 -- About 1,000 first - graders here will become the first school children in the United States to receive a new vaccine against meningitis. It will be administered by a physicians' team from the University of Connecticut School of Medicine.
John Diebold, 46-year-old management consultant and venture capitalist, has long been a leading apostle of the computer as the key to a revolution in managerial technique.
In the Bills' first offensive huddle, O. J. Simpson asked, "Does everyone here know everyone else?" Walt Patulski said, "It seemed we were just introduced to each other before the game."

Family Court Judge Nanette Dembitz, who is seeking to be the first woman elected to the State Court of Appeals, announced yesterday that she had appealed to the State Bar Association to reconsider its finding that she was "not qualified at the present time" for a seat on the state's highest tribunal.

The Chess Club Argentina of Buenos Aires organized a round-robin tournament recently to celebrate its 67th anniversary. Twelve grand-masters, international masters and masters participated and to the surprise of the chess public, Hermann Pilnik topped the field by scoring 9 points out of a possible 11.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Bonn Brown of Elkins, W. Va., was found guilty today of conspiracy, bribery and influencing the jury in the 1968 trial of W. W. Barron, former Governor of West Virginia.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- A Philippine official said here today that martial law might be maintained in his country for as long as two years to allow the Government to control subversion and carry out social reforms.
A patrolman hanging from a safety belt 12 stories high made a daring rescue of a 29-year-old woman threatening suicide in Queens yesterday morning.

The Vietnam war, which was supposed to be Senator George McGovern's strong suit politically, is actually working to the advantage of President Nixon in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, where much of the antiwar movement has been centered, according to a voter survey released yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N, Y., Sept. 25 -- Interpol, the international police organization, unanimously approved an American-sponsored resolution today urging its 110 member nations to intensify their efforts to combat "nonpolitical" terrorism.

The money and capital markets were kept on the defensive again yesterday, but activity was extremely light and interest rates did not climb by very much. Some rates, in fact, such as those on Treasury bills due from now until early next year, managed small declines.
NEWARK, Sept. 25 -- More than two dozen persons were injured today when an incoming Erie-Lackawanna commuter train bumped a train that was starting to move out of Penn Station here.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Sept. 25 -- Sargent Shriver, supporting a coordinated Democratic campaign against the Republican Administration, charged President Nixon today with failures in the field of health care.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The District of Columbia, designated by President Nixon as a national laboratory on crime control, has emerged in the political campaigns as a center of controversy over the highly emotional issue of "crime in the streets."

HANOI, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam has reiterated the position that the North Vietnamese want to release all captured American pilots and will do so when there is agreement on ending the war.
TEANECK, N. J., Sept. 25 -- Being a realist, Randy Newmann says he accepts his reputation and role as a "white, Jewish heavyweight hope," even though he happens to be German.
Just about the only major deodorant toilet soap that will be affected by the Government's new ban on the non-prescription use of the germ killer hexachlorophene is the market's leader, Dial.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- President Nixon won a political endorsement of his candidacy and pragmatic support for his new Soviet trade policy today from the International Longshoreman's Association.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Officials of civil rights and women's rights organizations made public today a memorandum that, they said, confirmed a "retreat in equal employment" by the Nixon Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Two new political polls reported today that Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential nominee, had narrowed the massive lead for President Nixon found in previous surveys.

A wide variety of reforms in Haryou-Act, Central Harlem's often controversial eight-year-old antipoverty agency, was promised yesterday by the new officers of the program, which is once again to channel $5,119,385 in Federal and city funds into the area for the year starting Oct. 1.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (AP) -Coach Harry Sinden said today that Team Canada had won its point and that the two West German referees who worked last night's hockey game against the Soviet Union "will not be used for the rest of the series."

Nations and individuals, once grown successful and affluent, tend to forget their humble origins and the struggles of their ancestors. Franklin D. Roosevelt, in addressing the Daughters of the American Revolution as his "fellow immigrants," intended more than a political wisecrack. There can be no meaningful belief in America as a nation without the acknowledgment of America as the creation of immigrant peoples and cultures.

COLUMBIA, Md. -- So far, the big event in the seven-week life of the Howard County headquarters of the Committee for the Re-election of the President has been a brief visit by the President's son-in-law, Edward F. Cox, a couple of weeks ago.

The Board of Higher Education last night approved the appointment of Lillian Hellman, the playwright, as distinguished professor in the Romance languages department of Hunter College, which includes part of that institution's program in the arts.

The Mafia informant who has cooperated with law-enforcement officials since soon after Joseph Gallo was murdered last April testified in State Supreme Court here yesterday that he and four other members of the rival Joseph A. Colombo family had planned and carried out the gangland leader's execution.
TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- New Jersey secondary schools will begin moving this fall toward a new system of credits and graduation requirements designed to increase curricular flexibility in local schools.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Brazil's armed forces have begun a combined drive to flush guerrillas out of a remote Amazon jungle region. At least one soldier has been reported killed in clashes between the rebels and 5,000 army, air force and navy troops.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The United States Steel Corporation signed a consent decree today under which it will start immediately a major program to eliminate massive pollution by its coke works at Clairton, Pa., on the Monongahela River 15 miles from here.

A character in Thomas Love Peacock's "Headlong Hall" comments that in laying out a garden he distinguishes three characteristics affording pleasure -- the picturesque, the beautiful and the unexpected.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Following are the texts of a resolution on terrorism offered by the United States in the General Assembly today, and of an American draft convention for the prevention and punishment of acts of terrorism:
The Police Conference of New York yesterday endorsed President Nixon for re-election.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- Secretary General Waldheim today named a retired Swiss diplomat as his representative to deal with matters relating to South-West Africa.

Anthony L. DiLorenzo, the 44-year-old reputed Mafia leader who disappeared on July 26 while on an unescorted furlough from Federal prison to his dentist on Long Island, was indicted yesterday on charges of escape from Federal custody.
Harvey L. Schein has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Sony Corporation of America, the American subsidiary of the Sony Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Following is the text of President Nixon's address today before the meeting of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank:

Francis A. Southard, a former employe of the Atlantic County Road Department, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to charges of conspiring to commit bribery and extortion in the awarding of contracts in Atlantic County.

Israel's elder statesman, David Ben-Gurion, celebrated his 86th birthday yesterday -- three weeks early by most calendars. But the white-haired former Premier chose to receive friends at his home at Sde Boker in the Negev according to the Jewish calendar.
Prices declined yesterday in quiet trading on the American Stock Exchange and in over-the-counter activity.

ARLINGTON, Tex., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Nolan Ryan became the sixth man in American League history to post 300 strikeouts in a season and then scored the winning run tonight as the California Angels beat the Texas Rangers, 2-1.

MINEOLA, L. I., Sept. 25 -In an unusual split in Republican ranks, County Executive Ralph G. Caso today vetoed a plan by the Republican-controlled County Board of Supervisors to implement a court order directing the board to reapportion on the basis of the one-man, one-vote principle.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 25 -- Five persons were wounded, one seriously, when two rival groups of Zulu tribesmen fought in the central area of this city at dawn today.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- A tentative agreement to end the longest strike in the history of General Motors was reached today. The 172-day strike cost the company over $100-million in lost production and 4,000 members of the United Automobile Workers about $20-million in wages.
A $37-million refrigerated warehouse and pier, designed to maintain New York as the nation's leading meat import center, will be built on the East River shorefront of the Hunts Point Food Center.

A wrecker's ball wielded by the Senate Finance Committee threatens to smash the most thoughtful measure ever devised on Capitol Hill for correcting defects in the private pension plans that cover more than thirty million workers.

The Hawaii Corporation announced yesterday in Honolulu that the sale of its Pacific Trade Center for "more than $26.5-million" had been approved by the boards and committees of the prospective buyers. The Pacific Trade Center is an office-retail-parking complex in Honolulu's financial district.

In his cyclonic career the protean Peter Hall has directed plays, operas and films. During the last year he staged Albee's "All Over" at the Royal Shakespeare Company, Pinter's "Alte Zeitung" in Vienna and Monteverdi's "The Return of Ulysses" at Glyndebourne.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- The United States asked the United Nations today to convene a meeting early next year to act on international terrorism.

BONN, Sept. 25 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt asserted today that West Germany's powerful conservative Opposition had offered money to members of parliament to defect from his coalition and wipe out his parliamentary majority.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 25 -Pierre Salinger, co-chairman of National Citizens for McGovern said here today that Senator George McGovern, if he became President, would work to give Louisiana a larger share of the tax revenues from oil found off its coast.

Fifty-one members of the theatrical profession were cited yesterday at the Drama Desk's annual awards luncheon for "outstanding contributions" to New York's 1971-72 season. Fourteen winners in the "most promising" categories each received $100 checks from Theodore W. Helweg, president of Ticketron, Inc., the electronic box-office system.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Pittsburgh scored five times in the sixth inning tonight and Steve Blass hurled the Pirates to a 5-1 decision over the Philadelphia Phillies for his 19th victory of the season.

The current emphasis on polls of voters' preferences suggests that our present election practices should be changed. In the old days it was customary for voters to cast their votes openly, by voice, so that everyone could know how each of his neighbors voted.

Vince Matthews said yesterday he had no regrets about his behavior at the 20th Olympic Games and probably would continue his track and field career "because it feels better to be in shape instead of out of shape."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- American Airlines has cut off air travel credit to the Democratic National Committee for failure to pay more than $6,000 in overdue bills.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Hank Aaron and Dusty Baker hit homers as the Atlanta Braves built an early lead and then staved off late-inning uprisings by the Cincinnati Reds to score a 10-9 victory tonight.

Indian Head, Inc., a diversifield industrial producer, realized increases of 13 per cent in sales and earnings for the third fiscal quarter ended Aug. 26, establishing new records, Richard J. Powers, chairman and president, reported yesterday. For the nine-month period, earnings were also up 13 per cent on a sales gain of 11 per cent.
Once again, Messrs. Gallup and Harris are becoming an issue in a national campaign. How reliable are their polls? How meaningful? Do they become self-fulfilling prophecies?
LONDON. Sept. 26 -- Edmond J. Safra is a Lebanese-born banker with Brazilian citizenship and a home in Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The House today approved creation of a 26,172-acre national recreation area at the entrance to New York harbor after killing a provision for a massive housing project that the Rockefeller administration wanted to build on part of Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn.

David J. Billings 3d, who for three years was chairman of the city's policy-making Council Against Poverty, was named yesterday as the assistant administrator for community projects in the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration.

In two unexpected moves, the International Business Machines Corporation and R. H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday announced top management changes. I.B.M. also established a new mandatory retirement age of 60.

It is a measure of success, however limited so far, that the struggle against spreading drug abuse must now assume a new dimension. Need is growing for employment opportunities for ex-addicts who have completed drug-free therapy or who have become established in a methadone maintenance program. The head of the city's Addiction Services Agency, Graham Finney, estimates this need at more than 40,000 jobs in the coming year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said today that his Government opposed acts of terrorism and "acts of violence that serve no positive ends and cause loss of human life."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The presidents of nine building and construction unions representing 1.7 million workers endorsed President Nixon for re-election today, saving that they found "the positions and policies of the candidate of the Democratic party wholly unacceptable."

GALVESTON, Tex., Sept. 26 -- Sargent Shriver, the Democratic Vice-Presidential nominee, said today that any consideration of amnesty for those who fled the country to avoid military service should await the conclusion of "a national program to take care of the veterans of the Vietnam war."

PRINCETON, N. J. -- The air is a bit more rarefied at the Institute for Advanced Study than in the rest of Princeton, and the new architecture, generally, is better. The institute, the prestigious center of advanced research in the fields of mathematics, historical studies and natural and social sciences, is the country's sacrosanct temple of pure learning at ionosphere levels.
ROME, Sept. 26 -- Pope Paul VI worked as usual and made no public appearance on his 75th birthday today.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, who warned Democrats away from Senator George McGovern here in June, returned today to urge them to come home to the McGovern candidacy for President.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Can George McGovern win?
The Bronx has a "continuing crisis" of refuse disposal that will culminate in two years when the city no longer can use the Pelham Bay landfill site, the City Planning Commission was told yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The State Department acknowledged today that it had supplied the White House with its Public Affairs Division's mailing list, which was apparently used by the Democrats for Nixon campaign organization.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A recent bulletin published by the Christophers contained this informal prayer:

Most live hog futures prices declined the limit yesterday on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange following a report Friday by the Department of Agriculture that more pigs would be brought to market this year than had been expected.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The less-developed countries, which traditionally have concentrated on lining up more economic aid at the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, are asserting themselves in the monetary-reform arena with unusual emphasis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- The Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. John D. Ryan, has testified that Melvin R. Laird, the Secretary of Defense, turned down his recommendation that key members of Congress be told why Gen. John D. Lavelle was relieved in April.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Steve Busby, a 22-year-old rookie right-hander, and his battery-mate, Ed Kirkpatrick, dealt Chicago's title hopes a severe blow tonight by leading the Kansas City Royals to a 2-1 victory over the White Sox.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Two French centrist parties announced a far-reaching joint reform movement today and offered to negotiate a coalition with the Gaullists after elections if their program was accepted.
The city's maximum-base-rent program for rent-controlled apartments was sharply attacked yesterday by tenants, the real-estate industry and the state's Rent Administrator.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 27 (AP) -- American officials said yesterday that over-all ground fighting in South Vietnam had tapered off to its lowest level since the North Vietnamese began their offensive March 30.

ELDRED, N. Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Two Alaskan huskies and a tranquilizer gun put an end to the adventures of a 30-pound escaped monkey tonight, and -- authorities said -- sheer exhaustion later killed the animal.

HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A truce between Hollywood and minority groups -- soothed by lucrative ail-black movies and heightened minority employment -- is being shaken by angry complaints, demands and charges of bias.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Senator George S. McGovern today proposed new rules for international financial dealings, rules aimed at stopping sudden, sharp changes in the price of money which have left Americans with less to spend in many foreign countries.
ROME, Sept. 26 -- The Colosseum was completely closed to the public today after an examination of the most famous ancient Roman monument by a municipal commission.

A 21-year-old unemployed dishwasher was arrested and charged yesterday with the murder and robbery two weeks ago of 83-year-old Peter Brejwa in the basement of the rectory of St. Clemens Mary Roman Catholic Church at 406 West 40th Street.
Ralph Nader said yesterday he was pleased that major pension reform had been sidetracked by the Senate Finance Committee, but only because the legislation it was considering did not go far enough.

Dumping garbage in the ocean, a practice outlawed by the United States Supreme Court in 1933, was suggested by the Lindsay administration yesterday as a means of solving the growing problem of where to put the city's waste.

The artificial distinctions between the way young criminals and older criminals are processed by the authorities and punished, if found guilty, have long stood in the way of the suppression of juvenile crime.

The Air Force announced yesterday that it was temporarily sending 48 of its F-111A attack bombers to Southeast Asia to bolster its low-level and all-weather capabilities for the approaching monsoon season.

The appointment of Allan R. Johnson, chairman of the board of Saks Fifth Avenue, as general campaign chairman of the 1972-73 Greater New York Councils, Boy Scouts of America Finance Campaign, was announced yesterday by David L. Yunich, vice chairman of R. H. Macy Co. and president of the New York Councils.

Federal and local narcotics agents arrested 14 persons in the metropolitan area yesterday who were said to be part of a major heroin ring supplying central Harlem and the South Bronx. Nine other persons were being sought.
Willis Reed returned to Madison Square Garden with the Knicks last night and the good times were back for a crowd of 16,323 which turned out to welcome professional basketball back for a new season.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 26 -- The Israeli police confirmed here today that arms shipments air-freighted abroad for a terrorist campaign against Arabs had reached their destinations.

Three members of the Jewish Defense League pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to charges related to bombing incidents last year at two offices and property of the Soviet Union here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Senate reversed itself today and rejected, by a vote of 45 to 42, an end-the-war proposal that it had adopted two months ago. The vote was widely regarded here as marking the collapse of the antiwar movement in the Senate for this session, leaving the Administration firmly in control of the war issue in Congress.
LONDON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Bob Foster knocked out Chris Finnegan with a smashing left and right to the head in the 14th round tonight and retained his world light-heavy-weight championship.
Governor Rockefeller's special horse-racing study group will "listen terribly hard" to everybody with something to say, its Chairman promised yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A Federal appeals court has dismissed contempt charges against four antiwar veterans who were twice jailed in Tallahassee, Fla., for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating protest plans for the Democratic and Republican national conventions.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Europe reacted with dismay and concern today to Norway's rejection of entry into the European Economic Community.
SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 26 -- Prime Minister William McMahon announced tonight strong new measures to restrict foreign control of Australian industries.

MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- Canada's top hockey professionals squeezed out a rough-and-tumble 4-3 victory tonight over the Soviet Union to pull even with their hosts and set up a winner-take-all showdown in the final encounter of their eight-game series Thursday.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today that sales and production of one of the basic engines used in the 1973 Mavericks and Comets would be held up because it had not met Federal air pollution standards.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Discovery of a long-sought hormone produced by the thymus gland was reported here today by a team of scientists from Paris.

MONTREAL, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Billy Williams drove in three runs with his 35th homer of the season and a single, and Milt Pappas won his 10th straight game tonight as the Chicago Cubs shut out the Montreal Expos, 6-0.
YONKERS, Sept. 26 -- In the 54th and final year of his career as a harness racing driver, 78-year-old Earle Avery was feted tonight at Yonkers Raceway, the site of many of his successes.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Sept. 26 -- A University of Florida eye doctor reported today that he and a team of research ophthalmologists had improved the vision of 10 persons "legally blind" in one or both eyes by means of a new kind of plastic surgery that requires less than one minute to perform.
The Pennsylvania Company voted yesterday to pay the Oct., 15 dividend on its 4 5/8 per cent cumulative preferred stock to holders of record Oct. 6.

HOUSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A two-run double by Gary Matthews and a single by Tito Fuentes led to four runs in the fifth inning and vaulted the San Francisco Giants to a 5-2 victory of the Houston Astros tonight.

HARTFORD, Sept. 26 -- Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today questioned the quality of the management of Connecticut's bus companies and warned that he would veto any attempt by the General Assembly to force the state to subsidize the companies to keep the buses running.

A narcotics raid in Middlesex County yesterday resulted in the arrests of 24 persons, including two 15-year-old boys.

The club is called the New York Islanders, an $11-million investment in the future of hockey in Nassau County, and tomorrow they meet for the first time the New York Rangers in an exhibition game.

Hogan of Manhattan and Governor Rockefeller over the creation of the anti-corruption post.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- (Reuters) -- Total reserve assets of the United States rose by $34-million in August to $13.12-billion after a $240-million decline in July, the Treasury Department reported today.

Prices firmed at mid-day on the American Stock Exchange, but eased during the afternoon to close lower again yesterday. Over-the-counter stocks were moderately improved.

David L. Yunich, former president of Macy's New York and currently one of the two vice chairmen of the parent company, R. H. Macy Co., Inc., will retire at the age of 55 next February after 33 years with the department-store chain.

The Bowater Corporation, Ltd., a paper and building-materials producer, and Ralli International, Ltd., an investment-holding company, announced yesterday an agreement to merge. The transaction is valued at about $196-million based on current stock market prices.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company confirmed reports yesterday that it planned to share ownership of its proposed $1-billion offshore nuclear generating plant. New York's five District Attorneys held a luncheon meeting yesterday to discuss their future relations with the city's new special deputy attorney general, Maurice H. Nadjari.

Peter Diapoulos, alleged bodyguard of the late Joseph Gallo, was convicted last night in State Supreme Court in Manhattan of having possessed an unloaded gun, a misdemeanor, after Gallo was murdered last April.

Columbia will open its football season against Fordham today because Buffalo University decided it could no longer afford the luxury of a varsity football team. Buffalo, originally scheduled to meet Columbia today, dropped the sport in January of 1971. Within a few weeks Fordham's athletic director, Pete Carlesimo, and Columbia's athletic director, Ken Germann, had things arranged for the rare meeting of two New York varsity football teams.

MALMESBURY, South Africa, Saturday, Sept. 30 (Agence France-Presse) -- At least 100 people were reported killed last night when a passenger train was derailed near Malmesbury, in Cape Province, in what appears to be South Afria's worst train disaster.

PHOENIX, Sept. 29 (AP) -Mrs. Billie Jean King of Palm-Aire, Fla., the first woman athlete to earn $100,000 in a year in 1971, did it again today with a victory in the quarter finals of the Virginia Slims - Phoenix Thunderbirds women's tennis tournament.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 29 -- The Boston Red Sox ended the three-year reign of the Baltimore Orioles as champions of the American League tonight with a 4-2 victory in 10 innings that also kept the Red Sox in the Eastern Division lead with five games to play.

HANOVER, N.H., Sept. 30 -Ellis Rowe, a junior fullback from Miami, gained 153 yards in 12 carries before spraining his ankle early in the third period today, but his spark was enough to push Dartmouth to a 24-14 victory over New Hampshire at Memorial Field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -After a month on the road, Sargent Shriver's campaign as the No. 2 man on the Democratic ticket has begun to develop a significance unusual for a Vice-Presidential nominee.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30 -Theodore C. Sorenson has issued a sharp attack on President Nixon's Latin - American policies and then outlined what may constitute a preview of Senator George McGovern's position on the subject.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -President Nixon today signed the Congressional resolution approving a five-year freeze at the present levels of most United States and Soviet offensive nuclear weapons.

MOMBASA, Kenya -- The "great snake" uncoils under the humid, Indian Ocean sun of this strange Sinbad city of open vowels and Arab dhows plying the monsoon. All afternoon the evening train for Nairobi is assembled while the Arab Old City blinks in the heat.

LIBREVILLE, Gabon, Sept. 30 -- The creation of a commission to promote trade between African countries was urged today by representatives of 33 black and Arab African nations here.

NAGOYA, Japan -- For 19-year-old Mikiko Ura, working at the Teijin, Ltd., spinning mill here is an unusual mixture of feudalism, individual enterprise and Japanese tradition. She was recruited on another Japanese island and brought here at 15. Her whole life is involved in her job, but she has saved almost $1,300 in her four years here and is acquiring the high school diploma she might never have received had she stayed home.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The House Banking and Currency Committee rejected today, 20 to 15, a proposal to hold public hearings on certain aspects of the alleged bugging of the Democratic party's Watergate headquarters.
MANILA, Oct. 3 -- President Ferdinand E. Marcos has embarked on a program of encouraging foreign Investments, particularly in oil exploration and mining.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- In a Senate given to mutual accommodation when it comes to dispensing Federal largesse, the two Senators from Washington are finding themselves unexpectedly challenged by Senator J. W. Fulbright in an attempt to get a $11.5-million contribution for a fair in their home state.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Pentagon statistics showed today that bombs dropped by the United States in Southeast Asia in the first nine months of 1972 exceeded in tonnage the bombs dropped in all of 1971.

JERSEY CITY, Oct. 3 -- Inmates at the Hudson County Jail shuffled into the small third-floor gymnasium today in groups of five and 10, not to play the usual games of volleyball or shuffleboard, but to register to vote in the Nov. 7 Presidential election.

New Yorkers who wish to vote in the Nov. 7 election may register at their local polling places tomorrow, Friday, Saturday and next Tuesday. The polls will be open from 5:30 P.M. to 10:30 P.M. tomorrow, Friday and Tuesday and from 7 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct 3 (AP) -- The 140,000-pupil school system here, struck for two weeks by teachers, returned to normal today as the Senate District Committee opened hearings on a 12 per cent teacher pay increase.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 3 -Chasing a hastily drawn schedule through northern industrial centers, Sargent Shriver is attempting to break through a wall of suspicion that seems to stand between Senator George McGovern, the Democratic Presidential candidate, and many traditionally Democratic voters.

ROME -- There is a saying in Rome that when the Colosseum fails Rome will fall. Ever since 50-pound chunks of travertine marble began crashing to the ground a few months ago from the 150-foot high structure, superstitious Romans have had cause for alarm.

One of the major builders in the city criticized the construction industry here yesterday for being "hapless" and "ineffective" in collective bargaining, pitting amateur management negotiators against skilled union negotiators.

Anyone who has ever had a toothache disappear when he reached the dentist's office knows how easy it is for the dislike of a treatment to mask or color the perception of an ailment. The same phenomenon often occurs in national economic policymaking: Policy determines analysis, rather than vice versa.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 -- Russians love anniversaries, and on the eve of Sputnik's 15th anniversary, medals are being handed out to unidentified scientists and technicians, the results of the Soviet space program are being reviewed and assessed, and the newly developing collaboration with the United States is being hailed.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Legislation providing a special tax credit to parents and others who are paying tuition to private, primary and secondary schools was approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- In a largely unnoticed lawsuit filed here more than three weeks ago, a manufacturer of cloudseeding equipment charges that the United States is making rain in Indochina with a device he invented, in violation of his patent rights.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Managers of a bill to create an independent consumer protection agency failed today for the second time to limit Senate debate on the measure.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Television people, citizens' groups and the Government approached agreement today that there should be some kind of incentive for broadcasters who present quality programing for children.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Senate killed today a compromise welfare reform plan that President Nixon had earlier refused to endorse.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 3 -- China told the General Assembly today that the people of the world "must not be deluded by certain temporary and superficial phenomena of detente at the present time and develop a false sense of security."
NEWARK, Oct. 3 -- For Edward Plaza, 29 years old, lately of Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office, "Here is where the action is."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- Just eight hours after the Philadelphia horse show -- the first major event of the indoor fall circuit -- opened in the Spectrum today, a horse dropped dead of a heart attack.

A $90-million offering of California bonds met resistance from potential investors yesterday, leaving the tax-exempt market with considerably less optimism about the market's direction than before the sale.

In Some of the strongest language he has used about the courts since becoming Mayor, John V. Lindsay charged in an interview that the State Supreme Court was highly inefficient and strongly susceptible to corruption because it was controlled by political bosses.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- George Gallup, the pollster, said today that American prestige was at a low point in the world, partly because United States "press services, in concentrating so heavily on our problems, may have given a distorted picture."

INWOOD, L. I., Oct. 3 -Jimmy Wright, playing on his home course, and Bill Collins, a stranger to the layout, shared the lead at 72 in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship today.

Senator George McGovern promised yesterday to make eradication of crime and drug abuse "the No. 1 domestic priority of my administration."

A non-registered secondary offering of 237,500 shares of Mohasco Industries at $32 a share was announced yesterday by Morgan Stanley Co. and Shields Co. as managers. The company's stock closed at 32, down 7/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Ivy League unveiled its 1972 football teams in nonleague competition last weekend and came away with a collective 6-2 won-lost mark. As expected Columbia, Dartmouth, Penn and Yale demonstrated superior talents in beating Fordham, New Hampshire, Lafayette and Connec ticut, respectively.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- After months of working through the so-called establishment in the Jewish community, the men running President Nixon's reelection effort have taken their vigorous campaign to increase his share of the normally Democratic Jewish vote into the neighborhoods and the streets of the cities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- No plan of action was in sight after the Federal Communicasion member among the most days of panel discussions last week on the content of television programing for children and the propriety of the commercials that make up almost 25 per cent of each program hour.

Forty-nine lawyers have been formally disciplined for serious misconduct this year by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, a jump of more than 33 per cent over the highest previous such total since World War II.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu has again denounced the Vietnamese Communists' peace proposal for a three-segment coalition Government in the South.

A disastrous start in the National Football League season continued for the Minnesota Vikings yesterday as Gary Cuozzo threw a touchdown pass with a minute 38 seconds left to play that lifted the St. Louis Cardinals to a 19.17 victory over the Vikings.

A woman who said a masked man had set fire to her apartment after he ransacked it and tried to strangle her was rescued yesterday from her burning South Bronx tenement flat by two policemen and two firemen.

DALLAS, Oct. 8 -- Further increases in bank lending rates are likely to provoke the Federal Government to take direct action to control the cost of money, the president of the American Bankers Association warned here today.
The Ailanthus, a much-maligned tree with a long list of enemies (most of whom call it a contemptible weed) has found a new and important friend -- the New York Botanical Garden.

Violent crime in the nation's suburbs is increasing nearly twice as fast as in the large cities. But suburban crime rates, on a per capita basis, are still so low that even at the present rate of increase, there is no chance that suburbanites will soon be in as much danger of violence as city residents.

Some 100,000 people are expected to march up Fifth Avenue under fair skies today in the 28th annual Columbus Day Parade. The marchers will step off at noon from 44th Street and turn east on 86th Street to Third Avenue.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 8 -- Chief rabbis for Israel's two religious communities are to be elected next Sunday, and after nominations closed in Jerusalem today it appeared that candidates backed by the Government were certain to be chosen.

INZAI, Japan, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Gay Brewer missed a chance for victory in a three - hole playoff today then triumphed in a sudden-death playoff in the Pacific Masters golf tournament. He defeated David Graham of Australia for the $65,000 first prize in the world's richest golf event.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -Henry A. Kissinger, the President's adviser on national security, held another private meeting in Paris today with North Vietnam's top negotiators. The White House said they would meet again tomorrow and left open the possibility of an unprecedented third consecutive meeting on Tuesday.

Robert Byrne, a United States chess co-champion, has been appointed chess columnist for The New York Times. He replaces Al Horowitz, who has been on a leave of absence.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 9 -- The Pittsburgh Pirates moved within one game of the National League pennant today when they rallied in the late innings to defeat the Cincinnati Reds, 3-2.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 9 (AP) -- United States troop strength in Vietnam dropped by 700 men, to 35,200 last week, the United States command announced today.

The New York bridge community has lost one of its most talented young experts -- Frank Mela, of Great Neck, L. I., who died Saturday following a heart attack at the age of 37. He was the reigning player-of-the-year champion of the Greater New York Bridge Association based on his 1971 record.

BACOLOD, the Philippines, Oct. 7 -- Out in the provinces of the Philippines, military men are playing a much more important role under martial law than before, but governors, mayors, judges and other civil authorities continue to function and to administer their areas of responsibility with little change.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- A man clad in the white vestments of a missionary bishop and wearing a golden cross got into the papal summer residence at Castel Gandolfo one day last month and tried to approach Pope Paul VI.

More than a thousand household workers, more commonly referred to as domestics, concluded a three-day convention here yesterday and resolved, among other things, to seek from their employers better wages, improved working hours and a recognition that being a domestic is "no low business," that, indeed, a domestic is a "respectable professional."

Steel production for the week ended Oct. 7 totaled 2,568,000 net tons, or an index level of 105.3, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with the 2,557,000 tons poured in the week ended Sept. 30 when the index stood at 104.8.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- The bank rate, which for 270 years has been the peg for monetary policy and interest rates in Britain, was abolished today by Anthony Barber, the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Oct. 10 -- Several hundred Vietcong guerrillas continued to hold on yesterday in at least three hamlets within 20 miles north of Saigon, Government military spokesmen said.
A 6-year-old mare named Typecast turned the $117,300 Man o'War Stakes into the Woman o'War yesterday at Belmont Park by thrashing 10 male rivals in the 14th running of the weight-for-age event.

Both the U.S. and Europe desire to maintain their agricultural output above a strictly economic level for social reasons; they want to avoid an accelerated trek of population away from the land into urban regions.

SOUTHBURY, Conn., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Judy Rankin braved the wind and the cold at the Heritage Village Country Club today and pulled away for a five-stroke victory in the second Ladies Professional Golf Association Heritage Village open.
J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., the largest of the nation's banking concerns doing business chiefly with corporations, reported here yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose by nearly 5 per cent.
Bertram Perkel, a 42-year-old labor lawyer, has been appointed special counsel to Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murhpy.

TBILISI, U.S.S.R., Oct. 9 -- "All of a sudden I have millions of relatives," chirped George Balanchine during an intermission at one of the New York City Ballet's performances in this capital of Soviet Georgia, the homeland of his forefathers.
Who ever heard of a posh jewelry shop offering necklaces, bracelets, pins, rings, pendants and cuff links ranging to $5,000, with only four tiny diamonds in the entire establishment?
A model contract considered to be "a major breakthrough" for future negotiations between writers and publishers has been submitted by the Authors Guild to its 3,700 members.

LONDON, Oct. 9 (Agence France-Presse) -- Negotiations between the Iraqi Government and the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company are making progress, and I.P.C. will take no legal action until a further statement on mediation progress, the company said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- President Nixon's top economic advisers said today that there was a "good chance" that the House of Representatives would approve on Tuesday the President's requested $250-billion ceiling on Federal spending.

A Bronx grand jury began an investigation yesterday of the death last month of a 26-year-old electrician who was allegedly thrown off a roof by two patrolmen. District Attorney Burton B. Roberts, who has been questioning witnesses from the South Bronx area where the death occurred, said that "a great deal of evidence" would be put before the panel.

Willis Reed will be on the disabled list tonight when the New York Knickerbockers open their 27th National Basketball Association campaign against the Seattle SuperSonics at Madison Square Garden. Game time is 7:30.

SUVA, Fiji -- A tiny community of displaced South Pacific islanders is battling against the British Government and international phosphate interests over the ravaging of their once-fertile home island by strip mining.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, Oct. 9 (Reuters) -- Yemeni troops have occupied a Southern Yemeni island in the Red Sea after naval and air attacks in which many civilians were killed, a Southern Yemeni Government spokesman said here today.

HOLLYWOOD -- After a 15 year absence from the movies, Ida Lupino is back in "Junior Bonner," now playing in the Metropolitan area, and she's giving the kind of gutsy, intelligent performance that made her a dramatic star in such early Lupino classics as "Ladies in Retirement" and "The Hard Way."

The name of Matt Snell was added to the growing list of New York Jets' invalids yesterday. The Jets' fullback was operated on by Dr. John Vieta, chief of surgery at Lenox Hill Hospital, for removal of a ruptured spleen.
It was Cristoforo Colombo's day yesterday as a Fifth Avenue parade and other ceremonies honored the 480th anniversary of the Italian explorer's serendipitous discovery of the Americas.
The General Electric Company reported yesterday new highs in sales and carnings for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

The State Division of Human Rights has ruled in favor of a 20-year-old Hamburg, N. Y., youth who said that a restaurant in his home town had refused to serve him liquor while it served drinks to girls under 21.

The chairman of United Towns for Home Rule, the group that has led the opposition to the state Urban Development Corporation's housing plans in Westchester County, announced yesterday that he was resigning because others in the group's leadership wanted to take it off a present course he characterized as "moderate."

Gene Hull, who once led one of the best big jazz bands in the Northeast, has "turned a page" in his career and is now heading a six-member pop/rock jazz combo called Free Spirit, currently at Shepheard's.

In a rare move among corporate executives, the president of Liggett Myers Inc. has denounced the Presidential candidacy of Senator George McGovern and endorsed the re-election of President Nixon in a letter sent to 45,000 company shareholders.

Staten Island ferry riders adjusted quickly to the new system of one-way toll collection that went into effect yesterday.

RAPID CITY, S. D. -- Your junior Senator, who aspires to the Presidency, has made known throughout the United States that he would cut our defense budget to the bone. Senator McGovern has pledged to cut $30 billion, or 35 per cent, from our present levels of defense spending and halt the development of new weapons systems.

Lubomir Kavalek lost to Milko Bobotzov. Pal Benko drew with Gheorghiu Tringov, William Martz drew with Ivan Radulov and George Kane drew with Nikola Padevski.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted new rules today enlarging the present exemption for certain kinds of oil and gas securities from stock-registration requirements.

The BankAmerica Corporation, the holding company of the Bank of America, announced yesterday afternoon that it had made an offer to acquire GAC Finance, Inc., a subsidiary of the GAC Corporation.

After a long series of actions intended to provide greater financial security for the elderly, the Senate has perversely buried the measure that promised the longest step of all toward improved protection in old age. PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The burial of the Bank of England's bank rate, which had become an anachronism after 270 years, will make it easier for Europeans to map a common strategy against inflation, central bankers and economists in several continental centers said today.

Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugarman said yesterday that his inquiry into the troubled Youth Services Agency would go beyond a reply to the City Controller's critical audit and include an over-all examination of the youth program.

CROTON, N. Y. -- The dining room ell, with the table set for lunch, was distraction enough: the stone floor and severe wooden table a background for a sunny harmony of oranges and yellows in the flowers, the napkins, the placemats. Even the hostess wore yellow -- a printed pants suit strewn with poppies and touches of wildflowers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation have been asked to supply the Price Commission with more information on their proposed price increases on 1973 models, further delaying a decision on their requests. A commission spokesman said today that the two companies were asked to provide "further clarification" of economic information submitted to the agency as the result of public hearings conducted on the request.

Tom Wicker's recent column on "The Lavelle Affair" raises my hackles by his careless and cavalier statement regarding Lavelle's retired pay. The average leader can only get the distinct impression from it that armed service retired pay is "virtually tax free." That is not the case.

Tyler Chase kicked a record five field goals and converted once to account for 16 of Brown's 28 points in the Ivy League victory over Penn last Saturday. The senior from Orange, Conn., who kicks soccer style, was named the kicker on the Eastern College Athletic Conference's weekly all-star squad.

HARTFORD, Oct. 10 -- The United States Supreme Court agreed unanimously today to hear an appeal in a case challenging the constitutionality of Connecticut's legislative reapportionment plan.
DETROIT, Oct. 10 -- A number of threatened strikes, should they materialize, could cripple production by the General Motors Corporation before the week is finished.

PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 10 -- Radio station WPAT and the Paterson Coalition for Media Change, a group of 30 civil rights and activist organizations, announced today that the station had agreed to provide more news and public-affairs coverage of the city and to hire additional minority-group personnel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Supreme Court struck down, 8 to 1, today an Ohio plan for direct tuition grants to parents of children in private and parochial schools. The plan had been considered a testing ground for new methods of public aid to church-related schools.
In stepped-up activity, prices rose yesterday for the third consecutive session on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market.
HONOLULU, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Union picket lines were withdrawn and longshoremen returned to work today, ending a three-day strike that shut down Honolulu docks for the first time in 23 years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- For the first time, the role of the Negro in American history is being fairly and adequately treated in school textbooks in this country, according to a study commissioned by the American Federation of Teachers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Although, point by point, Senator George McGovern's plan for peace in Indochina was little more than a recapitulation of his known views, the decision to commit his candidacy -- and his possible Presidency -- to a formal course in Vietnam has added both novelty and great risk to his campaign.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 10 -- Mrs. Douglas Frederick's hand-wrought concrete markers will again grace the tiny graves of her infant son and daughter in Glendale Cemetery here, despite a city ordinance requiring granite or bronze markers.

Councilman Leon A. Katz asked the City Council yesterday to investigate the possibility of a "major conflict of interest" in the acceptance by Albert A. Walsh of a position with the National Realty Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on the creation of a Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor, but refused to name the urban park for the late Representative William F. Ryan.
CLEARWATER, Fla., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Lawyers for Glenn W. Turner kept up a fusilade of legal moves today that caused a temporary delay and the naming of a second judge in his securities-violations case.

ATLANTA, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- The Atlanta school board voted last night to appeal to the United States Supreme Court a new desegregation order that some educators predict would result in an almost all-black public school system through a flight of whites to the suburbs.
LONDON, Oct. 10 -- The Government proposed today "a radical new approach" to the payment of welfare benefits. It suggested making them part of the income tax system.

The urban renewal agency in Peekskill, N. Y., announced yesterday that construction would start early next month on a $14-million development on a four-acre site in the northern Westchester County city's downtown area. The development will be a "super block" of five buildings grouped around landscaped plazas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Representative Bella S. Abzug, Democrat of Manhattan, said today that private investigators for her had found evidence that wiretaps had been placed on her Washington and New York Congressional offices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Charles Alan Wright, a tall, square-shouldered lawyer from Austin, Tex., sought to convince the Supreme Court today that the Hughes Tool Company should not be forced to pay a judgment of nearly $170-million to Trans World Airlines.

Not all of New York's best music-making goes on in the standard concert halls. The series known as Musica Sacra, given at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 64th Street, is about as worthy a project as could be desired. Obviously the word has got around, because the church was packed on Monday night for the opening of its third season.

Perkin, founder and former chairman, and certain other shareholders.

Mrs. Priscilla Ryan took her campaign to the early-morning subway riders, and Mrs. Bella S. The controversial low-income housing project in Forest Hills, Queens, would be limited to veterans and the elderly and be made a low-income cooperative under a proposal worked out by the Community Planning Board and supported by Borough President Donald R. Manes.

An offering of 1,500,000 common shares of Orange and Rockland Utilities Inc. at $16.625 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch. Net proceeds will be used to reduce short-term indebtedness incurred in connection with the utility's construction program. The company's stock was unchanged at 16 5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Like a desk-top ant farm, one small nook of the city welfare bureaucracy has been fascinating Lindsay officials lately. It has become a classic case of how to finesse a 20-fold increase in work from a group of civil servants.

Bausch Lomb, a glamour favorite on Wall Street earlier this year, plummeted 8 1/4 points to 28 3/8 as the market's most active issue yesterday. This dramatized the overriding importance of earnings in a market that posted a modest over-all decline.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 20 -- North Vietnamese troops reoccupied yesterday at least two hamlets near Saigon from which they had been driven earlier in the week.

Laird, insisting that the documented instances of unauthorized bombing of North Vietnam did not represent a breakdown of civilian control of the military forces, outlined today a series of steps that he said were aimed at "further strengthening" civilian authority.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, whose widely diversified products range from Scotch brand tapes to photographic equipment and health care products with expansion into pharmaceuticals, expects to post its 21st consecutive year of record sales and earnings in 1972, according to yesterday's financial report.

The American Stock Exchange index finished yesterday at its lowest level in more than nine months as prices declined in slower trading.

OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 19 -- The Sparky and Dick Show, a prime-time television serial designed to promote the sale of shaving cream and establish the rounders championship of the world, has developed into the most impressively cerebral program since "The $64,000 Question." This is fortunate indeed, for the physical aspects of the entertainment have been reduced to a minimum by execrable stage lighting.

The American Maize Products Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire from National Industries, Inc., its 75 per cent interest in the Cott Corporation, a bottler and distributor of carbonated beverages with sales of $72-million last year.

Barker, one of the men indicted in the alleged bugging of Democratic headquarters here.
