An aide of Representative Herman Badillo was refreshingly frank as he recounted the Congressman's campaign for Senator George McGovern. "We decide which appearances are good for Herman as well as McGovern," said the aide.

Piano and drums are about as bareboned and basic as a jazz combo can be. But Dick Durham, the pianist in the Dick Durham Duo, which played at the weekly Jazz Adventures session Friday at the Playboy Club, has managed to expand the usual concept of a jazz pianist into something approaching a quintet or a quartet.

An overthrown pass by Joe Namath caromed off the hand of Charlie Stukes, a Baltimore cornerback, and into the arms of Ed Bell, who ran 35 yards to complete an 83-yard touchdown play and give the New York Jets a 24-20 victory over the Colts yesterday before a crowd of 62,948 in Shea Stadium.

QUEBEC CITY, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- The Quebec Nordiques lost their first home game of the season tonight before 6,394 fans as the Ottawa Nationals held on to a one-goal lead established in the second period by Bob Charlebois to post a 3-2 victory in the World Hockey Association.

PARIS, Oct. 22 (Agence France-Presse) -- the Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, flew into Paris today on his way to the United States and said he was optimistic about the chances of peace in Laos and throughout Indochina.

State Senator Joseph J. Maraziti, Republican candidate in New Jersey's 13th Congressional District charged yesterday that his Democratic opponent, Mrs. Helen Meyner, supported the proposed Tocks Island project because she had a financial interest in utility companies that would benefit from the project.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -President Nixon, in his second nationwide radio speech of the weekend, built today on a Veterans Day theme to praise young Americans who have served in Vietnam and to detail his Administration's achievements in their behalf.

MORRISTOWN, Oct. 22 -Leaders of the Jail Chaplaincy Council of Morris County called tonight for "a complete restructuring of governmental regulation of the county jail" and the creation of a professional county department of corrections.

The Wells Fargo Bank, San Francisco, announced over the weekend formal termination of its agreement to buy the $1.25billion First Western Bank and Trust Company, Los Angeles, from World Airways, Inc. for $95-million in cash and notes.
DOVER TOWNSHIP, Oct. 22 -- Ocean County residents will learn next month the route of a controversial 35-mile New Jersey Turnpike spur linking this municipality with South Brunswick.

HONOLULU, Oct. 22 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today that 25 black men aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk are charged with assault and rioting connected with racial disturbances Oct. 12 and 13 while the ship participated in air strikes against North Vietnam.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 22 -- "And now here comes No. 19," the loudspeaker crackled "That's Ed Witte, oldest man in the regatta at 77, dropping his blades beautifully as he goes through the Eliot Bridge arch and into the last halfmile."

A rule-book work slowdown that may reduce police protection on subway trains and stations by about 15 per cent was started yesterday afternoon by the 3,200-member Transit Patrolman's Benevolent Association.
There may be many explanations why Colorado upset Oklahoma and Missouri did the same to Notre Dame Saturday -- none of which sound completely satisfactory.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 22 -Gene Tenace was upset that Manager Dick Williams took him out of today's seventh World Series game in the sixth inning, but Joe Morgan was more upset that the Cincinnati Reds let "one guy [Tenace] beat us."

CINCINNATI, Oct. 22 -- The Oakland A's -- the only team in baseball with 19 mustaches and one mule -- finally won the World Series today when they defeated the Cincinnati Reds in the seventh and last game, 3-2.

TIME CHAMBER An evening of medieval and Renaissance chamber music, played on recorders, viola da gamba, sackbutt, lute, psaltery, the lungs and other ancient instruments, starts off a new monthly series, "Music for a While," at the Synod Hall of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, 110th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, tonight at 8:15.

His way paved by three successful Chopin recordings and a sonata appearance here last season with the Polish violinist Wanda Wilkomirska, Antonio Barbosa made his formal recital debut yesterday afternoon before a large and friendly audience at the Hunter College Playhouse.

Your criticism of President Nixon (editorial Oct. 14), in which you charge him with hiding from the issues raised by candidate McGovern, carries your partisanship beyond the limits of good sense and reasonable understanding.

WARSAW, Oct. 22 -- The New York City Ballet ended a month-long tour of the Soviet Union and Poland last night before a delighted Warsaw audience that lavished its affection on George Balanchine, the director.

STAMFORD, Conn. Oct. 22 -A kind of do-it-yourself mass was celebrated today in the cafeteria of Stamford Catholic High School. The liturgy followed basic Roman Catholic canonical requirements to the letter, but worshipers were free to extemporize if they so desired.

Flags flew from the neat homes in the southwest corner of Forest Hills yesterday, tributes to veterans who fought for American traditions. But there were also clusters of stunned people talking on 70th Avenue and on Loubet and Kessel Streets.

The indifference of the Metropolitan Museum to the plight of the turn-of-the-century houses on Fifth Avenue across from the museum's plaza defeated our efforts to save the houses from demolition until such time as the Landmarks Preservation Commission could hold its authorized hearings.
School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner said last night that the Board of Education had agreed not to enroll 31 black students in John Wilson Junior High School 211 in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The New England Whalers took a 5-1 victory from the Minnesota Fighting Saints in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

Lenny Wilkens, starting his 13th season as a National Basketball Association backcourtman, will make his debut as a Cleveland Cavalier tonight at Madison Square Garden. The Cavs will attempt to end a season-opening six-game losing streak.

While judges experiment with sentencing panels and legislators call for mandatory prison terms for certain crimes, inmates in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men are devising sentencing reforms of their own.

Your Oct. 6 editorial dealing with oil import quotas was both superficial and factually inaccurate. It misstated the recommendations of Secretary Shultz's group and also misrepresented the economic implications of oil import controls by focusing on the peripheral issue of costs to the consumer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -After Minnesota drove 69 yards to the Chicago 5-yard line, only to be pushed back by a penalty, the Vikings' Fred Cox missed a 27-yard field goal in the closing seconds and the Bears upset the Vikings, 13-10, tonight.

Four Newark veterans of the Vietnam war period, two marines, an infantryman and a Wave, told yesterday of the frustrations they had had getting jobs, schooling and medical care in a nation they thought they had served.

Steel production for the week ended Oct. 21 rose by 4.2 per cent to 2.7 million net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 2,591,000 tons a year earlier. The industry's production index rose to 110.7 from 106.2 a year earlier.

About 200 veterans, most of whom had fought in longago wars and marched triumphantly to the acclaim of long-ago crowds, paraded down Fifth Avenue yesterday before modest crowds, to celebrate Veterans Day.

With few exceptions, outside of the major ballet companies, the classic ballets are subjected to ill-conceived performances. One of the notable exceptions is the Eglevsky Ballet Company, currently giving a series of six performances of "Coppelia" in the Greater New York area.
Mayor Lindsay has agreed to support a plan to convert the controversial low-income Forest Hills housing project into a low-income cooperative.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Despite bad weather, the Air Force refused today to give up hope as the search for a light plane carrying the House Democratic leader, Hale Boggs, and three other men entered its second week.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Sierra Club has appealed for national controls on the production and use of all types of energy including power plants, transmission lines, dams, oil and gas pipeplines, strip mining, and storage of radioactive wastes.

SOUTH STRAFFORD, Vt. -- A hunter's moon washed the hills and valleys of Vermont the previous evening, and in the morning frosty leaves crunched underfoot and icicles gleamed on the rocks of trout streams.
MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- Japan and the Soviet Union today ended their first formal peace treaty talks deadlocked on the key issue of four Soviet-held islands that the Japanese want returned.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- Representatives of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union opened talks today on a joint declaration to reassert four-power rights and responsibilities for Berlin and Germany as a whole.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Oct. 20 -- "When Trudeau talks Canadian unity he's thinking one thing while we're thinking another," a passenger on a Vancouver bus complained.
A few Long Island Rail Road trains were delayed yesterday, one as much as 29 minutes, but a spokesman attributed it to equipment failures rather than to the waning "sickout" of protesting trainmen.

The investigation into the murder of a six-week-old boy at his christening party in Brooklyn continued yesterday with the interviewing of many of the 50 people who were at the party and with forensic studies by the Medical Examiner's office.
